So it is important in Mental Health Week to recognise the importance of resourcing the organisations that provide those microcommunities for those who cannot sustain their relationships elsewhere.

There is a fine example of such a constructed microcommunity in my electorate of Parramatta. The Parramatta Leisure Club, run by Parramatta Mission, the Schizophrenia Fellowship and Sydney West Area Health Service, provides a place where people can meet and interact. It provides a highly effective support structure for people living with mental illness. Members and staff meet in a social environment and decide together the nature of leisure activities.

The Parramatta Leisure Centre has 433 clients and a staff of just four. That is over 100 clients for each staff member. It offers people a place to go, where members are comfortable and in control, and a sense of belonging. Perhaps most importantly, through the staff it offers someone just to notice if things start going wrong—a small group of people who notice the changes in behaviour that might precede a deterioration. Members are in regular contact with people who care about the wellbeing of the individuals and know enough about them to provide real human support if things go wrong. It is such a simple thing, that sense of belonging, but it makes a critical difference to people suffering from mental illness.

The real tragedy in our current mental health system is that when we shut down the institutions the resources did not follow the people as they moved back into our community. Since the early 1990s, in the absence of adequate care and with the failure of the money to follow the need, significant concerns have been raised about problems with deinstitutionalisation, including vagrancy, poverty, homelessness, increased care burden on families and increased inappropriate involvement of mentally ill people in the criminal justice system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This week being National Mental Health Week, I feel it is appropriate to talk about the work being done in my electorate of Makin by DRUG ARM Australasia. I would like to note that we have the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing, the member for Sturt, in the chamber this evening.

speech.para: Recently the Get Set program launched its CD within my electorate of Makin. The CD was created by a group of young people who wanted to use their personal experiences to teach their peers and the community about the harms and risks associated with illicit drugs. Get Set is a valuable program which has been implemented as a strategy within DRUG ARM. I have informed the House on previous occasions about DRUG ARM, which, for those people who are not aware, stands for Drug Awareness and Relief Movement.

DRUG ARM is a national, non-government, non-profit drug and alcohol agency founded upon basic Christian principles that I have supported and been involved with since around 2000. It was in 2000 that the South Australian coordinator, Ms Bianca Moerman, conveyed to me the work the agency does with individuals, families and the entire community who have in some way experienced the harm and destruction of illegal substances. Apart from the many other services and programs DRUG ARM implements, it saw the strong need for a young people’s project addressing drug misuse in the community. With the support of the organisation and federal funding, DRUG ARM was able to implement a peer education strategy to meet this vital need.

The aim of Get Set is to identify and bring together young people already at risk from their illicit drug use and encourage these people to build strategies to develop protective factors within their communities. Get Set’s operational procedure is to work with and support young people who in the past have misused illicit drugs. Through these young people, and the projects within their communities, DRUG ARM aims to deliver peer education strategies to empower a greater number of young people to make informed decisions about their lives and behaviours surrounding drug use.

In December last year, a group of young people engaged in Get Set created their vision on how to use their personal experiences to teach their peers. That vision was sharing their stories in a book and a CD that they are now publishing and have produced entirely amongst themselves. Their commitment to that vision has had them turn up each week for the past eight months to workshops and group sessions and support each other to have this vision come to life.

Not only did these weekly group sessions focus on the peer education strategy; they were also a powerful tool in stabilising their lives and drug use. Inside this group they developed a sense of belonging, they created a peer group of support where drug use is not accepted and they have participated in a positive and constructive community project. This has not only allowed them to achieve what they set out to achieve but also given them purpose and empowerment.

These young people stood up and delivered their project to their peers, their community and their families. The weeks of workshopping, writing their own stories, making them into lyrics and creating music that other people would listen and relate to finally came together. Their CD was launched and it has been an amazing success. They could relate standing together in front of an audience to taking the stand in front of their peers and saying no to using drugs.

It would be remiss of me to speak on this issue without applauding the Howard government’s Tough on Drugs policy. Since 1997, the government has allocated more than $1 billion to its national strategy against illicit drugs—Tough on Drugs. This strategy focuses on combining the efforts of individuals, families, businesses, community organisations, law enforcement agencies and government to contribute to fighting the drug problem. It is an integrated plan that comprehensively addresses law enforcement, prevention, treatment and education.

The latest National Drug Strategy household survey revealed that, in the three years to 2001, there was an extraordinary 23 per cent reduction in the proportion of people using illicit drugs. The implementation of Tough on Drugs has also contributed to a reduction in the number of heroin deaths among 15- to 44-year-olds, falling from 958 deaths in 1999 to 364 in 2002—a decline of more than 62 per cent. I would like to acknowledge the combined efforts of DRUG ARM, the Howard government and the city of Tea Tree Gully. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to mention a four-letter word that is hardly ever mentioned in this chamber at the moment: Iraq. In the review of the House of Representatives Annual Report 2002-03, the Clerk talks about the 71 hours of debate on Iraq in that financial year. We had two substantive motions: six months before hostilities commenced, in September 2002, about 85 members of the House spoke; and six weeks before hostilities commenced, in February 2003, 132 of the 150 members of this place spoke in the debate.

speech.para: Since then, what have been the contributions on this important and ongoing subject? In 2005, there have been nine speakers on a ministerial debate on Iraq. In that ministerial statement the Prime Minister indicated the Australian task group deployment of 450 troops to Al Muthanna province in southern Iraq to work closely with the Japanese-Iraq construction support group.

Last year, in 2004, there were two MPIs—one in May, with four speakers; and one in March, with four speakers. In grievance debates, member statements and adjournment speeches, there were five contributions. In June 2004, there was another MPI, in which there were five speakers. In 2003, after hostilities in Iraq were supposed to have finished, there were 12 speeches in grievance statements, adjournments and private members’ speeches. There were six contributions to an important debate following the terrorist attack on the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad.

Why have contributions on this important subject dropped off? The analysis of the Iraq situation indicates that 1,950 members of the United States military have died since the beginning of the war in March 2003—1,500 of them in hostile action. Some 14,900 US servicemen have been wounded. In addition, 96 of the United Kingdom’s military have died and there have been 102 fatalities from the military forces of other countries. Damning evidence about Iraqi civilian casualties has been collected. It is estimated by the best methods that around 25,000 people have died. In May, the Oxford Research Group estimated the number to be 24,865. Some 37 per cent of those deaths were at the hands of the US and coalition military forces. Some 30 per cent of the civilian casualties occurred between March and May 2003. On average, 34 Iraqis met a violent death every day between March 2003 and May 2005. If there is to be the continuing involvement of over 1,000 Australian Defence Force personnel in Iraq or in the region, we need to consider our expectations of the outcomes of continued deployment in Iraq.

An interesting report on an allied matter was produced by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, called Weapons of mass destruction: Australia’s role in fighting proliferation—practical responses to new challenges. There would be merit in this parliament discussing the report. It confirms that the weapons of mass destruction that were used as an excuse for going into Iraq did not exist. Hence it is time that this government brought forward another motion. If it was good enough to have 71 hours of debate before we went into Iraq, and we are still there 2½ years later, why don’t we have a fully-fledged debate on this subject? Why is it that we do not discuss the outcomes? Why is it that, 2½ years later, Australia is still involved? What is Australia’s exit strategy? Is there a risk of a fully-fledged civil war between the Shia and the Sunni? Now that we have been into Iraq with the other coalition partners, has it increased the chances of Iraq being a training ground for terrorists? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I thought the standing orders provided that ministers were not eligible to participate in adjournment debates unless there were no other members jumping for the call.
—Are you seeking the call?
—I am indeed.
—I call the member for Hunter.

—I was flabbergasted during question time today when the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in response to a dorothy dixer from his backbench, wanted to celebrate the fact that the New South Wales government had decided to sign the AusLink agreement. The New South Wales government has been reluctant to sign the AusLink agreement for a number of reasons, but two stand out. The first is the fact that the Commonwealth government is using the AusLink agreement, like so many other processes in this place, to tie funding to certain conditions. In this case, to give just one example, it was to impose the Commonwealth government’s industrial relations agenda on the New South Wales government’s tenders for roadworks in that state. Just as importantly, despite what the government says, for the New South Wales government the AusLink document is nothing like a good financial deal.

speech.para: I remind the House of the arrangement. For the first time in more than three decades, the Commonwealth has unilaterally decided that there will not be a national highway project in this country. Up until now, there has been a national highway project. The Commonwealth has been responsible for the funding of the national highway project, and the states and territories have taken care of the balance of the road networks in each of their states. The Commonwealth has suddenly decided that there will not be a national highway network. The Commonwealth would rather put its investment into the areas where it thinks it will get the best political return. As a consequence, the Commonwealth now expects the state governments to put money into road networks which traditionally form part of the national highway network. This is not a net benefit to the New South Wales government in financial terms.

Let me give you the best example of all. Mr Speaker, if I had not been officially warned by you during question time, I would have had something to say about this at that time. I challenged the minister for transport to tell us what is happening with the link road between the F3 Freeway, at the northern end, and the New England Highway, north of Branxton. This is an important transport link for the Hunter community. In fact, the Hunter’s mayors unanimously agreed that this is the most important piece of transport infrastructure that will ever be built in the Hunter.

When the Howard government was elected in 1996, we were entitled to believe with great confidence that this road would be constructed by 2005. Hunter residents, and all those residents that pass through the Hunter region on their way north or south, would have used this road. Until recently it was believed that the F3 link to Branxton would cost about $320 million to construct. Alas, when you keep putting off a project because of funding cuts, the project gets more expensive. I have been warning for a while that the project costs were blowing out, and it has now been confirmed that the cost of the project has blown out to some $750 million.

The Commonwealth government say: ‘We are committed to this road project. Some $253 million has been earmarked within AusLink. Therefore, our slate is clean. We are showing a commitment to this project.’ But $253 million out of a $750 million project is a pittance. Where does the minister for transport think the balance of the funds will come from? He is surely not suggesting that the New South Wales government has the resources to find some $500 million to construct this important road project.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8 pm, the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: D r N elson to present a bill for an act to make provision in relation to the selection of a site for, and the establishment and operation of, a radioactive waste management facility, and for related purposes. (Commonwealth Radioactive Waste Management Bill 2005)

D r N elson to present a bill for an act to make an amendment related to the Commonwealth Radioactive Waste Management Act 2005, and for related purposes. (Commonwealth Radioactive Waste Management (Related Amendment) Bill 2005)

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 10.10 am.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise in this place to discuss Mental Health Week and to touch on a few issues related to that. It is important to reflect on the overall costs of mental health to the community. We know from an Australian National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing that 20 per cent of adult Australians experience a mental health problem, 14 per cent of children and adolescents experience mental illness and three per cent of adults have a serious mental illness. If you look at mental illness in terms of the total disease burden in this country, you will see that it is roughly 13 per cent. It represents roughly 30 per cent of the non-fatal disease burden. Clearly, it is a very significant problem.

speech.para: If you look at the suicide rate for last year, you will see that it was 2,454 people. A significant majority of those people committed suicide as a consequence of their mental illness. One would think, given the scope of this particular problem in the community, that governments of all persuasions would be putting bucket loads of funding into solving this issue. Unfortunately, as I continue to report to this House, funding across all levels of government for mental health is about seven per cent of the total health budget. We have a massive problem: some 2,454 Australians committing suicide per year, mostly as a consequence of this particular problem, yet seven per cent of the total government health budget across this country is spent on mental health. I think that is a disgrace, particularly when you look at countries like New Zealand that spend roughly 14 per cent of their health budget on mental health.

I would like to think that we would lead New Zealand in a whole range of areas—we trumpet that. So we are behind other First World countries. Many other First World countries spend between 10 and 14 per cent of their total health budget on mental health. The fact is that 62 per cent of Australians who have a mental health problem cannot access mental health services. Of the 38 per cent who do, most will see a GP. They are the gatekeepers for our mental health system. Unfortunately I report to this House today that, if you look at the Better Outcomes in Mental Health program that helps doctors treat people with mental illness, you will see that it had an underspend of $63 million. This was a $121 million program over four years to help GPs provide better mental health outcomes to patients—the some 38 per cent of people who access those services. The fact is that, in commemorating Mental Health Week and looking at the mental health of Australians, when we look at government inaction and underspending on this issue, for the least advantaged in our community, it is a national disgrace. We have to do something about it or more Australians will die. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On Friday, 7 October I was fortunate enough to visit ANSTO’s Lucas Heights research station and be given a tour of that facility. In particular, I was fortunate to see the new OPAL reactor that is currently being constructed there. The visit was certainly an eye-catching and eye-opening moment. I saw the processes conducted at the reactor that contribute to many of the health treatments of diseases that we have in Australia, including cardiac disease, cancer and the like. I strongly believe that science and technology into the future will provide us with more options for and solutions to the treatment of serious, and possibly terminal, health problems, as is the case with current science and technology. The current reactor generates many of the treatments for cancer patients in Australia at a lower cost than if we were to import products from overseas. After my visit, I am more than ever convinced that the new Lucas Heights reactor plays a critical role in the treatment of many of the health problems of Australians and is critical in solving future health problems.

speech.para: In order for the new reactor to be licensed, the government faces a fairly serious time line to find a possible site for a nuclear waste repository. The government needs to act to ensure that Australians in need of pharmaceuticals do not lose that access. A critical part of the licensing condition for the new OPAL reactor—the open pool Australian light water medical and research reactor—at Lucas Heights is that Australia must have in place a store for our own reprocessed fuel due to the mandatory return of waste from Scotland and France. If a decision on a site for waste management cannot be made within a matter of months, Australia will no longer be allowed to produce radioactive isotopes that are used in hospitals in every state and territory of Australia. For that reason I am very keen to see a decision made very quickly on the location of a suitable repository.

My visit to ANSTO was extraordinarily interesting and extraordinarily well conducted. I would particularly like to thank the director of ANSTO, Dr Ian Smith, and all his staff for the wonderful efforts they made to show me around the place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to add my voice to the growing number of people concerned about the prospects for any kind of peaceful future for Iraq in the near term and to repeat a number of questions that have been put to the government in relation to this issue both by the opposition here in the parliament and by the public and my constituents. It is critical that we not be distracted by cheap politicking from the essential features of the Iraq engagement nor from the fact that this war, which the Howard government took us into, was against the wishes of a majority of Australians. That this military engagement was based on a lie remains a great shame; that it breached the norms and accepted principles of international law is to our discredit. The decision of the Howard government to participate in that most serious of national undertakings without thinking through the consequences that flow from committing troops to the far side of the world without a strategy for engagement or exit is increasingly exposed as short-termism of the worst kind. It is to the great credit of Australia’s service men and women that the engagement has been conducted with great courage and skill, but it is a matter of phenomenal luck that, throughout the war in Iraq, our personnel have been relatively unscathed—and we must fervently hope this remains the case. Tragically, it has not been so in relation to US personnel nor the region generally.

speech.para: These men and women are poorly served by the downpour of cliches that pass for debate from government members on this issue. It seems that members opposite are completely unaware of the international dynamic that led to the war and the increasingly intractable problems that the war has spawned. Central to the Iraq question—especially in light of the growing need for additional resources to be applied to antiterrorism measures and the predicted shortfall of $1 billion per year in the defence budget identified this week by the Kokoda Foundation—is the question of why the government does not simply throw away the neocon phrasebook and square up to explaining what is happening now in relation to Australia’s ongoing involvement in Iraq.

The British Joint Intelligence Committee made it plain in its assessment of February 2003 that the threat from al-Qaeda and associated groups would be heightened by military action against Iraq. This was confirmed by AFP Commissioner Mick Keelty before the government pulled him into line. The French Ambassador remarked only this morning that France’s stance on the war was right and Australia’s wrong. Notwithstanding the upcoming referendum on an Iraq constitution, it is difficult to conceive of anything other than increasing instability, terrorism and violence in Iraq. That is to be hugely regretted. So it is time for the government to explain clearly what it now means by ‘getting the job done’. Are there conditions and a timetable for troop withdrawal? What will our response be if civil war breaks out across Iraq? What in the interim will be done in relation to the pressing, serious shortfalls in security capacity in our region? Those are the questions for the Prime Minister and the foreign minister, and we demand an answer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to tell the House about the great volunteer small equipment grants through which the residents of La Trobe were able to secure $25,000 in funding. One of the recipients was the St Vincent de Paul Society in Upper Ferntree Gully, which received over $2,000 through the round of volunteer small equipment grants. St Vincent de Paul received the grant for an electric heater and 400 reusable food parcel carry bags. It is important to note that any funding these organisations receive must go back to the people they are there to help. Therefore they cannot purchase products like this for their own organisation. I am very glad to say that the Howard government was able to assist them with their needs.

speech.para: I met with Gordon Veerasawmy, Judy Atu, Allan Bailey, Dennis Buckley, Bev McNamara, Connie Bala, Elsie Johnson, Wally Johnson, Brother Michael, Peter Springfellow, Vivian Springfellow and Adele Paterson on 27 August this year to discuss local issues and congratulate them on the valuable contribution they make to the local community. The society exists primarily to provide home assistance to the poor. It understands their personal need for as much assistance as its resources will allow. I am thrilled that the society was successful in its application under this grants scheme as it acknowledges the hard work and dedication of these local volunteers. Each of the society’s members works tirelessly on a voluntary basis, providing one-on-one assistance for the people of our local community who need the most help. Each month they assist approximately 30 people through their efforts. The provision of an electric heater and reusable food parcels carry bags will make a significant difference to the services they provide to the local community. This organisation may not have been otherwise able to afford these items.

On a final note, I would like to make special mention of Gordon Veerasawmy, who went above and beyond the group’s responsibilities recently after I received a call for help from Merv and Elaine Vincent, who had an old stove they needed removed but were unable to do it themselves. My office contacted Gordon to see if there was anything the society could do. Gordon, with the assistance of Dennis, quickly went to the house, removed the heater and took it to the tip. It is little things like this which make St Vincent de Paul’s a great community group. Again, I wish to strongly thank this organisation for the fantastic work they do in the local community.

talk.start.para: —There is significant concern within our community about the installation of mobile phone towers in heavily populated areas. This concern is especially serious when towers are installed near sensitive areas such as schools, kindergartens and hospitals. Today I rise to reaffirm Labor’s commitment to strengthening the regulatory policies governing mobile phone towers and highlight the shambles created by a government unable to show leadership over a dispute between local councils, communities and the growing telecommunications industry. Battlelines have been drawn in the Australian suburbs, with communities fearing the effects of mobile communication towers on their health and councils and telecommunications at each other in the courts seeking clarification over legislation.

speech.para: This crisis was highlighted again to me the other day when I met with some residents of Goodwood who were concerned over potential health risks associated with a mobile phone tower that has been built, without community input, on a building next to a local primary school. Although it had been modified after pressure from the community and local councils, people were still concerned about health risks and the inability of local councils to significantly alter the construction of these towers.

Unley City Council Mayor, Mr Michael Keenan—a very good and hardworking mayor, I might add—is so concerned about telecommunications companies simply bypassing council planning regulations that he tabled a report at the Unley City Council meeting that led to a motion financially supporting a legal battle that has now reached the High Court. He believes the council has no option but to add their support, for, if successful, telecommunications companies will have a legal precedent to bypass local council processes in the future. Telecommunications companies are arguing in the courts that they are exempt from council planning processes due to the Telecommunications Act. Local councils consider the towers constitute a development issue and are therefore under their jurisdiction. In the latest round, the Supreme Court ruled in favour of the councils, though granted leave for the telecommunications company to appeal the decision in the High Court. This is a problem that could have been easily solved by simple legislation and some government leadership, instead of lengthy court battles.

Labor released a policy at the last election that would have directly confronted this issue, promising to introduce stricter guidelines, give support for local council procedures and continue to listen to and act on the concerns of local communities. I want to reaffirm this commitment and call on the government to implement Labor’s initiative and provide some leadership on the issue. I pledge to my constituents in Goodwood—and, indeed, to all of the constituents in Adelaide—that I shall continue to fight for the rights of local communities when it comes to the placement of mobile phone towers in our neighbourhoods. I would also like to pledge my support to Mayor Michael Keenan and the Unley council for the action that they are taking to stick up for the residents of Adelaide.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to talk about a very important issue which is facing my electorate: the location of a new gaming facility with up to 40 new poker machines in the suburb of Morphett Vale. This is a suburb which is already highly saturated with clubs and pubs. Straight opposite the proposed site is an RSL eternal flame site along with the Morphett Vale Memorial Bowling Club and the Morphett Vale Football Club. According to local welfare groups which are dealing with the issue of problem gambling at a grassroots level, this particular suburb already has a higher than average rate of gambling addiction, associated social problems and family breakdown. This is an area which has been targeted by Club One. The proprietors have lodged the development application with the City of Onkaparinga because its high level of problem gamblers will ensure higher profits. These unscrupulous operators are targeting the area with no thought for the social consequences and without concern for the lives, families and communities they will destroy.

speech.para: There are houses within 80 metres of this proposed pokie parlour whose occupants enjoy a pleasant and peaceful lifestyle. If this new gaming facility is to be approved, their lives and the value of their homes are about to deteriorate. The late-night trading hours applied for—up to midnight during the week, 2 am on Saturdays and midnight on Sunday nights—are absolutely disgraceful. There is limited parking available on this site already, and with the additional customers to the site people will be parking in the side streets and in front of these homes. The extra noise and vehicles at midnight or at 2 am are certainly not what the residents in that area are looking forward to.

I initially doorknocked and within two hours I had obtained 500 signatures to a petition which has now been lodged with the City of Onkaparinga council. Since then I have collected a further 2,000 signatures to the petition to ensure that this proposed pokie facility does not go ahead. I would like to thank the residents and concerned citizens of the southern suburbs for their commitment to saying enough is enough. As a former police officer within the southern suburbs, I have seen first-hand the problem effects of gambling and what it does to a poor socioeconomic area such as the southern suburbs. We are fighting for this one to ensure that it does not go ahead for the people of the southern suburbs and for the people of Adelaide.

talk.start.para: —On 15 July this year, despite promises made prior to the last federal election and prior to the last Northern Territory election, Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, announced three possible sites for nuclear waste repositories in the Northern Territory. As I said earlier, this was despite undertakings given and promises made prior to the last federal election. Since the announcement in July, Territorians of all political flavours have rallied in their opposition to the proposal. They have rallied in seeking information and clarification from the Commonwealth about what is proposed. They want answers to fundamental questions such as: is the Territory the safest place to store nuclear waste and is it scientifically demonstrated to be the best option? What they learnt subsequently is that it is not. The most preferred sites are in New South Wales, in National Party and Liberal Party seats. Has the decision to place nuclear waste in the Territory been a political convenience? Of course it has, as evidenced by the fact that the most preferred sites are in fact in New South Wales. They want answers to these questions and to the observation made by Brendan Nelson:

quote.para: … why on earth can’t people in the middle of nowhere have low level and intermediate level waste?

speech.para: You can imagine the anger of the people of the Northern Territory when they heard that, particularly the traditional owners of the country which has been identified as a possible site. There are three sites: one to the north-west of Alice Springs, one to the north-east of Alice Springs and one to the south-west of Katherine.

People are angry at the failure of the government to take them into its confidence, consult with them and talk to them about what it was proposing. The Central Australia Community Alliance has been formed to oppose a proposal for nuclear waste facilities. This alliance is made up of members of political parties, environment groups, Indigenous organisations and traditional owners, as well as local government. One of its first actions was to organise a public meeting to hear the views of the community before a panel of representatives of local government, Territory government and environment groups. I was also on the panel as the federal member. The meeting prepared a list of questions which was forwarded to Brendan Nelson. Of course, we have had no response. Three hundred people attended this meeting. I am pleased to say that, since this initial public meeting, the community has conducted a very successful Hiroshima Day rally, based on their opposition to the expansion of the nuclear industry but most particularly the proposition of nuclear waste dumps in the Northern Territory.

Finally, last week Lhere Artepe, the Aboriginal corporation representing traditional owners, held a march and meeting in Alice Springs. This rally was supported by the Arid Land Environmental Centre, the Australian Conservation Foundation—
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 10.31 am to 10.35 am

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—Before we resume the clock on members’ statements, I want to apologise to the member for Lingiari. If I had been more on guard, I would have let him finish the 17 seconds remaining for his statement.

—The rally by the Northern Territory government, the Central Land Council and the Alice Springs Town Council gave the Indigenous perspective on the opposition to the dump. The campaign continues and Territorians are united in their resolve to prevent the government imposing nuclear waste facilities on the Northern Territory without the agreement of the Northern Territory government or the community.

—The passing of the Telstra legislation through this House is an important milestone for telecommunications in this country. The $3.1 billion Connecting Australia program—providing $1.1 billion for mobile phone and broadband and $2 billion for the Future Fund to ensure that regional Australia gets excellent telecommunications services not only now but into the future—is vital to the future of this nation. The government realises that, if we are to have competitive small businesses, quality educational services, good health services and economic development in regional and rural areas, we need to have telecommunications infrastructure that is going to support that. Telecommunications is playing very much the role that the railways did in the 19th century in providing opportunities for business in more isolated areas.

speech.para: I would like to comment on some new facilities that have been installed in my electorate. The mobile phone tower near the small town of Bowraville in the Nambucca Valley will mean not only improved telecommunications services for the locals but also greater convenience and safety for people who are perhaps working out on farms by themselves, and tourists will be able to travel throughout the Nambucca Valley and still be in contact with their offices. Many tourists cannot be away from phone services; they need to be able to stay in contact with their office in order to have a holiday.

Another tower has been installed in the town of Maclean. When it is fully commissioned, it will provide improved CDMA and GSM services for the town of Maclean, the area of the Pacific Highway near the town and areas in the west of Yamba which have suffered from poorer mobile phone services than would be ideal. So I am delighted to see these two towers, in particular, being installed in my electorate in response to the telecommunications needs of the people in the electorate of Cowper.

A tower was also recently installed in upper Macleay, near the town of Bellbrook. Despite there being a relatively low population density in that area, this tower is providing much needed mobile phone communications in a sparsely populated area. This was supported by the government. This tower would not have been there except for the telecommunications policies of this government to ensure that people in regional and rural areas have equity of access to telecommunications services.

These services are vital if we are going to expand our business opportunities in those areas. They are vital to the safety of the people of the upper Macleay Valley and are vital in providing equity of opportunity for people who want to live right around this country. The government recognises the fact that there is a role for government in providing services which would not be provided on a commercial basis. The government believes that it should be spending taxpayers’ money not on subsidising phone companies but on providing telecommunications services which would not be viable on a commercial basis.

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—The time for members’ statements will expire in 60 seconds, but I propose to allow the member for Port Adelaide to have the whole three minutes—and I thank the member for Gellibrand for reducing her speech to accommodate that.

—I appreciate the contribution by the member for Gellibrand as well. On 21 September I was asked by the business groups of the western suburbs of Adelaide to give an address to their meeting—a non-political speech on humour, public transport and the history of transport in Port Adelaide and the western suburbs. It was a fascinating exercise to delve into the history of public transport in South Australia and make some comparisons in the modern context with what goes on today.

speech.para: It was interesting to find out that South Australia built the first railway from Adelaide to Port Adelaide but the railway sleepers were set longitudinally, not at right angles. Of course, on the first trip with all the dignitaries on board, the obvious thing happened. The rail also had no ballast and so the locomotive ploughed a 30-metre furrow through the ground. It was a very embarrassing start. It is interesting also to note that in 1860 the frequency of the services from Port Adelaide to Adelaide was 20 minutes. That is better than it is today. In the 1950s the transport system from Port Adelaide to Adelaide ran every two minutes in peak period. That is far better than it is today.

There are some principles about public transport in Australia that only one city, today, has ever followed. I will come to that in a moment. Trains are most useful for long distances, speed, and they need to run at a frequency of at least 15 minutes. Trams are most useful and much better than buses or any other form of transport on regular routes and buses are used for the rest. It is interesting in a modern context that only one city in this country fulfils the trifecta of good public transport principles and that is Melbourne. Perth and Brisbane have excellent modern electric rail systems but little else. They have one-way streets and an overreliance on buses and a very poor public transport system. Adelaide is showing some signs of moving in the right direction by extending its only light rail system and hopefully joining it in—as the people in Melbourne did with Port Melbourne and St Kilda—to the rail network.

It is interesting that the biggest and the smallest cities in Australia, Sydney and Hobart, have absolutely the worst public transport. They do not follow any principles whatsoever. In Sydney, their rail system is in trouble. They have no tram system to speak of, there is an overreliance on buses and they rely on one-way streets. Hobart, the smallest city in Australia, does exactly the same. Why, God only knows. It is hard to admit sometimes as a South Australian that the Victorians have actually got it right in public transport. Whenever you hear criticism of Victorian public transport I hope that it is made in the context that they are correct.

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—Order! In accordance with the resolution agreed to in the House earlier, the time for members’ statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT (STORED COMMUNICATIONS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 does have a long history, which I will take some time later in my speech to go through. The bill before the House now introduces a number of amendments which will tidy up the act, extend provisions for the use of intercepted material and provide that certain agencies are now eligible to access the powers granted under the act. The bill adds an additional paragraph into the act allowing that the prohibition against interception would not apply in relation to the interception of a stored communication. I will go into the definition of ‘stored communication’ in some detail.

speech.para: Essentially, the bill before us today seeks to implement five measures. Firstly, it will extend the use of intercepted material for the following currently eligible authorities: the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption; the New South Wales Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission; and the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission. The bill will correct anomalies concerning these bodies which will enable them to have effective use of intercepted material. This will allow those bodies to use lawfully obtained intercepted material to the full extent envisaged by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Additionally, it will allow the Inspector of ICAC, the Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission and the Crime and Misconduct Commission to similarly receive and use lawfully obtained intercepted material to the extent that other eligible authorities are permitted to under the interception act.

Secondly, it will expand the list of eligible state authorities by two, adding the Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption to the list. Under the amendments, these state authorities will now be able to access the act’s powers, allowing them to receive and use lawfully obtained intercepted material for the purpose of the investigation of police corruption and misconduct. This is partially the outcome of a settlement between the Commonwealth and Victoria and it is contingent on the enactment of certain legislation by Victoria, which I will discuss later. The legislation will not operate if suitable arrangements and legislation are not in place in Victoria within the relevant time frame.

Thirdly, this bill will extend provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant for an additional six months. Essentially, this will allow the status quo to continue for the following six months. A ‘stored communication’ is defined in the bill as a communication that is stored on equipment or any other thing, but does not include communication stored on a highly transitory basis such as voice over IP or any other communication where the storage is merely transitory as an integral part of the technology used in its transmission. This exception will have effect for 18 months. There was an original 12 months proposed in an earlier bill and an additional six months extension to the sunset clause. Within this time a review of the act is to be undertaken. The time frame of 18 months for the review is appropriate given the far-reaching recommendations of the Blunn review, the complex nature of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and the even more complex nature of modern telecommunications technology.

There are a number of recommendations made by the review of access to stored communications. The government has requested an additional six months to consider changes to the interception act and we believe that this is appropriate given the complexity of the issues at hand. We accept that the extension of the sunset clause is necessary to allow the government additional time within which to properly assess and respond to the substantive findings and recommendations of the Blunn review. This review was constituted in March this year and completed in August.

Fourthly, the bill will clarify the expression ‘officer of state’ to include all members of police services of that state. Under the previous legislation there was uncertainty as to whether police officers were covered. The amendments clarify this and it now means that it will be a permitted purpose under the act for the state police to pass lawfully intercepted material to a body established to investigate alleged misbehaviour of a member of the police force.

Finally, this bill will remove references to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 consequential to the enactment of the Legislative Instruments Act 2003. The amendment in this section will clarify that, when the minister makes a declaration under section 34 of the interception act, the minister is creating a legislative instrument. The effect of this will be that such declarations will fall under the definition of a legislative instrument that is present in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

As I mentioned earlier, the bill will add the Victorian Office of Police Integrity to the list of organisations with access to the powers under the act. The Victorian Office of Police Integrity, upon its establishment in November 2004, was initially refused a grant of these powers under the act by the federal government. The reason given for the refusal for the grant of powers was an apparent conflict of interest by the Victorian Ombudsman who was responsible for both running the new body and also, in his role as Ombudsman, the oversight of such powers. The Victorian government has agreed to introduce appropriate oversight amendments and, in accordance with this, the current bill grants interception powers to the OPI for 12 months from the assent of this bill. Within that time frame the Victorian government has agreed to enact the oversight legislation or face the loss of those powers if it does not do so.

This represents a significant win for the Bracks government of Victoria and a significant cave in by the Howard government. The extension of the telecommunications interception powers was first called for by Premier Bracks some time ago and the Bracks government has to be congratulated for being able to now resolve this issue. I would also like to congratulate the Howard government for backing down from its original position and agreeing to the request made by the Victorian government. Despite initially resisting the call from the Bracks government for alterations to the act, it has subsequently decided to act on the recommendations of the Victorian state government. It is refreshing to see that the government, in this instance at least, has not allowed its extremist ideological predispositions to interfere with its commonsense.

The bill will assist state agencies in their fight against corruption and as such should be supported. The Labor Party is supporting the bill with the extension of the sunset clause by six months. The Labor Party, as I have mentioned, has supported the extension due to the extensive nature of the Blunn review. The review identified the need for a comprehensive and overriding legislative framework to deal with access to telecommunications for the purpose of security and law enforcement.

While speaking on this bill, I must note that this is the third bill that the government has introduced to sort out the issue of stored communications under the act. An initial bill providing for amendments to the act was introduced in 2002. Its intent was to remove the requirement for a telecommunications interception warrant where a stored communication could have been accessed without the use of a telecommunications line. A colleague in the Senate, a member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, has advised me that the committee recommended the opposite to this proposal in 2002 and recommended that such data did require a TI warrant in order to be accessed. As a result of the good work of that committee, the provisions of that bill were withdrawn by the government.

Then a second bill was introduced which largely kept intact the powers to access a TI stored communication without a warrant but introduced new provisions to distinguish between messages which had been accessed by the recipient and those that had not. Under the regime of the second bill, a message could be accessed without a warrant if it could be accessed without the use of a telecommunications line and it had already been accessed by the recipient. This second bill had further provisions for accessing a message where it had not already been accessed by the recipient but where access could be gained with equipment that the intended recipient could have used and this did not require the use of a telecommunications line.

However, practical difficulties became evident with the second bill. Evidence was heard by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee that it would be difficult for an internet service provider to ascertain what had been accessed by the recipient and what had not. Furthermore, there was significant confusion: differing accounts from the Attorney-General’s Department and the Australian Federal Police as to whether powers already granted to the Federal Police allowed access to stored information without a warrant. The Senate committee further recommended, firstly, that the legislation be deferred until there was agreement between the AFP and the A-G’s department on the operation of the TI regime and, secondly, that the bill be amended to provide for a review of its operation and consideration of whether stored communications should be exempt from the review. The provisions in the second bill which covered the stored communications exception to the interception power were to have a period of effect for 12 months from the date of the commencement. The Attorney-General also proposed that within that time a review of the act would be conducted. At that time the committee accepted the undertaking with the caveat that any review would be public, that it would seek submissions from the public and that its findings would be made public. The Blunn review accomplished both of these goals in seeking public submissions, which are now publicly available. The government did not ultimately proceed with this second bill. Instead it has introduced this third bill, which is before us today.

Labor is prepared to support this bill, although its history is a little tortuous, for the reasons that I have outlined. I commend it to the House. Before resuming my seat, I would like to record my thanks to my colleague Senator Ludwig and, for its work, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which seems to have handled this issue in great detail on many occasions and has done good work for the government in doing so.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to join the debate on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005. Most honourable members would be aware that the purpose of law enforcement agencies has always remained purely and simply to investigate and arrest those who break the law. A civilised society requires sanctions for those who breach the rules of that society; therefore, it is important that law enforcement agencies are given the appropriate tools to enable them to carry out their duties in the community interest. So I suppose you could say effectively the law enforcement agencies are the goodies and in some respects they are trying to catch the baddies. But over the years the changes that have occurred to technology have made new tools available to criminals and it is therefore important that crime fighters are able to stay up with the game. Often there is debate in the community as to where the balance should be between individual rights and the need to give law enforcement agencies the tools they require to do their job in an appropriate way. Thus, this is becoming a more and more complex area of legislation and the incredible intricacies of new technologies are well beyond the comprehension of many, and it is very interesting to see the way in which the technological knowledge of our community is galloping ahead at an ever-increasing pace.

speech.para: The purpose of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 is to ensure that some simple legal weapons are available to the various state organisations charged with investigating corruption and protecting the integrity of public positions. Among the modern documents that are now often integral to the investigation of corruption and are required during court proceedings are stored communications. This issue of equipping our crime fighters is a very important one, so earlier this year the Attorney-General, Mr Philip Ruddock—who in my view is one of the very best ministers this government has—appointed Mr AS Blunn AO to investigate the legislative framework that regulates access to stored communications. That report has been completed and its recommendations are being digested by the department. They will also obviously be considered by the government.

I think most honourable members would agree that this should be carried out thoroughly. It is important not to make or change policy on the run and in that regard one of the primary purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 is to extend for six months the provision set out in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 that enabled the authorities to access stored communications without first obtaining a warrant as required by the interception act. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested to hear that this was a measure that was first introduced courtesy of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2004—that is last year—along with a sunset clause that would see this valuable crime-fighting provision lapse in mid-December this year.

I have to say that I am one of those people who often have a concern that after more than 100 years of Federation we have accumulated on our statute books many laws that are really no longer required. It takes omnibus bills from time to time to clean up some of those irrelevant statutes and remove them from the statute books. An increased use of sunset clauses might mean that our legislation would automatically tidy itself up and not require amendment by omnibus bills, which so often will amend large numbers of acts of this parliament in one hit. Today’s bill simply extends the provision, which would have lapsed in mid-December this year, for an extra six months to mid-June 2006 while the analysis of Mr Blunn’s recommendations on access to stored communications is finalised. I am pleased to hear the shadow Attorney-General, the member for Gellibrand, indicate that the opposition is in fact supporting this bill.

The bill will enable better use of intercepted communications by those organisations involved in the investigation of corruption. These include—and I think most members are probably aware of them—the Crime and Misconduct Commission in Queensland, the Office of Police Integrity in Victoria, the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. These bodies already had some provisions available to them under the interception act of 1979, but they were restricted in the way that they could use intercepted documents. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 corrects that problem. Thankfully, unacceptable incidents of public servants behaving corruptly are rare. Any such behaviour by officials, police and any number of other government workers only serves to destabilise our communities, undermine our democracy and bring about a sense of alienation from and disillusionment with the political process. Corruption, once it begins, can quite often lead to further, even bigger crime: commercial fraud, money laundering and organised crime.

Not surprisingly, the bill currently before the House will also usher in several other minor changes. It will clarify the definition of an ‘officer of the state’ in that it will come to mean any officers of any of the state police forces—I think they call themselves police services these days—as well as civilian employees of those police services. These employees already came under the guidelines of the act and the bill serves to clear up any uncertainties. This feature also serves to remind all employees involved in the investigation of crimes, and the bringing to justice of those who commit crime, that they are also not above the law. While Australia might be seen to be relatively free of corruption in official positions compared to other countries we hear some quite appalling stories about, there have been documented cases in the past of which Australia ought not be proud.

This bill gives law enforcement agencies further clout to be able to fulfil their vital functions of weeding out the bad eggs and successfully bringing them to justice. I commend the Attorney on this legislation and commend, in particular, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005. I am also pleased to note that the opposition supports this bill. The purpose of the bill is to extend for six months provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. This bill also adds the Victorian Office of Police Integrity to the list of eligible authorities able to obtain telecommunications interception warrants for law enforcement purposes and allows various state bodies that are already eligible authorities to make greater use of lawfully obtained intercepted material.

speech.para: The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Act 2004 introduced into the interception act the concept of a ‘stored communication’ and provided that a stored communication could be intercepted without the need for a telecommunications interception warrant. Access to such communications could therefore be obtained by other lawful means, such as a normal search warrant.

The amendments also included a provision to the effect that any information obtained from intercepting a stored communication was not lawfully obtained information for the purposes of the interception act—that is, the information was not subject to the restrictions on use imposed by the interception act. The amendments were intended as an interim measure pending a thorough consideration of how best to regulate access to communications in the ever-changing world of technology. As an interim measure the amendments included a 12-month sunset clause, meaning that the provisions will cease to operate on 14 December 2005.

Since 1994 there have been four major reviews dealing with telecommunications interception. These were the 1994 review by Mr P Barrett into the long-term cost-effectiveness of telecommunications interception; in 1999, a review by Mr D Boucher of interception arrangements under section 332R of the Telecommunications Act 1997; the 1999 review by Mr P Ford of telecommunications interception policy; and the 2003 review, by Mr T Sherman AO, of named person warrants and other matters.

The latest review—the Anthony Blunn review of 2005 into the regulation of, and access to, communications—invited submissions from the public and, in particular, from parties which had demonstrated an interest in the previous reviews and in the legislative processes related to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Mr Blunn was asked to review the policy options for the regulation of access to telecommunications, with particular emphasis on new and emerging telecommunications technologies, having particular regard to protecting the privacy of users of the system.

Mr Blunn was also asked to consider and comment on the ongoing appropriateness of the current telecommunications interception regime and, if relevant, alternatives for the lawful access to content; the protection of information systems from attack by means of a telecommunications system, including the use of intrusion detection systems and other measures; the cost implications, including cost recovery mechanisms; and any other issues as they arose from the review.

Mr Blunn has now completed the review of the regulation of access to communications and has made a number of recommendations in relation to stored communications. These recommendations need to be fully considered and, where appropriate, implemented in order to ensure that the interception act is able to meet the demands of new and emerging technologies. This bill will therefore extend for six months the operation of the provisions dealing with access to stored communications.

By way of background, the current access regime is regulated through the provisions of the Telecommunications Act and the interception act. Very broadly, the Telecommunications Act, insofar as it is relevant, regulates the networks that carry or are capable of carrying communications. The scheme of the act is built around a structure of licensed carriers and carriage service providers which constitute the network. It concentrates on the obligations of those carriers and carriage service providers and associated persons in relation to accessing that network. Access is dealt with in parts 13, 14 and 15, which respectively deal with the protection of communications, the national interest matters and cooperation with agencies.

Importantly, part 13 provides, among other things, that eligible persons must not disclose or use any information accessed in the course of employment that relates to the content or substance of any communication that has been or is being carried by a carrier and carriage service provider, the service supplied or the affairs or personal particulars of another person. There are, however, a number of exceptions, including in relation to content or substance where disclosure or use is required in connection with the operation of an enforcement agency under a warrant or in any other case as required or authorised by law. More broadly, disclosure of information or a document but not in relation to content or substance is expected where disclosure is certified by an authorised officer as reasonably necessary for the purposes of national security, enforcing the criminal law or a law imposing a pecuniary penalty or protecting the public revenue.

Part 14 of the Telecommunications Act builds on part 13 in requiring carriers and carriage service providers to do their best to prevent telecommunication networks and facilities being used to commit offences and to give authorities such help as is reasonably necessary for the purposes of (1) enforcing the criminal law and the law imposing penalties, (2) protecting public revenue and (3) safeguarding national security.

Part 15 provides the structures through which the obligations in relation to interception are imposed on carrier and carriage service providers. For those purposes, interception consists of listening to or recording communication in its passage over a controlled network or controlled facility. The interception act deals only with the interception of telecommunications passing over a telecommunications system. Other than as provided, the act makes it an offence to intercept such communications. For the purposes of the act, interception consists of listening to or recording by any means a communication passing over a telecommunications system without the knowledge of the person making the communication.

There are a number of exceptions to the prohibition against interception. For law enforcement purposes, the most significant are those related to stored communications and to interceptions under a warrant. The interception act is now expressed to exclude stored communications. The relevant amendment is sunseted and, unless some action is taken before 15 December 2005, the provisions will lapse. Currently, access to the content or substance of communications stored within the system is achieved by a general search warrant obtained under relevant Commonwealth or state law which is executed under the provisions of part 13 of the Telecommunications Act, which prevents disclosure of content other than as prescribed.

According to Mr Blunn, there has been no increase in the number of complaints about access to communications since the passage of the stored communications amendment. Prior to the amendment, it would appear that there were many very different views about the application of the interception act to stored communications. The review turned on the interpretation to be given to the words ‘passing over the telecommunications system’ and therefore to the issue of at what point a communication commenced and ceased passing over the system and ceased to be subject to the act.

In relation to when a communication ceases passing over the system, there are at least three competing views: (a) when the message has been received—that is, read by the intended recipient, (b) when the message reaches the recipient’s receiving terminal and (c) when the message is stored, in the sense that it is at rest—that is, it is not being automatically processed by the telecommunications system and has reached the address from which it can be directly accessed by the intended recipient. Also, according to Mr Blunn, prior to the amendment to the interception act a number of agencies were acting on the understanding that, even then, the third view was the position at law and on that basis were accessing stored communications other than by an interception warrant. The amendment had the singular advantage of settling that issue, at least for the time being. If the amendment lapses by the operation of the sunset clause, nothing will have been settled and the previous unsatisfactory and uncertain position will be restored.

This legislation not only extends for six months the provisions allowing access to stored communications without a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act but also makes amendments to the interception act to (a) make the Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption eligible authorities for the purposes of the interception act, thereby allowing them to receive lawfully obtained intercepted material for the purpose of fulfilling their statutory obligation to investigate misconduct, including corruption; (b) enable the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption and the Queensland Corruption and Crime Commission to use lawfully obtained interception material for the purpose of their statutory function of investigating corrupt conduct and to use the material in proceedings under the Independent Commission Against Corruption Act 1988 and the Crime and Misconduct Act 2001 respectively; (c) enable the New South Wales Inspector of the Police Integrity Commission to use intercepted material for the purposes of fulfilling its statutory function in relation to the conduct of the Police Integrity Commission under the Police Integrity Commission Act 1996; (d) clarify that the expression ‘officer of a state’ includes all members of the police service of that state; and (e) make technical amendments arising from the enactment of the Legislative Instrument Act 2003.

It is important that the current provisions be extended, allowing a thorough consideration of how best to regulate access to communications in the ever-changing world of technology advancement, especially in view of the increasingly uncertain world in which we now live. I look forward to the government’s response to the Blunn review and I commend this legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: —Last year I spoke on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Bill 2004. The amendment bill at hand, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005,provides for a six-month extension to provisions in the original bill, allowing law enforcement agencies to access stored communications without telecommunications interception warrants being issued under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The original amendment bill contained a 12-month sunset clause which would have seen the provisions cease operation in mid-December. The sunset clause was put in place to give the government time to consider the recommendations of an independent assessment of these changes. The bill before the House today adds a six-month extension to that sunset clause, giving the government additional time to consider a review of the regulations on access to stored communications. The review compiled by Anthony Blunn was presented at the introduction of the bill. It provides for a wide-ranging examination of where we are coming from, and where we are heading, in terms of regulating access to all forms of communication for investigative and security purposes.

speech.para: The purpose of the original bill was to rebalance our law and order needs with the ever-evolving communications sector. The technology we use to transmit communications is a very important aspect of the work of agencies charged with the security of this country. It will have profound ramifications for the investigative processes of our law enforcement agencies and those who seek to profit from crime. Mr Blunn’s wide-ranging report indicates that the government has, on the whole, struck the right balance between enhancing the powers of our law enforcement agencies and enhancing the privacy rights of citizens. But the government also needs to consider the supplementary issues Mr Blunn raised in his report. Hence the need for a six-month extension to the provisions of the original bill.

By amending the original legislation the government is seeking to give our law enforcement agencies modern-day powers to tackle modern-day criminal activity. The amendments put forward by the government and reviewed by Mr Blunn update the powers of law enforcement agencies, giving them tools in the fight against crime and corruption. Specifically, the changes will benefit a number of anticorruption agencies, as the previous speaker, the member for Hughes, mentioned. These include the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission, the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission and the Victorian Office of Police Integrity, all of which use intercepted material in the investigation of corrupt conduct. For these agencies to do their jobs to the best of their ability, their investigative powers must keep pace with communications technology.

Since the Telecommunications (Interception) Act commenced in 1979, more than 25 years ago, our methods of communicating have changed quite dramatically. When drafted, the act had only to cover live communications such as telephones, telexes and the like—where the content of communications was spoken or transmitted in real time and not able to be retained and stored in any manner, which, of course, is the case today. Accessing a stored electronic format of these communications was not possible in that era because messages could only be transmitted in a transient or temporary fashion. The review author, Tony Blunn, found that the language and detail of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 is becoming increasingly limited in accommodating new and emerging technologies through industry development and responding to the needs of security and law enforcement agencies.

To paraphrase Mr Blunn, we face an entirely different scenario today, as any of us who use mobile telephones, pagers or palm pilots would know. We no longer have to wait for a wired message to come through. Today we have instant communications in the form of email, text messaging, picture messaging and paging. Using these modern-day communications, individuals can draft, edit, write and store messages and information before sending them to the recipient. This new technology has changed the way we work, interact and communicate with our friends, families and contacts, but it has also created an ever-widening implication for intelligence gathering, investigative practices and national security.

Until the introduction of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications) Bill 2004, the interception of communications stored on new technologies such as text messages and emails was prohibited without a telecommunications interception warrant. Under the amended bill’s 12-month sunset clause, law enforcement agencies have been able to access stored communications with a standard search warrant rather than a telecommunications interception warrant, which has closed an ever-widening loophole in the legislation and helped keep pace with our ever-evolving communications technology. This is a crucial tool in fighting crime and terrorism, giving law enforcement agencies the power to access messages and other communications otherwise hidden from scrutiny.

An extract from the Australian Strategic Policy Institute’s recent publication, Local Jihad: radical Islam and terrorism in Indonesia, illustrates the existing conundrum very well. Under the heading of ‘Measuring success against terrorism’, the report says in part:

quote.para: The most obvious standard measure of success—

speech.para: and they are referring there to success against terrorism—

quote.para: is the absence of a terrorist attack. The problem with relying on that measure is it’s based on past acts rather than future possibilities. Just because an attack has not happened yet does not mean that one isn’t currently being planned—9/11 and the London bombings are evidence of that fact.

speech.para: Being able to proactively prevent a terrorist attack or simply compile evidence for investigation or prosecution of a crime by accessing stored messages, such as emails and text messages, is a necessary evolution in our laws.

One issue flagged in the Blunn report, which we as legislators must be mindful of, is the protection of privacy. Normally in these matters I would rather err on the side of privacy, but I recognise that we are in a much different environment today and we have to take on would-be terrorists and the like with the best tools at our disposal. To some extent, privacy has to be compromised—hopefully, not on a long-term basis but certainly until we are through this very difficult time. Mr Blunn underlined the fact that privacy concerns must be a fundamental consideration when drafting legislation for security and law enforcement purposes.

The government acknowledges that our ability to communicate freely and with a measure of privacy is one of the most fundamental tenets of our democracy. I am confident that this matter, along with the other recommendations in Mr Blunn’s review, will be at the forefront of the minister’s mind when considering the contents of the report. I think this extension is warranted, and I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
talker.role: Attorney-General
talker.name: Mr RUDDOCK

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the member for Hinkler for his very thoughtful contribution, and I also thank the members for Hughes, Fisher and Gellibrand. I understand there were some unwarranted comments by the member for Fisher, who tends to want to flatter me, but other than that I am pleased at the general support for this measure. Can I just say that the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment (Stored Communications and Other Measures) Bill 2005 regulates the use of interception and intercepted material by law enforcement, national security and a number of dedicated anticorruption agencies, and the regulatory regime ensures that there is a balance between protecting the privacy of those who use Australia’s telecommunications systems and the legitimate need to fight organised crime, threats to national security and corruption.

speech.para: This bill will of course continue for a further six months the provisions that deal with stored communications, pending our deliberations on the recommendations of the report in the Blunn review, presented to the House earlier in this debate. I thank the member for Gellibrand for her indication of support for this extension and her acknowledgment that these are complex issues and that the time to implement them ought to be available. The bill also includes important amendments to enhance the way in which anticorruption agencies are able to access and use lawfully obtained intercepted material. The bill really does send a very strong message that corrupt conduct by persons holding public positions is simply unacceptable and backs this message up with enhanced investigatory tools for anticorruption agencies.

The anticorruption agencies, of course, that will benefit from the changes include the newly created Victorian Office of Police Integrity and the New South Wales Inspector of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. Other agencies that will benefit are the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, the Queensland Crime and Misconduct Commission and the New South Wales Inspector of Police Integrity Commission. There is one issue in which I think some inappropriate observations were drawn by the member for Gellibrand about the amendments in relation to the Victorian Office of Police Integrity. The amendments here will only commence if the Victorian government legislates to provide satisfactory accountability and oversight arrangements for the office.

It is important to understand the issue that has been a very live issue here where the Victorian government resisted appropriate independent scrutiny of some potential use-for-interception material that was to be given to the Ombudsman with one title but to be supervised by the Ombudsman simply wearing another cap.
