For us that was totally unacceptable. It would be unacceptable to any fair-minded person that Caesar should investigate Caesar, yet that is what Victoria had in mind, and it persisted. Victoria could have had in place effective telecommunications interception for its police anticorruption agency if it had been prepared to put in place effective, independent monitoring of those arrangements. I would not want to say in relation to this measure that Victoria has backed down; I would want to say that Victoria now intends that its measures will be compliant with a regime that I think any fair-minded person in this House and certainly in the Senate would expect.

In fact, I think I would have been seen to be derelict in my duties if I had been prepared to see the interception powers used—powers which are very intrusive—without adequate independent verification and scrutiny. I am surprised that Victoria, which preaches in relation to these matters—and I notice it was a Victorian member, the member for Gellibrand, who seems to be on side with the Victorian Attorney-General, Mr Hulls—would want a situation where there was inadequate scrutiny. So I am disappointed that she suggests that this bill is in some way a backdown; it is not.

These measures will only operate for Victoria when they have put in place the appropriate independent scrutiny. So I make the point: the amendments in relation to the Victorian Office of Police Integrity will only commence if the Victorian government legislates to provide satisfactory accountability and oversight arrangements. That has always been our position. I am glad that Victoria has seen fit to come to the party. The bill will also ensure that intercepted material may be used in the investigation of misconduct by members of state and territory police forces by ensuring that state police fall within the definition of an officer of the state. The anticorruption measures of this bill indicate very clearly our commitment to fight against corruption. I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise not only to speak in support of the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 but also to address issues of a critical nature going to the governance of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the foundation bill governing the critical role of the Australian Customs Service, the Customs Act 1901 as amended. As members of the House are aware, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 by ensuring that customs duty is not payable on goods that are described as of a non-commercial character being brought in by non-Australian citizens who are family members of participants who are attending the Commonwealth Games in Melbourne in 2006.

speech.para: The bill is not contentious, because it exempts the imposition of a customs duty on goods. Any exemption from a customs duty or other impost, whether a tax, levy or other instrument of government revenue, is always welcome. Obviously, the loser, if one can call them that, is the long-suffering Australian taxpayer. Indeed, the Attorney-General and member for Berowra, the Hon. Philip Ruddock, said, in his second reading speech on this bill, on Wednesday, 14 September 2005:

quote.para: It is expected that Commonwealth Games participants and officials will bring with them a variety of goods that are to be used in a non-commercial manner. These will include give-aways, hospitality samples and other consumables that will be used for team promotion and for cultural and hospitality activities.

speech.para: Clearly, the intention of this legislation is to recognise that the financial benefit to Australia of the imposition of a customs duty on such non-commercial goods imported into Australia is outweighed by the national policy impact of the impost during such an auspicious event as the Commonwealth Games. Members of the House see in an instant the wisdom of exempting such goods from customs duty, yet how does this parliament regard the situation of goods upon which a duty is prescribed under the customs import regulations and which are clearly imported for commercial profit but which are systematically hidden from the Australian Customs Service with the sole and substantial intent of defrauding the Commonwealth of its revenue? What do members of the House and the general public say about those cheats who deliberately import, by the container load, shipment after shipment of goods, deliberately failing to declare the quantity or understating their price with the sole and substantial purpose of defrauding the Commonwealth of its revenue by refusing to pay the prescribed amount of duty?

May I speak for all in this parliament and all law-abiding Australian citizens in saying that no-one likes a cheat. No-one likes to see two importers of goods upon which an import duty is payable, one abiding by the law and the other not abiding by the law, and then see the wrongdoer not only profit as to his or her criminal and civil liability conduct but also compete unfairly against the other importer who is paying his or her customs duties and declaring the goods to the Customs Service, Quarantine and other agencies—in short, doing the right thing. With these precursors in mind, I wish to bring to the attention of members a reported judgment in the Supreme Court of New South Wales, Common Law Division, involving the CEO of Customs v Ozzy Tyre and Tube Pty Ltd and Lorene Khamis [2005, NSWC at 948] before Justice Stephen Rothman. This judgment was handed down only three weeks ago, on 25 September 2005.

I bring this case to the parliament’s attention today because of the size of the sums and the audacity of the defendants in attempting to defraud the Commonwealth of its revenue and otherwise evade Commonwealth law. Ms Lorene Khamis is a director of Ozzy Tyre and Tube Pty Ltd. The statistics of this case are quite staggering: (1) eighteen shipments of motor vehicle tyres, wheels and parts from 18 December 1998 to about 24 March 2000, (2) a finding by the Supreme Court on the total of unpaid duties, equalling a reported $255,000 and (3) the total of fines imposed by the Supreme Court being a staggering $3,237,000. However, the case does not end there. What is even more staggering is a fact reported in the Australian on 26 September 2005 in a news article by Vanda Carson entitled ‘Judge slams hot-rod deal’:

quote.para: A director of Australia’s largest hot-rod wheel and tyre supplier has been fined $3.5 million for smuggling car accessories into the country and defrauding Customs.
Justice Stephen Rothman lamented the fact that the plea-bargain-deal allowed her to avoid punishment.
Customs chief executive John Mansfield has agreed not to pursue Ms Khamis or her company for the $3.5 million provided she pays $255,000 in unpaid duties.
The judge said there would be no deterrence from breaking the law if importers caught evading duties were only punished by having to pay the duty they should have paid in the first place.

speech.para: Before getting to the heart of this deplorable situation, I wish to remind the parliament of the threefold primary roles of the Australian Customs Service. I cite page 14 of the Australian Customs Service annual report of 2003-04 under the title ‘Vision and Roles’.

quote.para: Customs has three principal roles:

item.para: to facilitate trade and the movement of people across the Australian border while protecting the community and maintaining compliance with Australian law
to collect customs revenue efficiently; and
to administer specific industry schemes and trade measures.

speech.para: Let us now apply the outcomes of the Ozzy Tyres case to the three primary roles of the ACS. Has the ACS in the Ozzy Tyres case facilitated trade and the movement of people across the Australian border while protecting the community and maintaining compliance with Australian law? I say no. Yes, the Customs chief executive officer did commence civil litigation against those defrauding Customs and the Australian taxpayer of our revenue and, yes, the Customs chief executive officer did obtain a judgment from the Supreme Court of New South Wales. However, what is inexcusable is the fact that, after the judgment three weeks ago, he let these smugglers go. He let these persons convicted of their civil liabilities go, releasing them of a liability to the Australian taxpayer of some $3.5 million.

Let us go to the second prescribed role of Customs—that is, to collect customs revenue efficiently. Again I ask the House whether it believes, in light of this Supreme Court of New South Wales judgment, that the ACS has collected customs revenue efficiently, including those fines and penalties accruing from failure by persons liable to pay that revenue. Again I say no. The ACS, as agent for the Commonwealth, was owed $3.5 million in fines and simply allowed the defrauding smugglers to walk away.

What does that all say about the governance of the ACS? Again, I can only reiterate the words of Justice Rothman, who with total clarity notes the complete collapse of any final fear and deterrence in the hearts of the wrongdoers. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say to the Attorney-General today what this judgment means for community protection and for compliance with Australian law. First, the action of the Customs chief executive officer in reaching this sweetheart deal with the director of Ozzy Tyres and with Ozzy Tyres as a body corporate is one of the most destructive decisions in the history of the Australian Customs Service, in my opinion. Far from protecting the Australian community, including those legitimate participants in the Australian tyre retail and distribution industry, the deal struck between the Customs CEO, Ozzy Tyres and one director of that company has dealt a fatal blow to the confidence of legitimate importers of any kind. In other words, those who do the right thing will be abandoned, while those who smuggle, cheat and defraud will walk away without any final punishment. In short, the message is out: do the wrong thing and you will get away with it; do the right thing and you will be flogged. Put in simple terms, wrong is right; right is wrong.

For several years Ozzy Tyres deliberately imported goods with the sole intention of undermining the customs revenue collection system. When they were eventually caught, they pleaded that they could not pay the penalty and were simply let off. Let me now quote from the tyre industry journal, Australian Tyre Dealer. On page 13 of edition no. 4 of volume 14 of Australian Tyre Dealer—the August-September 2005 issue—is a full one-page glossy advertisement for Ozzy Tyres, titled ‘Ozzy Tyres wants you’. This advertisement describes Ozzy Tyres as ‘one of Australia’s leading tyre and wheel companies’. The advertisement goes on to boast that ‘Ozzy Tyres prides itself on only dealing with trusted and respected wheel manufacturers and has exclusive supply agreements with some of the biggest wheel companies in the world.’

Allow me to bring to the attention of the Attorney-General the impact of Ozzy Tyres on its competitors. As a result of Ozzy Tyres’s conviction for being a smuggler and a defrauder of Commonwealth revenue and its breach of several sections of the Customs Act—too numerous to mention here today—Ozzy Tyres has radically undercut the price of its competitor distributors.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene. I was wondering whether the honourable member opposite would consent under the standing orders to answer a question.
(Mr Lindsay)—Will the member for Lowe concede?
—Yes, I am happy to answer a question.

—Thank you. We are in this debate talking about the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005. While I know that the member opposite feels very passionately about the subject he is currently addressing, I wonder whether he would be able to show us how the matter of Ozzy Tyres in some way comes within the purview of the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005, given the fact that the purpose of this bill is to allow entry of certain goods relating to the Commonwealth Games.

—The bill amends the Customs Tariff Act 1995 by ensuring that customs duty is not payable on goods that are described as being of a non-commercial character. I am talking about a case that was brought to my attention last week by a constituent who is very concerned about the implications for the tyre industry across Australia. It is a very important public interest matter. I appreciate that my colleague and friend the member for Fisher was not here at the start of my contribution, so I will make that concession. But this is a very important matter which I believe is germane to the debate, and I would like the Attorney-General, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to follow up this particular case. I am afraid that Ozzy Tyres effectively got off scot-free in this particular matter. It is to the detriment of other operators in the industry that these people can just continue to operate and not pay the ultimate penalty, which they should. Perhaps if the member listens to what more I have to say, he will appreciate the relevance of it. I would hope that he would advocate on behalf of the concerns of my constituents and all those honest, law-abiding people in the tyre industry across Australia to see that this sort of thing does not happen again. Quite plainly, the principal in this particular matter is continuing to operate, and that is at the expense of all those law-abiding citizens who are operating within the industry.
(Mr Wilkie)—Member for Fisher, are you raising a point of order or do you have a question?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I was wondering whether the member for Lowe would deign to answer a further question.
—Member for Lowe, are you willing?
—I am happy to answer another question.
—I would remind the member for Fisher that the questions need to be kept short.

—Thank you. I am a keen advocate of the intervention procedure in this place and I would like to see it in the other chamber as well. My question to the member for Lowe is that, while I can understand the significance of what he is telling us, how does he justify the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 to be the appropriate forum to draw to the attention of the Attorney-General the serious matters that he is currently addressing in the chamber?

—Before the member for Lowe answers the question, I would remind him that this is not the Customs Tariff Act 1995 that we are debating today. We are debating the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005, which is very narrow in its focus.

—It is relevant to protecting the revenue, Mr Deputy Speaker. With great respect, I take the point you make but I see this as wider than the narrowness of this particular amendment and wish to bring this matter to the attention of the parliament. I see clearly that it is a public interest matter and I would be grateful if you would let me continue. The member for Fisher was not here originally but, as I said earlier when he entered the chamber, he would want to pursue this with the Attorney-General and make sure that this case never recurs.

—I would remind the member for Lowe that, whilst the case may be very important, there might be other forums available for the presentation of the topic being canvassed. If the member for Lowe could in some way tie his remarks to the bill, that would be acceptable.
—As I said, I believe it is relevant to protecting the revenue and I seek leave to continue my remarks.
—You do not need leave, Member for Lowe. Please continue.

—Let me continue. By simply refusing to pay customs duties, Ozzy have unfairly undercut the price of tyres, wheels and other motor vehicle parts at the expense of their competitors. In short, Ozzy have profited by their dishonesty and their breaches of Australian Commonwealth law. The damage to the tyre industry in Australia could not be more catastrophic. Ozzy’s competitors have been wrongly accused of forcing prices up. They have lost market share and ultimately gone into bankruptcy or insolvency. As a direct consequence, the legitimate retailer and distributor channels are being seriously undermined and Australian industry is being destroyed. This type of conduct is part of the grey marketing scourge being visited upon Australia today.

speech.para: Is this what the CEO of the Australian Customs Service calls protecting the Australian community and maintaining compliance with Australian law? The border protection of Australian industry in matters such as the Ozzy Tyre scandal is a matter that cries for justice. In this case there is a desperate need for the ACS to be fully staffed and equipped to monitor and prosecute those smugglers and other wrongdoers. Australian industry deserves lawful protection and I am sure the government wants to do something about it.

Grey marketing is a serious matter. Figures are scant but it is estimated that only three per cent of container terminals are actually inspected by Customs—that is, 97 per cent of all containers are not inspected. What does this say about smuggling and the importation of dangerous goods in the terrorist environment that we are experiencing at the moment? Australia is currently a wide open target for grey marketing. In the Ozzy Tyre case we have the benefit of one finding of 18 smuggled shipments.

It is hard enough for the plaintiff lawyers to gather the evidence, issue the subpoenas, build the case and lead to a successful finding of civil liability; it is lamentable that the CEO of Customs could let the convicted wrongdoers off the hook entirely, calling upon them to pay no more than what they were bound to pay anyway. What the Ozzy Tyre case represents is that the ACS is weak on enforcement. In my view, the government makes Australia a laughing stock for those who would attempt to defraud the Commonwealth of its revenue and make more and more audacious breaches.

‘You must pay your taxes and duties, but only if you want to.’ That is the message. Equally, the message is that if you do not want to pay taxes and duties then it is okay. That is what I am concerned about. I fear that the government’s response to the New South Wales Supreme Court’s judgment will be to refer this matter to some committee seeking amendments to the Customs Act or some other legislation—because this is how it is usually done. Such a problem is usually referred to some committee so the government is seen to be doing something when in fact nothing might change. I want to see something change in this particular case.

The CEO of Customs in this case had obtained a conviction. There was nothing more to do than enforce the court’s judgment. If the defendants could not pay then bankrupt them. That would leave the legitimate businesses, who are doing the right thing, to trade with a measure of relief and in the knowledge that there was some protection of their interests. However, sadly this is not the case.

I urge the Attorney-General to take action to ensure that justice is done in this case. A good start would be to examine why only civil litigation was commenced and whether the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions has been briefed for possible criminal action against the defendants. A second thing the Attorney-General can do is to call in his CEO of Customs and have him show cause for conduct that has the Australian tyre industry tearing its hair out in despair at the moment. I am advised that the arrangement between the CEO of the ACS and Ozzy Tyres is ‘good at law’ and still stands.

This is an appalling precedent and a disgraceful outcome for Australian industry and all those Aussie battling family businesses that this government purportedly represents. The law in this area is inadequate in that it permits only a pecuniary punishment. I recommend that the Attorney-General expand the range of permissible penalties, including incarceration and community service orders. In this case, yet again, we have a situation where a director has placed the assets out of reach of her creditors, arrogantly pleading that she is impecunious—being a family business—meaning that she simply cannot pay the $3.5 million due to the taxpayers.

Let me tell you that by her conduct she has ruined other honest industry operators. That is why I am bringing this to the attention of the parliament. Her conduct is selfish. If she or the company cannot pay it should be placed into administration or made insolvent. Why should Ozzy’s competitors and the Australian taxpayer pay for a convicted criminal and civilly liable conduct? Why should we jointly and severally permit these serious breaches of customs law to be rewarded whilst Ozzy continues trading and expanding its business? How is it that Ozzy is able to place full-page advertisements in major journals, such as the Australian Tyre Dealer, boasting that it is so successful that it is expanding and calling for more franchises, when it is supposed to be impecunious? This is the point I am making: these people are clearly corrupt.

In concluding, I caution on a disturbing point. As I mentioned, grey marketing is rampant in a multitude of import industries, particularly high-volume consumables. Examples also include computer media such as floppy disks, CDs and other computer components. Other industry examples include cosmetics and clothes. The list is almost endless. All these types of goods are imported largely without rigorous regulation. Equally, there is an active industry in the recycling of import companies that are fly-by-night businesses and operators, making it difficult to prosecute any one entity. On behalf of my constituents and people in this industry and similar industries, I am demanding greater regulatory control.

I urge the Attorney-General to demonstrate leadership and to govern by taking the matter of Australian industry protection seriously and beginning to punish those who flagrantly abuse our customs laws while destroying Australian industry. I further urge that there be an increase in Customs forces, with particular reference to container searching and inspection so as to increase the absolute number of containers searched from the current statistics of three per cent. I ask my friend and colleague to take the circumstances of that case back to the Attorney-General, who might not be aware of it, and ask him to follow that up with the CEO of Customs. It has certainly left a very sour taste not only with my constituent in the tyre industry but also with all his colleagues in the association that represents the tyre industry. They would like something to be done about it. I am sure they will appreciate me bringing it to the attention of the parliament, and I hope that something good comes from this, notwithstanding the issue—which I understand—raised by the member for Fisher in relation to its direct relevance to the bill before the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to join the debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005. Referring to the remarks made by the honourable member for Lowe, I think the appropriate minister is probably the Minister for Justice and Customs. He would religiously read the Hansard, but I would like to make the point at the outset that, because I have a high regard for the member for Lowe, I did not take a point of order on relevance on this. I could see that he felt very strongly about the subject and, even though—as you pointed out, Mr Deputy Speaker—there could well be better or more appropriate forums for him to raise those matters, we chose not to take a point of order on this occasion.

speech.para: Next year, starting from 15 March, Australians will once again relish the chance to show the world what we are made of. That of course is the date of the opening ceremony of the 2006 Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Melbourne. Representatives of the 71 Commonwealth nations will converge on the capital of Victoria for 11 days of physical competition in pursuits such as athletics and swimming through to basketball, boxing, cycling, shooting, rugby sevens, weight-lifting and so on. But international sporting events are today much more than just sports events. They are held alongside cultural extravaganzas and festivals that celebrate the diversity of the world. The Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 aims to bring about a very sensible situation which will remove duty and tariff barriers that would potentially detract from the celebratory aspect of the Commonwealth Games.

Honourable members will be interested to know that the bill will provide duty-free entry to Australia of items that are of no real commercial value but that are brought into our country by non-Australian members of the Commonwealth Games family for purposes related to this sporting and cultural celebration. These goods would include those needed for cultural and hospitality functions, samples, promotional items and also giveaways. Goods such as alcohol, tobacco, motor vehicle parts, television cameras and radio broadcasting equipment will not be eligible for the concession.

Honourable members would be aware that Australia is not new to hosting international sporting events. For instance, Melbourne hosted the Olympic Games in 1956, the Commonwealth Games were held in Brisbane in 1982 and the world saw Australia through new eyes when we hosted the Sydney 2000 Olympics—and it is really hard to believe that five years have now elapsed since that wonderful event. Australians showed the world at Sydney, and also at Melbourne and Brisbane, what we can do when we work together, and the world was impressed. The world was impressed not only at the smooth operation of those events, particularly the Olympics, but also by our people—our volunteers, our bus drivers, cabbies and general citizens—who all shared the patriotism and excitement that the games brought. Who will ever forget the words uttered by the then President of the IOC, Juan Samaranch, when he described Sydney in 2000 as ‘the best games ever’? With Australians now counting down the days to the Melbourne Commonwealth Games, the government is determined to reduce the legislative restrictions that may in any way hamper these games from becoming an equal runaway success.

While the desire to be triumphant on the international scene is an overwhelming one, the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 will not—and I stress will not—usher in a free-for-all import environment for anyone to abuse. I cited a moment ago a number of items that will not be eligible for the relaxed provisions. These provisions outlined in the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 are similar to provisions created for the Sydney Olympic Games and also the Paralympics. The Paralympics in 2000 were also an outstanding success. These provisions will remain in force for a period of six months from 1 January, a period that allows plenty of time for our visitors to be able to bring their items into Australia to prepare for the March event. The Australian government are proud of our achievements at Sydney and we are committed to providing a platform for similar success at Melbourne. Melburnians are mad about their sports and that in-built vigour is already generating community-wide aspirations for a successful Commonwealth Games in 2006. The Australian government feel the same energy, and this bill further indicates our strong commitment to the success of the Melbourne event.

Customs laws include a number of pre-existing concessions for personal effects and equipment that are directly required by officials and athletes involved in the games itself, but while in Australia these athletes, coaches and family members from the various Commonwealth countries will also have first-hand experience of our hospitality, our laid-back, comfortable way of life, our tolerance of others and our determination to put on a cracking good show. And I do hope that many of those Commonwealth Games visitors take advantage of the opportunity of travelling to Queensland, to the Sunshine Coast and to other parts of our nation to appreciate that Australia has a lot more to offer than simply being an outstanding games organiser and an outstanding sporting nation.

I see the Attorney-General in the chamber. In an earlier speech I said that, in my view, he is one of the best ministers in the government. He is here, his time is important, so I will not continue to talk at length. I just stress that the provisions of the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 will help achieve the outcome the government seeks and will help ensure that the Melbourne Commonwealth Games are a real success. I am very pleased to be able to commend the Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 to the chamber.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
talker.role: Attorney-General
talker.name: Mr RUDDOCK

talk.start.para: —I did hear earlier the remarks of the member for Fisher. I thank him for his generous remarks. I do not think they are deserved, and I am sure members of the opposition do not think they are deserved, but I value his role as a constructive barracker and appreciate the spirit in which the remarks were offered.

speech.para: The Customs Tariff Amendment (Commonwealth Games) Bill 2005 is an important measure, and I am glad that it is being supported. Obviously, the amendments to the Customs Tariff Act to provide duty-free entry for goods for use in, or for purposes related to, the Melbourne Commonwealth Games will be an important adjunct to the success of the games. The goods will include giveaways and hospitality samples. Concessions will not apply to alcohol and tobacco products or extend to importations of a commercial nature. The existing provisions under the customs legislation relating to personal effects and temporary importations will also be available for the purposes relating to the games.

I would have thought the opportunities to speak on this legislation would have been fairly limited, but I am told that the member for Lowe was able to range quite widely on customs matters generally. I should just take the opportunity to say in relation to his comments about the extent to which containers are examined in Australia that I am surprised, given the spirit in which this bill is being considered and because of the security situation, that he would not have acknowledged that container examination issues are taken very seriously by this government. The inspection of containers in Australia compares very favourably with the quantum and percentages that are effected in the United States and in Canada. Very extensive container examination facilities have been installed in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide and Fremantle. In addition, I am told that the customs container examination process is among the world’s best in volume, speed, cost and system capability and that more than 98 per cent of containers are back at the wharf within the free storage period. So it is a good news story, and that ought to be appreciated.

From time to time issues are raised in relation to customs matters. The member for Lowe wanted to raise a matter which is before the courts. I imagine that, if there were relevant issues that ought to be put, it would be more appropriate to have approached the Comptroller of Customs and his officers to put a view. He could have done that. I am advised that on this issue the Australian Government Solicitor and Customs are aware of the matter. The case does raise quite complex issues. I understand that the presiding judge commented on the lack of alternatives to the outcome in this case, which has arisen only recently. My colleague the Minister for Justice and Customs will be briefed on the issues raised and the government will consider whether changes to the law are required. I do not know that it needed to take up the full amount of time that it did. I would prefer in a matter of this sort that the bill proceeds expeditiously. I am grateful for the support that has been given for the bill’s passage, and I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Barresi:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —Before debate on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation report Making it work was adjourned I mentioned that these concerns are the very concerns that the Transport Workers Union made so clear during its campaign to heighten awareness of the plight of independent contractors that has prompted action on my part. In an effort to put a set of rules in place that will allow independent contractors a fair go at negotiating fair agreement with large organisations, the member for Hunter and I have co-sponsored a private member’s bill that will amend the Trade Practices Act to allow small businesses to access collective bargaining.

speech.para: Just because independent contractors are treated like business operators does not mean they carry with them all the clout that would ordinarily be associated with a business operator. It is important that the Trade Practices Act reflects this. Already this year we have had amendments to the Trade Practices Act that do nothing but exacerbate the problem that people like the transport workers I met in Canberra are currently experiencing. Their right to have a union collectively bargain with large companies on their behalf has been removed under the guise of reform. This government says that these workers—and at the end of the day they are workers, not necessarily just business operators—have the right to negotiate, but bear in mind that many are often forced to negotiate with the large and sometimes internationally based organisations for whom they work. It is like asking a goldfish to negotiate with a shark and expecting that the goldfish will have a fair chance of not being eaten. It is a ridiculous expectation—one that everyone knows is well beyond reality—which contractors such as these transport workers and other independent contractors face on a daily basis.

The private member’s bill that I co-sponsored seeks to rebalance the process by allowing small business operators to collectively bargain. I know that members opposite may claim that the recent decision of the ACCC means that in truth it is still permissible, but these are exceptions rather than any general rule. The private member’s bill seeks to strengthen the bargaining position of small businesses by allowing them to get together to bargain as a collective without the cumbersome, time-consuming and inefficient authorisation processes that currently exist through the ACCC. This is the sort of thing that, quite frankly, small businesses want. This is the sort of thing that would help them out immediately, and it would certainly be a greater weight off their minds than whether or not they can unfairly sack somebody without repercussions.

I congratulate the Labor members of the committee for their dissenting report, but I also congratulate all members of the committee on the amount of common ground that was found. I look forward to the government taking these matters seriously by adopting a number of the recommendations that were agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I indicate my support for the private member’s bill that the members for Hunter and Werriwa are moving. It is soundly based in practical terms and philosophically because it is based on our assertion of the right of all working Australians to be able to bargain collectively. We certainly know that independent contractors in the transport industry are very hardworking Australians. The irony, of course, is that the government is amending the Trade Practices Act to allow small businesses that supply products to large businesses—most particularly small firms supplying, for example, large retail chains—to bargain collectively. It seems to me that, if it is good for the government to do that in relation to suppliers to large retailers, surely it is similarly important and right that workers in the transport industry have the same basic right.

speech.para: It astonishes me that, day after day, week after week and year after year, the government claims that every Australian has the right to bargain collectively. This is just untrue. It has been untrue since 1996. Yet the former industrial relations minister, now the Minister for Health and Ageing, told a Vietnamese worker who was locked out in the Morris McMahon dispute that, if they wanted a collective agreement, they had every right to ask for it. What he did not say is that the employer has every right to refuse it. That is the truth of the matter. Those working Australians who seek to bargain collectively and who seek a collective agreement have nothing more than a right to ask the employer to agree to that. The employer, under that legislation, has a right to say no. I say that a right vetoed is no right at all.

I will not speak for long on this committee report entitled Making it work. I do want to commend the member for Gorton, the Deputy Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation. The main report is of very substantial value, I must say; the dissenting report, even more so. Point 1.3 says:

quote.para: It was accepted by all Committee members that there were genuine independent contractors—

speech.para: and we all accept that—

quote.para: but an inordinate amount of evidence suggested that many workers were being forced to work as so-called independent contractors in order to avoid taxation or traditional employer responsibilities, such as superannuation contributions or workers’ compensation insurance.

speech.para: This is just another case in this industry of the government using the tax system—using whatever it possibly can—to encourage people to set themselves up as independent contractors where, in many cases, they are not. A lot of revenue is being forgone as a result of that, but so obsessed is this government with busting unions and busting collective arrangements that it is prepared to allow the taxpayer to bear the burden of that. I commend the member for Gorton, and I commend this report.

talk.start.para: —Making it work is an important report which deals with some very important matters. I would like to add some brief remarks to those that have been made by the member for Rankin and the member for Werriwa. This is a matter of growing importance in our economy, with a growing incidence of independent contractors and labour hire employees. One of the great questions is how this phenomenon is being driven. Is it being driven by individual contractors seeking increased flexibility in their working lives and in their business arrangements and therefore incorporating themselves and seeking to work as contractors? Alternatively, is it being driven by companies seeking increased flexibility from their employees, asking that they incorporate themselves and therefore changing the employment relationship so that these people are no longer technically employees although they are, of course, employees in the real world? Both elements are at play here. This happens both ways. One of the big questions is: what is the overriding factor?

speech.para: I have to say that the majority report is disappointing in that it does not make a more satisfactory distinction between genuine independent contractors who deserve support in their arrangements and what are in effect labour hire or contracting arrangements which are driven by the employer to gain more flexibility from the employee in a way which is not necessarily to the employee’s benefit. This report does make some useful recommendations in relation to people who are genuine independent contractors. This is a growing sector of the economy, and we need to do everything we can to support these people. In particular, I refer to recommendation 13, which calls on the Office of Small Business to develop more resources to support independent contractors in ‘setting up a small business, financial and reporting requirements, dispute resolution options and business management practices’.

As I say, I think the biggest inadequacy in the majority report is its failure to deal in any meaningful way with problems facing labour hire employees, many of whom only work in such circumstances because it is the only form of employment available to them. Working for a labour hire company can be a very precarious existence. Between 75 and 95 per cent of labour hire workers are casually employed. Of course, this means that they can have very irregular hours of work, no sick leave and no annual leave. Some would say they get a higher hourly rate. Sometimes that is true and sometimes it is not.
The minority report makes a very interesting recommendation in relation to the registration of labour hire companies. The report notes:

quote.para: The Committee received evidence from labour hire companies and unions suggesting the need to register labour hire companies. It was contended that many labour hire companies were not competent to be legally recognised as labour hire companies and therefore it was considered that a register be established to ensure that business conducted by labour hire companies meet an appropriate industry standard.

speech.para: The most interesting thing out of that is that some of those submissions were made by labour hire companies themselves. I dare suggest that the labour hire companies that made those recommendations to the committee are the genuine ones that are sick of their good name being sullied by the operators out there who exploit their workers and give the other labour companies a bad name. I am not saying that all labour hire companies are a bad thing. Employment by a labour hire company suits some people. There is no doubt about that. But some labour hire companies are exploiting their employees, and the more reputable labour hire companies are sick and tired of their good name being sullied. So they, together with trade unions, have suggested that a register of labour hire companies be established. That is a recommendation taken up by the minority on this committee but not, alas, by the majority. I do not think that the majority report deals anywhere near adequately with that issue.

The Victorian parliament’s Economic Development Committee found that one quarter of Victorian businesses use labour hire companies and three per cent of Australian employees are employed by labour hire companies. So this is an important matter. Of course, we have seen growing flexibility in the Australian labour market over the last few years, and that is not a bad thing; it is a very good thing. But we need to ensure that labour hire companies operate in such a manner that the rights and conditions of their employees are protected.

In relation to independent contractors, I referred earlier to the matter of whether an independent contractor makes the move to that form of employment for reasons to do with the flexibility of the employer or of the employee. I was drawn to the submission to the inquiry from the Transport Workers Union which talked about the degree of practical independence of most independent contractors in the transport industry. Of course the transport industry is dominated by owner-drivers or, to use another form of words, independent contractors.

The Transport Workers Union pointed out that the degree of independence enjoyed by most owner-operators in the day-to-day exercise of their business is minimal, to say the least. They said, for example, that most owner-drivers—in fact, they say almost all, without exception—perform work for a single transport operator. They perform work at the behest of that operator, in accordance with very specific priorities including specific delivery pick-up priorities set by the directors and management of that operator. They are usually required to hold themselves available to perform work for a single contractor, thus rendering them unavailable for anyone else. They take direction from that operator on a day-to-day basis, as if they were employees of the operator. They are required to paint or otherwise mark their vehicles in their operator’s colours and/or insignia and they have little or no power to set the price—rather, they take the price they are given. In other words, anybody seeing a truck or a van drive past with the colours or logo of a courier company—or some other sort of transport operator delivering goods on behalf of that operator—would, if they thought about it, quite fairly assume that the individual driving that truck or courier van was an employee of the company.

In the vast majority of cases they are not an employee; they are independent contractors who happen to work for only that company and are required by that company to work for only that company. They work a roster set by that company, their days and hours of work are determined solely by that company and they have a payment rate set by that company. They do not negotiate with the employer, the parent company, and say, ‘Here’s how much we’ll deliver your parcels for.’ The rate is set by the company and all the contractors get paid exactly the same rate. There are no independent negotiations. There is no force of supply and demand to say, ‘Here I am, an extra-flexible individual who is able to work for a transport company and I will do it as an independent contractor.’ They are in effect, if not in law, employees of that company, of course.

This brings me to representation. There are 12,000 Transport Workers Union members in New South Wales who are independent contractors. They, like many people in many other industries, like to be represented in negotiations. If they were employees, despite the government’s proposed workplace relations changes, they could of course be represented by their trade union. Until recently as independent contractors they could be represented by their trade union, but this government is taking that right away. The only possible explanation for that is ideology. There is no explanation in terms of rational policy, there is no explanation in terms of rational economic thought; there is an explanation in terms of ideology. This committee received evidence regarding the actions of the government in limiting the right of independent contractors to engage a trade union to bargain on their behalf.

The government is fine with independent contractors being represented by bodies such as the Pharmacy Guild or the various players associations across the country—the cricket players’ association, the football players’ association. That is not prohibited by law, but this government is opposing the right of these people to be represented by a group which happens to be a trade union. We hear often that this government is in favour of choice, unless you are an independent contractor who wishes to be represented by a trade union. In that case you have no choice.

Recently, together with other honourable members—the honourable member for Werriwa might have been there—I attended a seminar in Parliament House put on by the Transport Workers Union where independent contractors talked about how they would like their trade union to represent them. To their credit, some government members came and listened. I know the members for O’Connor and Gilmore were there. They heard the cases put by the independent contractors who said, ‘We work very hard, we need somebody to stand up for us and we choose the Transport Workers Union.’

Nobody could fail to be moved by some of those cases. These people work very long hours for rates of pay which are not high by any standard. They are simply seeking to have somebody represent them in their negotiations. What is wrong with an independent contractor choosing a body which also represents employees to represent them in negotiations over contracts? This government has refused that to happen. One of the most moving speeches at that seminar was, I thought, from the wife of an independent contractor who told the audience that she already rarely sees her husband. She does the bookwork for the operation and on a day-to-day basis they are trying to make their small business work. They wanted to get into small business and they are happy to do that; all they want is a bit of help in negotiations, some support from their union. I do not think that is an unreasonable request but apparently the government thinks it is an unreasonable request and that is a sad thing.

Moving on, the committee makes some useful recommendations in the field of occupational health and safety, such as recommendation 7, which suggests that the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations and the Workplace Relations Ministers Council develop initiatives to achieve greater understanding and that they more clearly delineate responsibilities among various governments for occupational health and safety for independent contractors—and, of course, amongst various agencies within the government. I support that recommendation. Occupational health and safety is a very important factor for everybody, including independent contractors.

In conclusion, this is an important report but it is a disappointing report in many respects. The majority report does not make an adequate distinction between genuine independent contractors, small business people who want to make a contribution to the economy and people who feel that, simply to make a living, they are being forced into incorporating small business and into becoming independent contractors. I would regard labour hire employees as a completely separate category. These employees might pack shelves, work on the wharves or carry out a whole range of manual work. They are not independent contractors in any meaningful sense of the word. They are casual employees who can only get jobs at labour hire firms. They work long hours and do not get great rates of pay to compensate them for the loss of sick pay, holiday pay et cetera. They are not independent contractors in any meaningful sense of the words. I think the majority report could have dealt with the issue of labour hire employees much better and made much better recommendations on support and protection for genuine labour hire workers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Howard:

item.para: notes that 15 August 2005 (VP Day) marks 60 years since the Japanese surrender which ended World War II;
recalls with profound gratitude the heroic achievements and sacrifices of those Australians who served in the defence forces during the war, as well as those who contributed on the civilian front;
particularly remembers the thousands of Australians who lost their lives or were wounded in the conflict, and especially recalls the suffering of so many Australians taken as prisoners of war;
whilst never forgetting those who suffered during World War II, acknowledges the strength and importance of the post World War II relationship between Australia and Japan; and
resolves that Australia’s efforts should always be directed to ensuring that a conflict of that magnitude never occurs again.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, 15 August 1945 was a seminal moment for Australia as a nation and also for Australians as a people. Japan’s surrender to the allied forces did not only mark the end of World War II; it also heralded a new era for Australia. It saw an era too where we were reconciled with the Japanese nation, which has gone on to be our greatest trading partner since. That having been said, it was a very testing time for this country. We were a young, vibrant nation. We had faced and overcome enemy attacks on our own soil. For the first time in our history mainland Australia was bombed by enemy forces. Shipping was attacked by midget submarines in Sydney Harbour, Townsville was bombed and, of course, there were the infamous raids on Darwin, and there were raids right across Northern Australia—80 of them in all. Our people faced the prospect, though we did not know it at the time, of a possible invasion through Papua New Guinea. It was a time of great uncertainty and fear. We are geographically isolated, with a huge border to secure and a very small population.

speech.para: As I said, Australia was a young nation, and it certainly faced its biggest threat. At the start of the Pacific war we were barely 40 years old as a nation, and we were about to be bloodied for the second time in 27 years—or, if you want to go back to 1939, when World War II started, we were going to be bloodied for the second time in 25 years. If it had not been for the heroic and sustained fighting that took place throughout the Pacific—including on the Malay Peninsula; in Singapore; in Timor; on the Kokoda Track; at the Battle of the Coral Sea; later, with our American colleagues, at the Battle of Midway; in the Solomons; on Savo Island; at Milne Bay; and, later in the war, during the trek back towards Borneo—it is probably fair to say that we would have faced a very uncertain future.

At Milne Bay, the Japanese were defeated on land for the first time in generations. That was an important moment not just for Australia but also for America and for all the allied forces, both those in the Pacific and those in Europe. Australian troops had already earned respect throughout the world in various theatres of war. We do not have to dwell on them, but we remember such things as the Battle of Britain and the North African war, in which Australians distinguished themselves at places such as Tobruk. Of course those who supported the war effort were not just those who served in uniform; many served at home in semimilitary capacities, in, for instance, the Women’s Land Army and the Civil Construction Corps. Others volunteered to serve in the Red Cross, CUSA and several other organisations. They played their part in making the war effort a significant one.

At the end of World War II, Australia’s population stood at only seven million. Throughout the course of the war one million Australians saw some sort of war service. When you think about it, one in every seven Australians seeing some form of service is quite a remarkable effort. Thirty thousand of the brave Australian soldiers who served in World War II ended up as prisoners and some suffered unimaginable hardship in places like Changi and on the Burma railway and the Sandakan death march. Another 40,000 troops were killed in fighting. In the Pacific alone—and that is what really resonates with us as Australians—more than 9,000 Australians were killed, 8,000 were taken prisoner and 14,000 were wounded or injured. That was quite remarkable for a young nation.

Believe it or not, I still have recollections of World War II. I was a very small child, but I can remember my father picking up troops hitchhiking along the road. I can remember the shopkeepers snipping the little tickets from the ration cards. I can remember the black cardboard that we used to have to put on our windows. I can remember some cars with various forms of carbon burners on the back to extend the life of petrol. I can remember the day the war ended. My parents and next-door neighbours partied right through the night and we walked home across the paddock between the two properties as the sun was coming up. During that party we went down to pick up someone from the movies—or ‘the pictures’ as they were called then—and people were walking around the streets painting ‘VP’ in whitewash on the windows. Those images come flooding back.

It must have been a very trying time, especially in the period from late 1941—around the time of Pearl Harbour and what happened immediately afterwards down the Malay Peninsula—through to September 1942. That was the period of greatest peril. When you think about what happened in that period, Australia really was in danger. We thought the Battle of the Coral Sea was the invasion fleet coming for Australia—in fact, it was aimed at taking Port Moresby. Nevertheless, that was a great turning point, as was the Battle of Milne Bay, which I referred to earlier, and subsequently the Americans engaging the Japanese at Midway.

Of course the war did not finish in September 1942. It was a long, relentless grind for the next three years. We saw some dreadful things happen: the sinking of the Centaur, the machine gunning of Australian nurses and, as I referred to before, things like the Sandakan death march. The first Australians who went into battle in the Pacific theatre, believe it or not, were the RAAF. They undertook bombing along the coast of Malaysia, particularly aimed at Japanese shipping. Their first contact was at a place called Kota Baru, along the Malay Peninsula. From then, right through until the campaigns in Borneo at the end of the war, Australians were continuously serving somewhere in the Pacific.

It brings a whole flood of memories back to many people and it causes us to reflect on some of the values—the fortitude, the strength, the sacrifice and the bravery—of the troops and of citizens who contributed to the victory. Those emotions shine through when you have these presentations of medals. I was quite surprised at the depth of emotion that was still evident in the people who received those medals. A lot of them had many service medals and I thought that for many of them this would be just another medal but, no, it was a very moving return for many of them to 60 years ago. Those same people lived through the horror of losing family members and friends, particularly the war widows, and that was also a very moving experience. Some people never quite got over that—as, I suspect, some people will never quite get over the horrors of the two Bali bombings we are commemorating today, because that is not someone dying of sickness or slowly fading away; that is sharp, brutal and indiscriminate.

When the war did end, as I said, people were going around the streets putting ‘VP’ on the windows and waving flags. Then there were the tickertape parades, and I suppose the most iconic symbol of that time was the dancing man with the hat in the air in front of the tram in Sydney, which has now been captured, I noticed the other day, on the dollar coin. So, 60 years on, those sorts of images still resonate with us. As the euphoria faded away, Australians marked the end of the war with services and family gatherings celebrating peace and remembering the dead.

There were some for whom the war did not end quite then. There was one group I will always admire. They were the guys who were brought in to disarm ordnance in about 1944, and they continued to do that right through until 1947. I used to get very angry that some of them did not get active service recognition. People told them: ‘You never faced the enemy. You were never in mortal danger.’ Good God! They had to take the plates off encrusted sea mines and dig out unstable landmines and the like, and with any trip, any slip of the spanner or the screwdriver, they could have been blown to kingdom come. So the war did not end for them or for many who went to Japan with the occupation forces. They fulfilled a role of what I suppose we could say was the start of the rebuilding of Japan and reconciliation with that country.

I think the best way we can honour Australians who served in the Second World War is to remember why they had to fight for their country and to learn the harsh lessons of history. We must also remember that freedom carries a high price. It is not guaranteed and it must be vigilantly defended by each generation, sometimes in different ways. As we have celebrated this morning, and even in a bill that we discussed just a few minutes earlier, we have to be prepared to face new dangers in different modes. Had World War II ended differently we would not have the privileges we enjoy today. Now more than ever Australians must remember the service and sacrifice of previous generations and honour the contribution that many brave people made to this nation.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The commemorations of VP Day in my electorate did not cease with the conclusion of services on Sunday, 14 August. The following Monday, in fact, I had the opportunity to present commemorative medals to a number of veterans. In a special ceremony attended by members of veterans’ families, and representatives indeed of the Ingleburn RSL, I had the opportunity to present medals to, spend time with and listen to the recollections of a number of World War II veterans—and listening to them from very much a different perspective. I was struck by the sheer determination that those who lived through the war expressed when they spoke about it. Deep within each of them I could sense the fierce determination that was clearly so central to each of them making it through those hard times. Each of them had a story to tell—an act of bravery or of sacrifice—but they felt it was nothing more than anyone else was doing under those same situations.

speech.para: These are brave people who faced war up close and personal. The experience was nothing like the view through the remote camera lens that we tend to view conflict through today. Those who survived the war, and, tragically, those who did not, saw the war directly, sometimes with the enemy not more than a few metres in front of them. But each of them, in their own way, is quite humble about their contribution. While they might not think that their individual contributions were significant or anything particularly special, that is certainly not the case. While they might play down their contribution, I was more than pleased on that day to be in a position to make sure that it received fitting tribute. I was pleased to be able to share the day with them, to learn more of their experiences, to share in their stories and, quite frankly, to pay tribute to them.

Much is made of the celebrations surrounding Anzac Day each year, and rightly so, but it is also very important that all Australians had the opportunity to reflect on what is probably an equally significant day in Australia’s war history. It is worth recalling the words of the then Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, some 60 years ago, when he said:

quote.para: Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may we look forward to a perch which they have won for us ... Let us remember those whose thoughts, with proud sorrow, turn towards gallant loved ones who will not come back.
Nothing can fully repay the debt we owe them, nor can history record in adequate terms their deeds ...

speech.para: The ceremonies that took place over that weekend in August, not just in my electorate at Ingleburn but throughout the country, were a fitting time to reflect on the achievements and sacrifices of Australians who served in the defence of our nation. The ceremonies not only were a means to mark an important anniversary of a country coming to age but were reflective of the ongoing debt of gratitude that today’s Australians have to Australians of that generation. The number of veterans may be dwindling, but I am sure that the memory of their contribution to our country will always be remembered—and I put that very clearly. Lest we forget.

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 12.45 pm to 4.01 pm

talk.start.para: —Today in the Main Committee I would like to join with other members of the House in speaking on the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II. This is particularly an opportunity to commemorate Victory in the Pacific, which marked such an important point in Australia’s history, and one to which many brave and patriotic people from my electorate contributed. I wish particularly to refer to the battle honours of the second 42nd infantry battalion and, of course, to the men from all over Central Queensland who came together and formed this famous battalion. I could not speak about the 42nd without acknowledging the original 42nd Battalion, which was formed in 1915 and saw action during the First World War in France. During these actions the men of the first 42nd won 152 decorations for valour.

speech.para: It was on 23 September 1939 that Lieutenant Colonel JEG Martin received authority for the enlistment of recruits for a special expeditionary force. The area from which the troops were to be drawn was from Gladstone to Mackay in Central Queensland. Once formed, the 42nd Battalion was ordered into camp at Yeppoon on 4 October 1939. In September 1940 men aged 20, 22, 23 and 24 years went into camp, and the local newspapers announced that the Pacific was teetering on the brink of war.

It was a Saturday afternoon when news of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor came through to the 42nd Battalion camp at Yeppoon, and most of the troops were on leave. To those who remained in camp over the weekend fell the huge job of transforming the camp to a war footing. For example, the rows of orderly tents had to be struck and moved into a dispersed pattern some distance apart and, where possible, under trees. Antiaircraft pits were manned on picturesque Wreck Point and an observation group was stationed on North Keppel Island, just off the Central Queensland coast.

That Christmas, one day’s leave was granted, and it was the last Christmas dinner most of the troops were to eat at home for many years. In March 1942 the battalion struck camp at Yeppoon and moved to join other battalions at Tiaro near Maryborough to form the 29th Brigade. Parents, wives, families and sweethearts were left behind and there was no way of knowing when or if they would be reunited.

From all reports, though, spirits were still high amongst the men while they were stationed at Tiaro. As is the way of young men from Central Queensland, the 20 miles to Maryborough was not far enough to keep them away, even though there was no transport because leave to Maryborough was not permitted. Nonetheless, many a young lad was seen hitchhiking, and on one occasion 60 men sat astride one log on the back of a truck into town. It was on one of these visits that the so-called battle of Maryborough took place. Some well-known Central Queensland footballers were said to have featured in this incident and the story of the altercation between them and the locals at a downtown cafe was the main topic of conversation amongst the troops for some time. Later that year, however, the battalion moved to Townsville before they finally embarked on the Duntroon and Taroona in January 1943 and sailed to New Guinea. The men of Central Queensland were off to war.

War is rightly denounced as a savage and loathsome exercise. Under its inescapable demands, men are plucked rudely from an ordered, sheltered life and thrust into unfamiliar and often horrific surroundings. However, this war did present some compensating features, for its harshness and crudity brought out those qualities of grit, comradeship and quiet heroism for which this World War II generation of Australians is so renowned. It is quite remarkable how few of these men resented the demands made of them when they finally returned to our country. Rather, there was a desire to perpetuate the comradeship and to honour the memories of fallen mates by returning to Australia and working to make it a strong and prosperous country—and one that we are lucky to live in today.

I am very proud to continue today to give voice to those desires of the men from Central Queensland who gave so much. I wish here today to perpetuate their memories and the esprit de corps of the 42nd, which was to stand them in such good stead throughout their long and bloody New Guinea campaigns. The first battalion of the 29th Infantry Brigade to make contact with the enemy was the 42nd Battalion. This was on 13 August 1943, when patrols from B Company ventured into enemy territory on the slopes of Mount Tambu and were fired upon. They returned the fire and were very satisfied with being acknowledged as the first of the battalion to see action. But the battalion’s baptism of fire occurred a few days later, on 16 August. The fight started at 9.30 in the morning and lasted for an hour and a half.

I want to recount that action to the House as it is recorded in the history of the 42nd Battalion. A patrol from B Company came under enemy fire. Hanging onto his stuttering Bren gun, George Eddlestone caused screams and wails of the most hideous kind to emerge from the enemy pits as he spluttered them with .303 bullets. Regardless of the risk he was running, Eddlestone kept his gun blazing. Bullets whined over his head and chewed up the ground on each side of him and behind, but still the Bren gun kept firing. Then the Bren fell silent. Eddlestone rolled over, shot through the heart. Enraged by the killing, huge Bill Green stood his whole six foot three inches and yelled at the top of his voice: ‘Come out and fight! Come out or I’m coming in to get you.’ No-one expected Green to carry out his threat; not until they saw him streak up the ridge towards the perimeter. The enemy was all around him, but he did not care. He swore and yelled at them at the top of his voice and all the time his Owen gun was pouring out a stream of bullets. Eventually he fell to a burst of light machine-gun fire. No man died more bravely than Bill Green. His action was an inspiration to the whole battalion and he is rightly remembered as one man who knew no fear. The men from Central Queensland were now out there fighting and dying together.

The men of the 42nd Battalion went on to serve their country and their battle honours include New Guinea, Milne Bay, Buna, Salamaua, Lea and Bougainville. It is not possible to list here the names of every individual from Central Queensland who served but I must place on record that they were everywhere—in the Air Force and the Navy and other Army units—and of course there were women serving as well. And let us not forget those who stayed at home and worked, waited and worried. But it was the 42nd Battalion that was Central Queensland’s own and its story is so much a part of the story of Central Queensland. To continue the story, as the war drew to its bloody conclusion the men of the 42nd were still there. On 25 July 1945 an A Company security patrol ran into a booby trap and Privates MH Davids, MJ Timbs and EJ Smith were killed. Then, sadly, on 28 July Private SW Craker of B Company was killed just days before the Americans dropped the first atomic bomb on Hiroshima, thereby ending the Second World War.

The battle record of the 42nd Battalion deserves to be acknowledged. No prisoners from the battalion were taken by the Japanese. The bodies of all the battalion’s dead were recovered. Every wounded man was picked up by his comrades and taken back to safety. The 42nd Battalion never lost a battle and never failed to carry out its task. Its battle casualties were severe and exceeded casualties from illness. Individual decorations were numerous—in fact too numerous to mention here. The last entry in the battalion diary was made by Private J Rickarts on 29 October 1945, when he recorded ‘C in C’s parade held’. For the men of Central Queensland the war was over. Everyone looked forward to the postwar world: to home, old friends and old surroundings. Some were home quickly while others were further delayed.

Most soldiers were unprepared for civilian life and therefore it often did not supply all the contentment that had been expected. Many found it was not so easy to settle back into the old routine—or rather what was now the new routine. For some it was the noise of a plane that would bring back visions of a crowded troop train. They again felt the weight of a rifle, experienced the smell of a jungle track or felt the sting of a mosquito bite. For each one the return was different, but gradually the men of the 42nd Battalion settled down to make Central Queensland what it is today.

A meeting was held on 14 March 1946 and the second 42nd Battalion Association was formed. Elected to that committee some 60 years ago was the association’s current secretary, Malcolm Barker. On 25 April, Anzac Day, every year for the past 60 years, the people of Central Queensland have gathered to stand and say thank you to the men of their own 42nd Battalion as they march together again, each man wearing with great pride his own 1939 to 1945 star, Pacific Star, 1939 to 1945 war medal and 1939 to 1945 Australian Service Medal. The men of the 42nd are indeed welcome home.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the member for Capricornia on an outstandingly good speech. It was a great contribution to this parliament and a moving memorial to the members of the 42nd from Central Queensland. We should do this more often. The 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific has allowed us two things that we have not had in the time that I have been in the parliament. Firstly, it has allowed a memorial exercise on the actual day, or days surrounding that, to be held in our electorates, with the government funding that to the tune of $10,000. Secondly, government funding for each electorate is expanded by the resources of the local community.

speech.para: I want to thank the members of my community who took part in that and so well supported it. We had our memorial on 21 August, a week after most of the other celebrations, so as not to get in the way of the official ceremonies for our RSL people who were involved and also because ours was centred on Bankstown Airport. It was organised by the Australian Aviation Museum at Bankstown in conjunction with the local RSLs. What they were able to do was bring together World War II aircraft, buses, trucks and Army vehicles. Indeed the aircraft were not only Australian; there was also a Japanese Zero and an American Mustang there. It was a very special thing and that is why we had it a week later.

Barry Thompson and the incredible volunteers at the Aviation Museum at Bankstown did an extraordinary job in bringing together people from all over the city of Bankstown and possibly even further. More than 1,500 people went through the Aviation Museum at Bankstown on the day. I was there throughout the day and I made the centrepiece of the day the presentation of medallions to some of those people in the electorate who were eligible to receive them. Some I still have to present to people because they came in a number of different batches. In fact, I have started to initiate today the presentation of the remainder of the medallions. I think the most appropriate thing is to present them on 11 November in conjunction with the Bankstown RSL at their memorial for those who fell at Gallipoli and to do it in such a way, if they are agreeable, as to have a twinning of World War I and World War II—a remembrance of those who fought and died in Europe and, in particular, in this case, in the Pacific to save Australia.

There are those who argue now that there was never any intention whatsoever by the Japanese to invade Australia—that they had no plans, that they made no effort, that the Brisbane Line was unnecessary and that we just got a bit upset and shaken about because a few Japanese submarines came into Sydney Harbour and there was a bit of an attack on Darwin. They argue that those troops who were in Papua New Guinea, on both sides of the current border, and those troops who came down through the Kokoda Trail had no intention of ever moving into Australia—they were just going to park themselves in Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya and not do anything in relation to Australia at all. There are some significant historians who argue that—that there was no further intent.

I think the only thing that would have stopped the Japanese during World War II from going any further was the fact that this is such a massive continent and they would have had the question of supply lines and also of what their major strategic objectives were. I have very little doubt, based on the historical evidence I have seen and based on what I have heard from my family and from the people who fought in that war, what they thought the intent of the Japanese was, because we took them on in the Pacific.

The Prime Minister at the time, Mr Curtin, who was entirely against conscription during the First World War, not only saw the necessity, given Australia’s danger, to embrace the conscription of Australians during the Second World War—because the very survival of the nation depended on it—but also had to break the fundamental military ties with the United Kingdom because Mr Churchill, as Prime Minister, demanded that Australian troops go to the Middle East and fight, as we had fought in the Middle East, in France and in the Low Countries during the First World War, acting under imperial government orders. We went to war in World War II under imperial government orders. Australia did not take advantage of the fact that, as a result of the Balfour Declaration, Australia could have signed up to the Statute of Westminster in 1932 and would not have been at war automatically. What did the conservative governments at the time do? Absolutely nothing, and we were automatically at war in World War II as part of the British Empire, as we were automatically at war in World War I.

Curtin made a fundamental decision. Faced with the extremity that Australia found itself in—faced with the collapse of Singapore, the British bastion in the Asia-Pacific area, and faced with what he found in the Battle of the Coral Sea where the Americans were brutally brought into the war by the attack on Pearl Harbor on 7 December 1941, after confronting the Japanese and their heavy march not only through the islands of Asia, the Pacific islands and the archipelagos of Asia but also through Burma and on the march through into India—Curtin made a fundamental decision that he would ensure that Australian troops were here to guard and protect Australia and to fight in the Pacific to ensure our national safety.

This is the fundamental linchpin of all future Australian policy. It broke our link with the past, with Britain, and it fundamentally reordered Australian foreign policy on a completely new basis. It is the foundation of our relationship with the United States, forged in the Battle of the Coral Sea, and it is the foundation of modern Australian policy and of an independent Australian foreign policy directed by Australians to the protection of Australians. That was necessary if you look at the conjunction between World War I and World War II. World War I, which is commemorated in Australia every year and is commemorated through Anzac Day and also through November 11, is one part of the picture, but a far bigger picture for Australia is what happened during the Second World War and the impact that total war had on every Australian citizen at home and abroad.

But that war was made during the First World War. The First World War saw the total destructions of the great empires of the past.
