It saw the breaking up of the Austro-Hungarian Empire; it saw the effective destruction of the British Empire, but people just did not realise it until World War II happened; and it saw a Japan become one of three countries on the rise politically, economically and militarily from 1870 on. Modern Germany was forged under Bismarck’s ‘blood and iron’ policy and its ability to train its people scientifically and to build its chemical, rubber and steel industries. Similarly, the United States, from 1870 on after the American Civil War, constructed an entirely new, modernised economy.

Modern Japan was the third part of that. From 1870 to 1900, Emperor Meiji forged a new Japan by copying Western models, copying the United States and Germany. During the First World War, that new Japan was an ally of the United States, Great Britain and Australia. What went wrong? Why did we end up fighting a militaristic, fascist Japan during the Second World War? Essentially, not only did you have the complete destruction of those old empires but in their place in 1919 the Treaty of Versailles. Woodrow Wilson, an isolationist American President, joined with Clemenceau, Churchill and others to construct the world on the basis of small beginnings, of small, so-called democratic states—in some cases, real democratic states; in others, an attempt to be democratic states. One of the countries created in 1924 was Iraq—and we know what problems we are in now when we get to the dissolution of one of the countries that was created after the fashion of the times. The creation of Czechoslovakia, the Sudetenland and myriad other small countries was an attempt to break up all of those empires and parcel them into small, democratic states but with a League of Nations that had no power to actually enforce peace within the world.

What was seen in 1921 at the Washington Naval Conference was a determination that the United States and Britain, as the leading maritime powers in the world, should have a particular ratio that advantaged them vis-a-vis Japan. Japan got the message. They were told that, as an Asian power, they could not hope to come to pre-eminence in the Asia-Pacific region. They turned from allies of ours into a country that became dominated by militarists, who saw the future as a grab for power against the domination of the Pacific by the United States. They constructed their whole policy on speed of attack, which they demonstrated against the US in the attack on Pearl Harbor. Their approach in the Pacific was similar to the Blitzkrieg approach the Germans had developed—surprise, speed and devastating power. The Japanese moved very quickly through what they saw as the corrupted British, Dutch and French empires of the Asia-Pacific region and supplanted them extremely quickly. They then moved towards Australia with great haste and established themselves in Papua New Guinea and what is now Irian Jaya, then part of the Dutch empire. They were on a launching platform to either isolate Australia or, given what they did in Darwin—though they did not tell us during the war—make the first inroads to literally invading Australia.

The men and women of Australia found themselves embroiled in a war that they did not ask for and found themselves automatically part of the British Empire effort again. Out of a population of four million in the First World War, 800,000 Australian soldiers signed up and 60,000 lost their lives. The population had increased to only about seven million, I think, by the time of the Second World War. We had more than a million men at arms during the war, pledged to Australia’s defence. It became a literal defence of Australia. Apart from the brilliant work done by the 8th Battalion in the siege of Tobruk and the important work done in Operation Torch later, Australia’s fundamental area of operation was the Asia-Pacific as part of a combined force under the leadership of General MacArthur which attempted to take back the islands and the countries of the previous Western European imperial powers in the Asia-Pacific region.

They did that, firstly, by holding the line and winning the Battle of the Coral Sea and the Battle of Midway and, secondly, through might and main and sheer hard, brutal work in New Guinea and Irian Jaya, confronting the Japanese soldiers and beating them back. They did it through the work of people such as Brett Collins in my electorate, who was stationed in Irian Jaya in a malaria infested, dengue fever infested area, where the 6,000 Australian soldiers who were sent there were told afterwards, when they had survived, that the expectation was that they would last a very short period of time because there were more than 100,000 Japanese soldiers bearing down on them. They did that through people like Doug McNally, who was in a position where he had to go from island to island intercepting Japanese code material, getting it down, breaking it, translating it and feeding the information back to Australian forces, including those forces at Bankstown airport who plotted our defence in the Pacific. Not one single Australian individual either at home or overseas could escape the effects of this total war. It was the conditioning of the Depression generation in Australia. It is right, fitting and just that we salute all of them for what they went through to defend us in extremity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to use this time to make some comments on the motion moved in the House by the Prime Minister, marking the 60 years since the Japanese surrender at the end of World War II. It was a most significant event in our nation’s history, for it was the first time that Australia came under threat of a direct attack. Out of a small population of some seven million people, almost one million Australians were mobilised in the war effort, both directly and indirectly. But it went beyond that: indeed the whole country was geared to supporting Australia’s effort. It was at that time that thousands of women for the first time entered the paid work force, often in heavy industry in the jobs that were left vacant by men who went to serve their nation overseas. Many women worked in a vast range of supportive and essential roles, such as those in the Women’s Land Army. The 60th anniversary of the end of the war provided the opportunity to recall our profound gratitude for the heroic achievements and sacrifices of those Australians who served in the defence forces and Merchant Navy during the war and all those who contributed on the civilian front.

speech.para: My generation is indeed a blessed one. We were spared the loss of life and suffering that touched so many families of our parents’ generation. We should not fail to recognise that 40,000 Australians lost their lives in that war and that 8,000 prisoners of war died in horrific circumstances in places like Changi and on the notorious Sandakan marches. These memories help in our resolve to ensure that the world lives in peace and that a conflict of this magnitude never occurs again. We recall the 55 million people around the world who lost their lives. So too do we recall the dropping of the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, graphically illustrating the destructive capacity of nuclear weapons and the dangers they pose for the survival of mankind. Much to our regret, our fears of the potential deadly force of nuclear weapons have more recently been reawakened.

Many people do not realise how real the threat was to Australia. Lives were lost in Darwin, which felt the brunt of 60 or so air raids, as did other towns such as Broome in the north-west. Even Sydney Harbour was not spared, with the incursion of Japanese midget submarines and the loss of lives on the HMAS Kuttabul. What stood out for me in the commemoration in my electorate was the large number of young people who were very keen to participate and learn the lessons of history. It is much the same at every Anzac Day service that I attend as well.

In the time that I have available this afternoon I would like to take the opportunity to acknowledge the fine efforts of many people who worked on a voluntary basis in my electorate on that day to provide a fitting commemoration to mark the 60th anniversary of the end of the war. I begin by acknowledging the support of the federal government for a range of activities that we undertook and the financial assistance that was provided and the members of my staff who worked to ensure a very successful weekend of commemoration.

The commemoration started on Saturday, 13 August, with the service march organised by the Port Kembla RSL subbranch. In particular, I thank Mr Ray Wetherall OAM, the president of that subbranch, and Angus Campbell, who took upon himself the coordination of the parade. And what a parade it was, with the Illawarra Pipe Band, the city brass band, the cadet units, the Light Horse troops and students from the local schools.

The main address on that day was delivered by Major General Brian Howard, who saw distinguished service in Vietnam. That evening the celebratory and commemorative atmosphere continued at a splendid dinner dance which involved many of our local community members. The next morning I was indeed honoured to present 65 commemorative medallions to World War II veterans, widows and widowers. Although it was disappointing that not all the medallions were processed in time for all the recipients to be granted their awards, those who were there on the morning were very pleased to have had their services acknowledged in a timely manner.

On Monday, 15 August—VP Day—the morning began with the laying of wreaths at Shellharbour City. I participated along with the mayor and councillors of the Shellharbour local government area and representatives of all the local RSL subbranches. The Albion Park RSL subbranch organised an exhibition of ‘show and tell’ memorabilia from World War II. Local students were invited to Centenary Hall, and it was estimated that some 900 students passed through the exhibition on that day. It provided the ideal opportunity for surviving World War II service people and community members to meet and talk with our younger generation. I am sure that the interaction on that day helped lead to a better understanding of Australia’s role in the war.

I place on the record my thanks to John Foran, President of Albion Park RSL, and Peter Ellis, Secretary of the Albion Park RSL, for this wonderful initiative. The commemorative events ended with a service on that day at the Warilla RSL subbranch. Their event involved representatives, again, of local schools and members of the Bass and Flinders Day Club. Each school was presented with a book for its library as a memento of the day. I thank President Keith Clemmett and Secretary Mary Clarke for their efforts in organising this event, which also displayed memorabilia from the era.

You can see, Mr Deputy Speaker, from the acknowledgments I have made that indeed one of the highlights in the electorate for me as local federal member was the fact that we were able to garner that level of support, enthusiasm and activity to mark a very important day in our nation’s history. As I said earlier, I think what was really remarkable was the number of young people who were enthusiastically involved and who interacted with the older generation so that they, too, could appreciate the significance of those events in shaping our nation’s history and our identity.

I also acknowledge the coverage that we received in the local media and, in particular, I want to conclude my comments by quoting some recollections of local veterans of VP Day, as reported in our local paper, the Illawarra Mercury. Former RAAF pilot Norman Gadsby, aged 82, recalled in his words that VP Day was indeed ‘worth a few sherbets’. He recalled:

quote.para: I was down in Melbourne when we got the news. We just went out and celebrated; it was an incredible day and a very long night.

speech.para: His wife, Joyce, was working at a building supplies store in Wollongong when word came through, and she recounted how people danced up and down the main street of Wollongong.

Another recollection comes from George Shelton, aged 81. Steaming towards Japan on the British aircraft carrier HMS Indomitable was George—then a young man—who said that the jubilation he experienced, along with his mates, on the ship was tempered when he arrived in Hong Kong to be confronted with the horrors of Japanese prisoner of war camps. He said:

quote.para: If you can imagine skeletons covered with skin—it was one of the worst days of my life.

speech.para: Noel Chapman, who served with the RAAF, reflected:

quote.para: These days have become important for the whole community, and in particular young people. That’s good because there’s not many of my mob left.

speech.para: In conclusion, I commend the Prime Minister for allowing members an opportunity to record their impressions, their thanks and their pleasure at the fact that their communities, through a wide range of activities across the nation, were able to come together and reflect on the significance of Australia’s involvement in the Second World War, the joy and some of the downsides of that experience, which really came to the fore on a weekend of great celebration and commemoration in the electorate of Throsby.

talk.start.para: —I would like to put my remarks this afternoon in a personal and a national context. On Anzac Day in 1949 I was almost five years old. At about half past four in the morning my mother woke me up. I think it was freezing cold. It was raining and it was windy. I very unwillingly went down with her to the train at the railway station at Largs North, where I lived, and caught the train to Adelaide. We walked to the Cross of Sacrifice and I attended my first dawn service, mesmerised—probably very confused—about what was going on. My mother, I could see, was very unhappy. I did not quite know how to deal with that.

speech.para: After the ceremony at the Cross of Sacrifice we walked down Pennington Terrace to North Terrace to the war memorial. In the war memorial in Adelaide you walk downstairs and all the names of the South Australians who died in the Great War and the Second World War are there. My mother went to the wall and rubbed her fingers along a series of names. She came to the last name, that of her brother, Reg Tuxford, who died in Corby in France in 1917. He was only a very young man. In fact, he lied to get into the Army. He was not allowed to join in South Australia, so he hitchhiked his way to Melbourne and did it from there.

At that time my mother’s family had cousins—the Vincents and the Barnes. Not one of them who went to World War I ever came home—not one. So a whole generation of relations of my mother were killed in World War I—all in France. My father’s family also served in France—every one of them came home alive and uninjured. In the Second World War my father’s family served in Tobruk, El Alamein and New Guinea, like many other families. Fortunately, they all came home, but some were very badly affected by their experiences in the Second World War.

Each Anzac Day went by and on one occasion, as I was sitting on the train, I remember a 10 shilling note being on the floor of the railway carriage. Enthusiastically—we were not very rich—I picked it up, gave it to mum and said, ‘Someone’s lost 10 shillings.’ She said, ‘You can have it.’ The next year it was a pound. The following year it was maybe another pound. When I was about 10, it was £10. That was half my parents’ wages. It took me all of that time to wake up to the fact that there was a guy who was always seated in the carriage who always lost money. It was perhaps his reward for my putting up with going to Anzac Day. I continued to go to Anzac Day and I continued to observe the characters of the generation who fought in the Second World War.

There are three very special generations of Australians and South Australians. The first are the people who came to South Australia and founded the fledgling colony. They were brave, gutsy people and we will never again see the like of those people in this country—or in the world. The second generation of very brave people were born in the period 1880 to 1910. Remember, at this time we thought the Russians were coming. To defend ourselves, we built forts along the coast of South Australia with great cannons. These people went through a worldwide depression in 1890 and the poverty right around the country in those days was appalling. In that context, there was a fellow called William Rooke Creswell, originally an Englishman, who came out to Australia to be the commander of the South Australian colonial ship the Protector, which fought in the Boxer Rebellion and served in World War I. I think it now forms a reef off the coast of Queensland, unfortunately. My Uncle Dave was the chief petty officer on the Protector—tough old cuss.

William Rooke Creswell was a brilliant person. He became and is known as the father of the Royal Australian Navy. He became Sir William Rooke Creswell. Prior to 1910, all the Australian ships were part of the Commonwealth Naval Forces. He formed the Royal Australian Navy in 1910 and became a rear admiral. Interestingly, we have never adequately remembered him, and a lot of other people of that generation.

Then comes the group who fought in World War II, the group we commemorate today. Remember they were children in the twenties, a time that was perhaps similar to today’s times when people lived the high life. Debt was huge. People were borrowing money on no collateral. Of course, the inevitable happened. When greed dominates economies, they go bust. So we had a depression and this generation lived through the Great Depression. In Adelaide thousands of people and their families were living in little shanties made of corrugated iron, cardboard and paper, living on the banks of the River Torrens. Where I lived, people were living in the sandhills—not just one or two but hundreds of people. It was not a great time. Jobs were very difficult. In my grandparents’ house there were 14 men. Only two worked—my father and my grandfather—the other 12 were supported by that family.

The bravest person who ever put on an Australian uniform was Thomas Currie Derrick, ‘Diver Derrick’, who grew up in Exmouth Road and Bucknall Road, Exeter, just around the corner from where I live. He could not get a job either. Like my father, he went up the River Murray in search of jobs: very poorly paid, with poor accommodation, but they got a feed. Diver Derrick came back and so did my father. My father was too old to serve in World War II and too ill, unfortunately, but Diver Derrick did. He served in El Alamein and got a DCM. He should have been awarded a VC, but he got a VC at Sattelberg in New Guinea. I will not go through his exploits but they are unbelievable. The Army tried to keep him out of the final days of World War II, but he wanted to be with his mates, and up in Borneo in the last days of World War II unfortunately he lost his life. We have not remembered him adequately in Port Adelaide either. There is a little street and a park, which I opened. He is regarded by all the military as the bravest person ever to put on an Australian uniform and we have not adequately remembered him.

These people lived through tough times. Compare World War II with World War I—four years in the trenches blowing each other to smithereens, not gaining a yard. In World War II, Hitler was in Paris in six weeks. He was walking down the Champs Elysees six weeks after the invasion of Poland. It is almost amazing to say that they were in Paris in six weeks.

Then, of course, there was the evacuation of the French and allied armies from Dunkirk. It was absolutely unbelievable, but it put the fear of God into everybody in the Western world. We had the Battle of Britain, where many Australians served and lost their lives. There was El Alamein, Tobruk, Crete, Greece, the shock of Pearl Harbor, the bombing of Darwin, the bombing of Sydney, the fall of Singapore and the sinking of the Repulse and the Prince of Wales. My mother tells me that in the streets of Adelaide people were just petrified. Forget the historians who are trying to rewrite history; people believed that the invasion was only months away. The Philippines fell, MacArthur came to Australia and John Curtin made a plea to the United States of America. There was the Battle of the Coral Sea, the Battle of Midway and the Kokoda Trail, and here is a generation that survived all of that. They are now in their eighties and nineties.

All of us have been to celebrations with these people. On the week before VP Day this year, I unveiled a plaque at the Port Adelaide Naval Association in memory of all the merchant seamen and Royal Australian Navy and Royal Navy personnel who lost their lives in World War II. On the 15th, I attended the Port Adelaide and Semaphore RSL to view a display of all the news clippings, souvenirs and memorabilia of World War II. It brings you back to earth. In many ways it is like going to a hospital and seeing someone fighting for their life. It puts your trivial worries, the worries that sometimes we blow out of proportion, into context.

This is a generation that did other things too. After the war they participated in probably one of the greatest postwar reconstructions this country has ever seen. It happened under a Labor government. We have failed to replicate in any way that reconstruction of the late 1940s and early 1950s. But, more importantly, we also had a social contract on employment that the community fought for and both governments actually supported. In fact, it was a move around the world. I suppose it was the basis of the welfare state in the United Kingdom and of a different approach in the United States and Europe. It has not lasted long. There is a frightening and striking similarity between the signs in the 1920s of where a world got incredibly into debt and could not control it and the indicators of today, but that is for another day.

In the next two weeks, like other members, I will be continuing to present Victory in the Pacific medallions to members of my community. I have been quite surprised: there have been about 1,900 in my electorate. Most people want them presented, and that has created a bit of a backlog for us. I think I have four presentations next week—one every morning! By the time you include friends and family it is a big function. Next week we will be based at the Port Adelaide and Semaphore RSL, assisted by Peter Davidson, the president, his committee and all his hardworking members, who are putting on the lunch. All I have to do is front up—I have the easy part—hand out the medallions, give a speech and thank everybody, and probably thank the younger versions of my parents’ generation for what they did. When I talked about the Port Adelaide Naval Association I forgot to thank Harley Doyle and his hardworking executive for organising for me to unveil the plaque at the naval association.

There is a bit of a sad touch to it all. One of my great supporters was Percy Lawrence, aged 86. On Anzac Day and on Remembrance Day I used to have to share my time between Port Adelaide RSL and the Naval Association because of family connections. I could not be at both places at the same time, so when I could not be at the Naval Association, Gundi Lawrence, who was an old merchant navy person—he went into the Royal Australian Navy and served on the Wilcannia—would lay the wreath on my behalf. Unfortunately, Gundi recently passed away. He lived a rich life; he was a wonderful man. We remembered the matters of the victory in the Pacific at his funeral, which was one almost bereft of grief. It was actually a celebration of this great man’s life. To Gundi and to Billie and the boys—Russell, Trevor, and Neville—I say thank you very much. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was honoured and somewhat humbled to celebrate Victory in the Pacific Day in my electorate alongside local veterans. I would like to use this speech to personally thank all of the RSLs in my district for making this year’s VP Day celebrations both memorable and enjoyable.

speech.para: Commemorating 60 years since VP Day is a stark reminder that, without the sheer guts and determination shown by men and women of this country during World War II, I would not have the opportunity to stand in this place today. Growing up, I have always had an ardent interest in history and I know that 3 September 1939 was a day that the world will never forget. The battles fought during the Second World War defined the world in which we now live. It would be six years before Australia and the world were at peace.

War with Japan was pivotal to the war effort, which brought the war to our very doorstep. World War II took Australians to virtually every corner of the world. Nearly one million men and women served in the armed services or merchant navy. From my own district, over 8,700 people who were born in Ballarat served in the Australian war effort—over 6,000 served in the Army; over 1,500 in the RAAF; 281 in the Royal Australian Navy; and nine in the merchant navy. We are not known for being surrounded by sea!

Kim Beazley described the men and women who fought in the First and Second World Wars as ‘our toughest generation’ and he is absolutely right. Australians were involved in many conflicts, which took the lives of many of Australia’s finest citizens. They served on two fronts: at home and overseas. When we look at the history of the war and the efforts being made by Australians across all areas of battle, and when we reflect on the fact that Australia was one of the nations hit hardest by the Depression, it is an enormous tribute to the men and women of that generation that we rose out of that. During the war in the Pacific, we essentially defended and saved ourselves, and we emerged from that war a different nation and a very different people. There was no nation whose people were more mobilised than the Australian nation. In this country every man and woman was turned to by the government and those responsible for organising the war effort.

In my electorate I have the fortune of having a fantastic group of veterans, who organised a number of events across the electorate to commemorate VP Day. I would like to thank in particular the Bacchus Marsh RSL which invited me to the Soldiers Memorial Hall on 15 August. Even the downpour of rain could not dampen the day. We moved the ceremony inside the hall, which was packed with veterans’ families, friends, local school students and community leaders. They were joined for the first time by the Ballan RSL. It was a fitting tribute for the day to see these two sub-branches there together.

As part of the proceedings I presented local veterans with their World War II medallions. We then enjoyed an absolutely delightful afternoon tea. Ballarat Legacy held a special luncheon on the Friday before VP Day, and I hear that a very good time was had by all. The RAAF Association in Ballarat, in conjunction with ex-servicemen’s clubs, organised in Ballarat a VP service on 14 August. That coincided with the military history group’s re-enactment of several battles and they had a number of military personnel and military equipment out at the airfield.

The service at Ballarat was attended by the Ballarat, Buninyong, Sebastopol, Ballan and Creswick RSLs, alongside other ex-service organisations. Local veterans turned out in force, as did the Ballarat community, to recognise the sacrifices local veterans made for their community and their nation. However, the day was marked by a sombre note. Arthur Lealand, who was 81, collapsed during the commemorative service and, despite the best efforts of local bystanders and paramedics, he died shortly afterwards. I had met Arthur on a number of occasions and had spoken to him just before we marched off that morning. Arthur was absolutely ecstatic—there is no other word to describe his mood on that day. He was brandishing with pride the baton that was used to conduct the band at the signing by the Japanese of their surrender. Arthur was there, and he had arranged for the baton to be used at the opening of our Australian ex-POW memorial in Ballarat and for it to be specially used in Ballarat at the VP Day anniversary. He came up to the mayor, David Vendy, and me to show us the baton and his contribution was formally acknowledged at the service. Unfortunately, Arthur collapsed shortly after and, as one RSL member said to me, ‘When I heard the Last Post playing I looked over at Arthur and I hoped that somehow he heard it and he went to rest.’

I had the pleasure of meeting Arthur’s brother Colin the next day at the Daylesford RSL commemoration where he was the guest speaker. He told me that Arthur was a staunch Ballarat Legacy member and, by all accounts, a handy batsman. He also told me, somewhat wryly, that Arthur was the youngest of the three boys who had all made it home from the war, and that he had broken ranks somewhat by dying before the other two. Family and friends have said that Arthur could not have asked for a more fitting final salute than to be surrounded by mates during such a historic anniversary. Mr Lealand will be sorely missed, and I would like again to pass on my condolences to his family and pay my respects to the marvellous contribution Arthur made to this country and to our local community.

It was at the Daylesford RSL ceremony where I had the pleasure and honour of meeting Arthur’s brother Colin and where Colin was the guest speaker. He gave a heartfelt and thoughtful speech. Again, as with all the VP Day commemorations in my electorate, it was great to see the whole community participating in the proceedings. The Clunes community also held a VP commemoration and lunch, and from all accounts it was a wonderful turnout involving all of the community, young and old alike.

The VP Day commemorations held across my electorate were a fitting commemoration to all those who served in the Australian defence forces during our country’s hour of need, and much thanks is owed to all the hard work of the local RSLs who spent many hours organising the events. I, unfortunately, do not have the time to thank all of the people involved individually, and I do not want to leave anybody out, but I would simply record my thanks to all those involved. Your contribution and service is a credit to your RSLs, ex-service organisations and the local community.

I, like other members here who are commemorating VP Day, have a number of medallion presentations to conduct. I will be doing my next one on Friday, and also several next week as we break from parliament. They are wonderful occasions and I think the medallion is a fitting way of recognising the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. I do have to say, though, that I have had a number of constituents talk to me about their disappointment about the criteria for the allocation of the VP medallion, particularly those families who have quite recently lost their World War II veteran, and they would like to be able to have the medallion in their family. I have of course, and I am sure other members of parliament have done the same, written to the minister to ask for some reconsideration of that. In my own family’s case, the only boy remaining in my mum’s family died just recently and, as she is the sole survivor of the family, I know personally from her that it is something she would very much like to have in the family to be able to commemorate not only his war service but also her brother who died at the age of 21 in the Pacific. So I think, whilst we are here commemorating VP Day, that perhaps there are some family members who are somewhat disappointed about not being able to have the medallion in their family and in their family history.

I also, just very briefly, want to talk about an experience I had most recently. Whilst we are talking about Victory in the Pacific and the 60th anniversary of VP Day, this year is also the 90th anniversary of World War I and of the Anzac Cove landings. Two weeks ago I had the opportunity to visit Gallipoli for the first time with Mount Clear College students and teachers, and the Mayor of the City of Ballarat. The college has developed a sister city relationship with Gallipoli High School and, through the wonderful work of a teacher, Ian Simpkin, has developed a cultural exchange between the two schools. It was incredibly moving to be at the site and, I think, probably even more moving to be able to be there when there is not a large crowd; when the silence of the sea and the silence of the site itself really give you an indication of what an incredible place it was to land.

One of the things I wanted to comment on is what has happened to the site in the course of the last 12 months. The teachers who were there with me have been to Anzac Cove on four separate occasions. The roadworks that have been undertaken at that site, regardless of what spin the government wants to put on it, have irrevocably changed that site forever. To paraphrase, one of the teachers said to me: ‘I look out at this cove, and I have photos from 90 years ago and photos from last year. Over the course of those 90 years, the shape and the skyline of that cove had remained unchanged. The wonderful thing about being at that site is that when you look out you see almost exactly the same image that those boys landing 90 years ago saw.’ He was able to show that. He had those photos and he could see that. But when we were there two weeks ago he said: ‘I can no longer say that. These kids who I’m bringing here today will no longer see the same sight that those boys who landed at this site 90 years ago saw. It has changed.’

The thing that I was shocked by, it being my first visit there, was that, whilst the Turkish authorities have clearly sought to accommodate the requests of the Australian government to improve vehicle access, it is less clear just how much oversight, if any, the Australian government had over that process. The Turkish authorities have done what they were asked to do, but when you look at the site you see that great excavations have happened. There is still soil dumped on the cove itself and there has been no replanting at the site. I must say, there desperately needs to be some remedial action taken to get that site at least back into a condition where it does not look as though it is a building site. It is a war memorial.

I understand there is a parliamentary delegation leaving to go to Turkey on the weekend, and I would encourage members of that cross-party delegation to look very closely at the site and make their own assessment. I understand that a Senate report is just about to be handed down and I would expect there are some critical comments in that as well. I would really encourage that parliamentary delegation to look very closely at the site, because there does need to be some attention paid to that and there needs to be some work done. I think that whilst we are here commemorating the 60th anniversary of VP Day—an incredibly important event to commemorate—we have an equal responsibility to make sure that those war memorial sites are not just something we pay attention to when there are cameras on us and when there is a big crowd there on commemoration days. They are in our custody forever and we need to take great care when we do anything to those sites.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to rise to speak on the motion before us today. The Second World War was, like all wars, a defining time in Australia’s history. It is really interesting to reflect on war and the part that it has played in Australia in bringing the nation together and forming our culture. After all, it was in 1915 at Gallipoli that all the newly federated Australian states came together as a proud nation. The Second World War also played a very significant role in the history of Australia, because it was the first time that Australians had to bunker down and fight on the ground to protect their own country. That was a very different way of looking at war. Previously, war had always been something that happened a long way away from Australia, but in the Second World War we were protecting our own shores. Every man, woman and child in the country joined the battle to save Australia.

speech.para: Australia was drawn into the war in the Pacific, in our own region, when we and the British colonies in Malaya and Singapore came under threat. It is also important to reflect on the fact that there were almost a million Australians—both men and women—who served in the Second World War. As well as the men and women who served in the actual conflict, there were many people who protected our home shores. There was the Women’s Land Army, established to encourage women to work in rural areas. Whilst the men were away fighting the war on foreign shores, the women were ensuring that those men had the food, the clothes and the equipment that they needed in that war.

Like the other members of this parliament, I have been working closely with the veterans community. When we were organising our Victory in the Pacific celebrations, I had a committee that worked very closely with me. On that committee were representatives from all RSLs within the electorate: Peter Moss from the Doyalson-Wyee RSL, Joe Hayes from the Pelican Flats RSL, Roy McDougall from the Catherine Hill Bay RSL, Doug Wallace from the Swansea RSL sub-branch and Hughie Winter from the Belmont sub-branch. Peter Moore, the President of the Toukley sub-branch, also worked with me, particularly in the presentation of my first round of medallions.

This committee helped me decide on the best way to allocate the $10,000 that the government provided for each member and their electorate. I would have to say that the choice was excellent. Money was given to Doyalson RSL for a very special commemorative function and to the combined Belmont-Swansea-Pelican RSL and the Catherine Hill Bay sub-branch for a similar sort of function. Out of the $10,000, money was allocated to purchase a Victory in the Pacific DVD for every school in the electorate. Those RSL sub-branches are going to help me distribute those at presentations within the electorate. So you can see just how important a role they played in the electorate and the celebrations and how I would be lost without the assistance that they give me—not only then but on all occasions. They are a very vibrant group, very caring about the welfare of all ex-servicemen within the electorate, and they are a group that provides support to them and their families at all times. On this occasion, they provided support and assistance to me.

When I was looking at the celebrations, how they affected people and what people thought when they heard that victory had been declared and that the war was over, I spoke to my mother. She said that she was standing in the kitchen preparing her breakfast. It was 7.45 in the morning. Next thing she knew, a friend burst in the back door and said, ‘The war’s over! The war’s over!’ Within about half an hour, the whole house was filled with friends and the celebration began. Since I spoke to her, I have also spoken to many of the people who have attended the celebrations that I held throughout the electorate.

One woman worked in the accounts department in a firm in Sydney. You may remember those machines that punch cards. They had been saving all of the little circles that had been punched out of the cards, and when they heard that the war was over they gathered these bags of confetti, went to the windows and threw the confetti out. And so the celebration began. Another person was in hospital in Singapore, and there was someone on a ship and a woman driving in a car—she and her husband were together. They were just overcome by the joy of the occasion.

This is something that we probably find a little bit difficult to understand, because this had followed the Depression—as other speakers have said—where there had been extreme deprivation. It was a time when people in Australia had done it hard and battled in a way that I have never had to battle and that my children have never had to battle. I know that in the Depression my grandfather bred chooks. Those chooks were used to sustain his family. They grew things to eat in the garden, whereas these days most people just walk to the supermarket and buy those things. So it was a totally different time—a time when Australians had been poverty stricken. It was a time that followed the Great Depression, but even given that hardship Australians had the resilience to fight and work to save our nation.

It is also important to note that the Second World War was a time of massive industrialisation. As I said before, it was quite often the women who moved in. We produced our own equipment and food. We fought the war and we fed and equipped the people who fought in it. My father-in-law did not fight in the war; he was required to stay at home. He was a radiographer and his job was to X-ray all the bombs to make sure that everything was properly manufactured. So there were so many different ways that people contributed to the war effort. As I mentioned, Australian women ran Australian industries. It was a time of great change for the women of Australia. They had to work in munitions factories while the men were on the Kokoda Trail. It is important to mention here that Kokoda is considered Australia’s most significant campaign of the Second World War. It was there that Australians halted the Japanese advance into Australia. It was a defining moment in Australia’s nationalism—as was the battle in Darwin—when the nation was saved from invasion. It was defining because Australia was under threat and we fought and saved our nation.

At a local level, each year we have a commemorative service at Norah Head on the Central Coast. We are commemorating the effort that the Merchant Navy made to Australia’s war effort. On that day we remember the many people who lost their lives at sea. We particularly remember the sinking of the Nimbin and the Iron Chieftain just off the coast at Norah Head. It is a very poignant ceremony each year, and it is interesting that the entire coast of New South Wales—I say New South Wales because that is the area I am familiar with—is littered with ships that were sunk during the Second World War. We do not realise just how close to home the war was.

My mother tells me that she was out on Sydney Harbour on the day the Japanese submarines pulled up. She had had to travel from Manly to Sydney. She has shared with me the feelings that existed at that time. Another friend, Lachy Watkins, helps me out a lot when it comes to veterans ceremonies. When I am down here, he invariably represents me. Except for last year when he was at Gallipoli, which was a very special time for him, he has accompanied me on every Anzac Day ceremony I have attended whilst I have been in the parliament. He was in the 2nd/33rd Infantry Battalion and served in New Guinea, Moratai and Borneo. He was at the bottom of Shaggy Ridge. He still wakes in a sweat at night, shaking from the memories of that war. He says the memories are always with him. He says that, no matter what, he cannot forget what happened there; it is forever with him.

The terrain in New Guinea was formidable and difficult and combat was often in torrential rain. There were more deaths from tropical disease than from combat fatalities. One description I read of the area described it as one of ‘swift-flowing mountain streams, dense, dank rainforests and almost vertical mountainsides’. Our troops who were there suffered from extreme sleep deprivation and inadequate shelter, food and medical supplies. They battled constant wetness, knee deep in mud, and the tortuous terrain of the Owen Stanley Range. They had to contend with the worst tropical diseases. They were ordinary, everyday Australians. They were Australians from my region who worked in the mines. They were Australians who, after the Depression, were battling to care for their families. Above all, they joined together as proud Australians to defend our coastline. We as Australians should be very proud of them. We as Australians are very proud of them—not only those who fought in New Guinea but also those who fought Hitler in Europe. Their role and contribution was enormous. They were involved in every aspect of the war in Europe. As a nation, we are very proud of them. We are also very proud of those who fought the battle at home—the women who were involved in providing the equipment, food and munitions that our soldiers needed. Australia salutes and thanks all those who fought for Australia in the Second World War.

talk.start.para: —World War II ended on 15 August 1945. We have recently had the opportunity to express our gratitude to those who served in the Second World War, to honour those who are still with us and to commemorate those who fell. In announcing the end of the war against Japan on 15 August 1945, Prime Minister Chifley said:

quote.para: Fellow citizens, the war is over. The Japanese government has accepted the terms of surrender imposed by the allied nations and hostilities will now cease. The reply by the Japanese government to the note sent by Britain, the United Nations, the USSR and China has been received and accepted by the allied nations. At this moment let us offer thanks to God. Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may look forward to a peace which they have won for us.

speech.para: We can only imagine how much relief and how much joy was in the hearts of people hearing the words that war was now over, yet how much sadness there must have been for the people that they had lost and the sacrifices that they had made. Some one million Australians served during World War II and almost 40,000 of them were killed. Many more people were injured during the war and 30,000 were taken prisoner. For every one of those who did not come back, there is a family who still grieves. For those who did come back, changed by war, there was a lifetime of readjusting. I think we should also remember that, although Australians suffered during this war, the peoples of every nation suffered. That is the problem with war.

Less than a week before the cease-fire, many Japanese people were killed in the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki when those new and deadly bombs were dropped. I think it is worth remembering that those people too—women, children and noncombatants—died in a terrible way at a terrible time in our international history.

The war ended and soldiers returning had all sorts of difficulties in readjusting to their civilian lives. Many of the women who had taken up the burden of working in the factories and on the farms had enjoyed their new-found competence and freedom, and suddenly they were expected to drop all their new skills and return to the home to raise families. They certainly loved their families, but the war had shown them that it was possible to do more—to do work that benefited the community and brought income into the family as well as raising their children. Just as many of the soldiers had difficulty readjusting to their lives as civilians, I think many women had difficulty in adjusting to the idealised life that was set out for the 1950s housewife.

Recently in my electorate we had a ceremony to honour those who served Australia and the allied nations. We had a morning tea on Friday, 12 August at the Australian National Maritime Museum. There we unveiled a commemorative plaque and presented special medallions, commemorating the end of the Second World War in the Pacific, to World War II veterans, their widows and widowers. There were 874 eligible recipients in the electorate of Sydney, and we were able to invite all of those people to the morning tea at the Maritime Museum because of the extraordinary generosity of the Australian National Maritime Museum. I take this opportunity to thank in particular the Director of the Maritime Museum, Mary-Louise Williams, and the Assistant Director, Michael Crayford, who did an excellent job as Master of Ceremonies on the day, and Inger Sheil, who did the bulk of the organising of this day. We thank all of the staff at the museum who helped and supported this event not just for their work on the day but also for their work during the lead-up to the day. We now have a wonderful commemorative plaque on the wall of the National Maritime Museum, facing Sydney Harbour, that thousands of tourists pass every day and that thousands of schoolchildren can see every week. Veterans of World War II can see it at any time and know that Australia honours their work and honours their sacrifice.

I want to particularly acknowledge the very good work of a number of the local RSL clubs in putting on this function. James Park, who is the Honorary Secretary of the Balmain-Rozelle RSL Club, and Aub Silcock from Redfern RSL were absolutely tireless in their efforts to make this event the wonderful success that it was. All credit should go to James and Aub for their hard work. But their work does not stop at this one event: each of them is organising or has organised further events in their local sub-branch areas to remind the community, particularly our young people, of the importance of this anniversary of victory in the Pacific.

I would also like to thank Father John Knight, the parish priest of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Waterloo, who offered prayers on the day and our friend from the Salvation Army who also offered prayers on the day. Bill Orton, the President of the Balmain-Rozelle RSL Club, made a wonderful contribution. We thank State Transit for providing buses to transport all our veterans and schoolchildren. Our photographer, as always, was the wonderful Izzy Perko. He has sent a photograph of every veteran or every veteran’s widow or widower receiving a medal to them. I know that those photographs have been greatly appreciated. Councillors Tony Pooley, Marcelle Hoff and Shayne Mallard attended from the City of Sydney Council.

Our very special guest was Mr Tom Uren, a former minister in the Whitlam government. Tom enlisted in the Royal Australian Artillery in 1939 and later served as a bombardier with the 2nd/1st Heavy Battery in Timor. From 1942 to 1945, he was a Japanese prisoner of war in Timor, Java and Singapore, on the Burma-Siam railway and in Japan. Tom remembers the dropping of the bombs on Nagasaki and Hiroshima; he remembers seeing the mushroom clouds. Of course those years as a soldier and, more particularly, as a prisoner of war were terrible years not only for Tom but also for the men that he was locked up with. But those years built in Tom a spirit of forgiveness, compassion and generosity that I think he would agree were in many ways the making of him as a man. We were very lucky to have Tom with us on the day not only to remind us of his experiences but also to remind us that war is never to be glorified and that these opportunities are not opportunities to glorify war but to honour the sacrifice of the people who went to fight fascicm.

The people who received medals on the day were Mr Frank Balbi of Rosebery, Mr Francis Breen of Balmain, Mr Harry Brindle of Camperdown, Mrs Lydia Bushell of Glebe, Mr Dusan Davidovic of Chippendale, Mrs Ethel Driscoll of Beaconsfield, Mr Alan Duncan of Balmain, Mr Donald Gale of Sydney, Mrs Sonia Gidley-King of Woolloomooloo, Mr Denis Gray of Millers Point, Mrs Elaine Hickey of Redfern, Mrs Isabella Jones of Potts Point, Mr Thomas Marshall of Alexandria, Mrs Juanita Minter of Balmain, Mr Rex Minter of Balmain, Mr Patrick Morriss of Glebe, Mr Iukhym Sapozhnikov of Waterloo, Mr Roland Schilling of Glebe, Mr Harry Slarke of Centennial Park, Mrs Maria Texeira of Waterloo, Mrs Sylvia Wardell of Balmain, Mrs Alice Weeks of Waterloo, Mr Ken Buckley of Sydney, Mr Efim Solovei of Surry Hills, Mr Burt Mulford of Redfern and Mr James Gray of Glebe. We also had a medal for Mr Bill Orton and we honoured Mr James Park and also Mr Aub Silcock.

This may be the last chance that veterans of Victory in the Pacific have to gather in great numbers to have their particular contribution honoured. So I wish to say to every one of the people on the list I have just read out and to every one of the over 800 people who are eligible for this honour in the electorate of Sydney: we thank you for your sacrifice and we acknowledge your hard work. We know that the number of young people who attend Anzac Day services across the country continues to grow. Again, I do not believe it is because these young people honour war. I think it is because they honour sacrifice. Just as we remember those who fought for us, when I looked into the eyes of the veterans to whom I was presenting medals I knew that they were remembering their mates who fell.

talk.start.para: —This is an important occasion for the parliament to pause and record its thanks, gratitude and appreciation for the sacrifice of a generation of Australians who, during World War II, saved Australia. There is a simple truth in all of this: that generation and their deeds did in fact save Australia from tyranny. They established the basis for what has been 60 years of relative peace and prosperity, and without their great deeds that would not have been possible.

speech.para: A while ago this parliament discussed a similar motion in respect of victory in Europe, and it was appropriate that we paused then to acknowledge the contribution in that theatre of war. As with the European campaign, Australian forces distinguished themselves in the Asia-Pacific region. It is probably the case that the first defeat suffered by the Nazi war machine in Europe occurred at Tobruk, which was largely held by Australians—indeed, the first defeat for Rommel was with forces commanded by an Australian officer.

The same can be said in the Pacific theatre of war. The Japanese war machine had effectively conquered all through Asia—through Korea, China, Indochina and Malaya, and had taken what was then regarded as the invincible stronghold of Singapore. It was not until August 1942, when they sought to take Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, that the Japanese suffered their first defeat on land. That was at the hands of Australian troops, most of whom were citizen soldiers. They were not career soldiers. They were part-time soldiers who had taken up the call to defend their country and their families. They had gone to New Guinea to resist the expected invasion, which came on 25 August. In extremely fierce fighting over some 10 days they repelled the Japanese attack on Milne Bay, and in so doing inflicted the first defeat on the Japanese army.

At the same time, and over the period of that battle, Australians were engaged in another very bloody encounter, on the Kokoda Trail. I think few Australians grow up without knowing the story of the Kokoda Trail and the great sacrifices by Australians and by Papua New Guinea citizens on the Kokoda Trail. I think we should acknowledge the contribution of those Papua New Guinea citizens, the people who lovingly became known as the ‘fuzzy wuzzy angels’ and without whom many more Australian lives would have been lost. We often see photos of Australian wounded being helped down treacherous mountainsides in terrible conditions by the fuzzy wuzzy angels. What is not as widely known is that many of them served in their own Papua New Guinea battalions and took up arms and fought alongside the Australians.

Also not often recognised is that, for most of the war in the Pacific, General MacArthur, the Supreme Allied Commander in the Pacific, had more Australians under his command than Americans. It was not until 1944 that MacArthur had more Americans under his charge than Australians. The brunt of the land battle in the Pacific was borne by Australian men and women. To their great credit, they performed with enormous valour and courage.

The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, in his contribution at the start of this debate, referred to the writings of an American historian in a book titled Touched With Fire. I want to repeat that reference because it rang a chord with me and a number of others with whom I have spoken. This was an American’s view of Australians involved in Papua New Guinea during those days. The American observed:

quote.para: The ingenuity required on the frontier, which Australians call the ‘convict mentality’, was very real. There was also a genuine ruggedness to the national character. Physical courage was highly prized. A broken nose was easy enough to come by in pre-war Australia ... It is, I think, safe to say that somewhere along the line the ‘Protestant work ethic’ lost some of its intensity in Australia. An Australian infantry man who served at Milne Bay told me they were glad to hear of the Japanese attack because that freed them from an ugly road building detail in the mud.

speech.para: He concluded:

quote.para: Soldiers who would rather fight crack Japanese assault troops than build roads win wars.

speech.para: And indeed they did. I think it is a very insightful observation of those rugged Aussies by an American historian.

I think we should also pay tribute to the other Australians who were involved—not necessarily in such a high-profile way. Whilst the Army was heavily engaged in the war in the Pacific—at Kokoda and Milne Bay and on the islands of the South Pacific—it was supported by Royal Australian Navy and Air Force personnel. They fulfilled not just the normal combat roles but a wide range of other roles, including strategic support and intelligence gathering. Some of those intelligence-gathering activities were every bit as treacherous and dangerous as the front-line combat activities. Australians who had the role of spotter were stationed with their radios on small uninhabited islands across the Pacific, and their observations of the movements of Japanese navy and aircraft were essential in providing the intelligence that allowed the allied forces to do so well in the major battles of the Coral Sea and Midway. Without the intelligence that they were able to provide at great risk to themselves, events may well have turned out differently.

I suppose their role is more often recognised, to the extent that it is, by virtue of one particular incident, where an Australian noticed that an American patrol boat had been sliced up in the night. It just happened to be commanded by John Kennedy, who later became President. It was an Australian spotter who was able to relay the information that rescued JFK and the survivors of his crew. The people in the Navy and the Air Force who provided that support and those in the Air Force who engaged in the bitter air battles in the Pacific deserve great commendation as well. Certainly in the early part of the war they often engaged in battles with inferior equipment but never without great commitment to their country.

I also want to acknowledge the people who were back home during that period. Some of those were in uniform and eager to go to war but never did. There was an Australian armoured corps unit, the name of which I forget at the moment. They were equipped with Matilda tanks and it was intended for them to go abroad on two occasions but they were never able to. I have met a number of people who were in that unit, and they certainly would have matched the courage of other Australian troops who were involved in that theatre. There are also the people who protected Darwin and Northern Australia from the attacks that occurred on land from the bombings of the Japanese air force.

I also want to acknowledge the role that women played during that period, including the Women’s Land Army, which was absolutely critical in ensuring that the needs of the nation continued to be met while literally millions of its people—its men—who had held down jobs were at war.

talk.start.para: Mr Price interjecting—

—As I am correctly reminded by my friend the member for Chifley, there was the role that women played in all walks of life in industry. This enabled the planes to be built, the weapons to be made and the vehicles to be constructed. None of that would have been possible without the role of women. There is no doubt that the women who were involved in those many facets of activity during World War II, whether it was formally as part of the Women’s Land Army or in other roles in industry, played an essential part.

speech.para: I also want to include a comment about the role of Indigenous Australians in the Australian Defence Force. They receive, I have to say, far too little recognition for their contribution. There were outstanding examples of Aboriginal Australians making such a contribution. And we have to remember that at that time they had no right to vote or even to be counted as human beings in the census. They were not regarded by the government of the day and the nation as a whole as people to be counted in a census. They were not, in most parts of Australia, paid the same wage in civilian employment as the white person working beside them. But they were committed Australians and many Aborigines served in the Australian Defence Forces—in all services, but particularly in the Army and the Air Force. I think it is a great tragedy, frankly, that it took until two decades after the war for them to receive the same basic rights as all other people, following the referendum in the mid-1960s. They should be remembered. Aboriginal Australians who fought during that period did so with great valour, and I hope that one day their story will be receive more publicity than it has had until now.

Finally, I want to acknowledge the people in my own electorate who have participated in the commemorative celebrations that have been held and who will participate in the celebrations that are yet to be held. This Saturday I will have the great honour and pleasure of attending a film evening with about 150 to 200 of my constituents. There will be some World War II newsreels, a large number of old diggers and their families, and the opportunity to present some awards to some of those assembled there. It is going to be a great evening. These occasions are important and, as the member for Sydney pointed out, they are important not because anyone wants to glorify war—the tragedies and the harm that come from that are all too obvious when we turn on our television sets every night. But it is more than appropriate that we thank those people for their sacrifice and acknowledge their contribution. Occasions like this are important for doing that. I want to especially thank the many people at the Gaythorne RSL in my electorate who have given their time—not just on occasions like this but on every day of the year—to support our veterans, as have the members of the Ashgrove RSL and the Bardon RSL. They do a fine job and we all owe them a debt of thanks for their support of a generation that was special.

In conclusion, I think this generation deserve greater thanks and credit than any other I can contemplate—and not just because of the deeds performed during World War II. This was a generation that grew up as children during the Great Depression. As young people they did not enjoy any of the normal worldly benefits that we might have enjoyed when we grew up or that our children do. They grew up and, as young adults, went into a war. After having gone through a depression, they moved as young adults into a war over many years to defend our nation. They then came back and put their shoulders to the wheel and helped build one of the most prosperous countries on the planet. That is a great testament. I think any one of those things makes a generation stand out, but that generation endured all three and did so with great fortitude, great pride and a great outcome. I think it is a wonderful testament to them and it is appropriate that we should acknowledge them.

talk.start.para: —I somewhat reluctantly follow the contribution of my friend the honourable member for Brisbane and shadow minister for homeland security. Certainly, I totally endorse all of his contribution. I begin my contribution with the remarks I made in my electorate and with which the Leader of the Opposition concluded his contribution to this debate. They were the words of Ben Chifley, the then Prime Minister, a month after Curtin died. On 15 August he said:

quote.para: Fellow citizens, the war is over ... Let us remember those whose lives were given that we may enjoy this glorious moment and may look forward to a peace which they have won for us. Let us remember those whose thoughts, with proud sorrow, turn towards gallant loved ones who will not come back ... Nothing can fully repay the debt we owe them, nor can history record in adequate terms their deeds from the black days that followed September 1939, and December 1941, until this moment.

speech.para: I cannot say that I have experienced war; in fact, I am a baby boomer born in the year that peace was declared. I think we forget what Australia was like in those days. Out of a population of six million, half a million people were under arms. We paid as we went as far as the war was concerned. Today we are a population of 20 million. We are not at war and our armed services comprise something like 50,000 people. As the honourable member for Brisbane pointed out, so many people contributed and so many received inadequate recognition for their efforts. I am pleased that he raised the issue of those in our Indigenous community who served and have been very much ignored.

I wish to speak of the contribution of Australia’s women. Australia, under its total mobilisation then in place, could not have kept wartime industry and the civilian components that were operating going without the contribution of women. When I say ‘the contribution of women’, they actually did jobs that they had never done before. They did jobs that were seen as jobs for men. They worked in munitions factories and on tanks and aircraft. Again, the honourable member for Brisbane has outlined that. I know enough to understand that there is nothing nice or attractive about war. I think that the older one gets the more one wants to very much avoid war. It is never the old who glory in war, but it is the old who send the young men and women of a nation to war.

We had a wonderful ceremony in Chifley, the details of which I would like to place on the public record, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick. A mutual friend of ours and former Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca, initiated an Australia Remembers service. I have to say that I have always counted myself a good friend of Con Sciacca. I put on the public record that he did not get to open the memorial gardens in the electorate of Chifley, much to my bitter disappointment. The gardens were a combined effort of the Rooty Hill and St Mary’s RSL sub-branches. Those memorial gardens continue today. I am fond of saying that council does not have flowers west of Alpha Park in Blacktown, but we have roses in the memorial gardens. They are a beautiful thing and both RSLs contribute many man-hours and hard work to keep them in pristine condition.

Kevin Hall, the president of the Rooty Hill RSL sub-branch, and Leanne Taylor, the president of the St Mary’s RSL sub-branch—who unfortunately could not join us on the day—were the two chief officials. It was just a wonderful ceremony. I got an unexpected but special reward, which was the privilege of unveiling a plaque in the memorial gardens. I was very touched. For me to unveil that plaque in front of people who had served during the war, been widowed during that war or served in subsequent wars under the Australian flag was a very moving thing. I did not get a lot of notice on the speech, but nevertheless I hope I did them proud.

But more than the remarks of the officials, or of the chaplain, I might say—I mean no disrespect—what gave real significance to the ceremony was the participation in the ceremony of all the students from the primary schools in Mount Druitt and the surrounding suburbs. It was just wonderful. Please forgive me if I mention the schools, but I am indebted to the teachers and more so to the students. I know it affected me, and those veterans appreciated it heaps—the students made it even more meaningful for them. The schools included Rooty Hill Public School, St Marys South Public School, St Marys North Public School, Bidwill Public School, Shalvey Public School, Hebersham Public School, Glendenning Public School, Colyton Public School, Dawson Public School, Lethbridge Park Public School, Willmott Public School, Minchinbury Public School, Plumpton Public School, Mount Druitt Public School, St Marys Public School, Eastern Creek Public School, Blackett Public School, Tregear Public School, Emerton Public School, Hassall Grove Public School and Noumea Public School. Thanks to those students.

Once upon a time in this country we had to fight hard to perpetuate Anzac Day, which primarily commemorates World War I, but it is these students’ understanding and sense of the sacrifice and what it was like, not any contribution here today—notwithstanding, I am sure, many fine contributions—which will perpetuate our memories and our gratitude for all those who served and all those who contributed, many of whom lost their lives.

Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, I know that you have a relative who fought in World War I. I hope that in the future we never see a war of this dimension, although the nature and character of war seems to have changed quite dramatically. We often talk at different services about how much those actions contributed to peace, but I often wonder whether we honour the people involved, particularly those who lost their lives, by fighting for peace just that little bit harder. As we have turned the century and as we have turned the millennium, it has not been a peaceful planet, I have to say. It is not a peaceful planet in the way I think we would all have hoped that it would be. If we want to honour veterans and honour so many people other than veterans and their families who contributed to our success in World War II, we, particularly as legislators in this place, owe it to them to work that little bit harder for peace.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to join my colleagues on both sides of the House as we pause to remember the men and women who sacrificed their lives in a time of war, particularly on this occasion of the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific Day. Like many of my colleagues, I have had the honour and the privilege of presenting commemorative medallions. On Saturday, 13 August I was able to present medallions to 70 local World War II veterans and widows at the Toronto RSL Memorial Club. On Tuesday next week I will be continuing that presentation, with a medallion presentation to veterans and widows at the Boolaroo Speers Point RSL Memorial Club.

speech.para: We have all mentioned the commemorative activities that have taken place in our electorates to commemorate the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. The Toronto RSL sub-branch began planning their commemorations more than 12 months ago, back in September 2004, because they knew that this would be a significant occasion and they were going to have the biggest and the best regional commemoration to celebrate the 60th anniversary of Victory in the Pacific. On Sunday, 14 August, I was honoured and privileged to participate in the commemoration ceremony. It was the largest in regional New South Wales and local school students performed extremely well. The sub-branch organising committee had a strong commitment, as the member for Chifley was just saying, that young people in our region should lead the commemoration honouring veterans and widows because young people really are going to make the difference, to make sure that we live in a peaceful world in years to come. On Monday, 15 August, the organising committee held a special luncheon at the Toronto RSL Memorial Club to honour World War II veterans and widows and to commemorate the end of World War II.

It would be remiss of me not to mention a lot of the people involved. There were the 12 months of organisation, the medallion presentation on the Saturday and the students had a march down the Boulevard, the main street of Toronto, around to the cenotaph. Only people honouring the veterans marched; the veterans and widows who were being honoured stood along the roadside and then joined us at the cenotaph for a program run entirely by school students from Lake Macquarie Christian College at Fassifern, Toronto High School, St Paul’s High School at Booragul and Blackalls Park Public School choir. There was not an adult voice to be heard throughout the whole ceremony.

The weekend commemoration was organised by the organising committee of the Toronto RSL sub-branch. I honour them here today: they did a fantastic job. The chair of the committee was Henry Miller. The school liaison person was Cec Donaldson OAM, who is a long-time stalwart and supporter of our local community. The patron of the Toronto sub-branch is Air Vice Marshal Jack Cornish (retired) AO, CBE, LVO, AFC. The publicity officer was Peter Stephenson. The secretary of the organising committee was John Handley. The assistant secretary and all-round gofer was Ron Richardson. The treasurer was John Renfrew. Other committee members were Brian Field and Gordon Gardiner. They should be very proud of the way the activities went and of the successful events over the whole weekend.

The main commemoration happened on the Sunday. At the service we had the honour of the RAAF Air Command Band from Richmond and also the Australian Army Reserve Band from Newcastle. Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, I do not think you have had the opportunity to visit Toronto on the shores of Lake Macquarie; you should come one day. During the Sunday afternoon, we all adjourned to the park down on the foreshore and the RAAF band went into swing in the rotunda there. Everyone enjoyed a wonderful sunny afternoon down by the lake following the commemorations.

There was also a flyover that had been arranged by the organising committee. It was vintage planes that were owned, operated and provided by Cole Paye and Phil Unicomb. It was a flyover comprising Kittyhawk, Wirraway and Trojan planes. Then at 1 pm on the Sunday we had a jet flyover that came from Williamtown RAAF base. For those of us who were not ready for it, it came as a bit of a shock. We do not usually have RAAF jets flying over Lake Macquarie.

The commemorations also included a publication. It was suggested by the organising committee that a publication be produced by high school students. It was, and it is called Sacred Records: Stories from World War II. It was compiled and edited by children from Toronto High School. These students did this under the supervision of their teacher, Mrs Beverley Richardson. They are year 7 independent learner students at Toronto High School and this publication is a great credit to them. It is going to serve as a memory and a way to continue honouring World War II veterans and widows.

A lot of stories in this publication came from these students interviewing members of their own families. As I said, Cec Donaldson OAM is a local identity and the first interview was with him. When Cec was interviewed he gave a bit of his background. He said that he had enjoyed being a cadet at school so when they heard the first reports of the war he decided that he was going to be a soldier. In the publication he is quoted as saying:

quote.para: First came the war, then the rations. The rations we had were horrible. Everything was pretty bad those days. I would go as far to say that everybody was everybody’s friends in the war and if one of them died they’d just let it be, because really there was nothing they could do about it.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: The war was indescribable, it was just so hard to look at all the people who took pride in their country just fighting till death right in front of your eyes

speech.para: Young Tynan Jayne interviewed his grandfather who was a young boy during the war. He recalls:

quote.para: One chilly August morning in 1945, I was walking to school with my sisters, Carmen and Shirley, when suddenly the big air raid siren screamed to life. People stopped everywhere, unsure what to do, terrified, fearing an attack. I stood paralysed to the spot, searching the faces around me for clues on what to do.
Moments later the local newsagent, Mr. Cook, came racing out of his shop yelling. “The war is over, the war is over!” The Japanese had surrendered.

speech.para: There is another interview with Mrs June Bickle. I do not have the time to go into it as far as I would like to; I will just quote the first part. June is very well known and well loved throughout our community. The article says:

quote.para: Every ANZAC Day and every Remembrance Day the people will see June Bickle with two flower posies to lay in tribute; you will also find June at the Field of Remembrance planting two wooden crosses.
One of June’s tributes is for her late husband, Alan Bickle, who was a long term president of both the RSL Memorial Club Ltd and also the president of the Toronto RSL Sub-Branch.

speech.para: The other tribute is for Charlie, who was killed in action in 1941. Charlie was June’s brother. The article goes on:

quote.para: ... at just eighteen years of age Ordinary Seaman Patrick was on his first ever voyage on a Naval ship.

speech.para: He was on the HMAS Sydney when he lost his life.

As many people have said, this is not to honour war; this is to honour the sacrifice that our veterans made to ensure that we all live in a democracy and in a safe land as we do today—and that that continues on for our children as well.

All the commemorations around Toronto that weekend had an empty chair sitting there with an Australian flag, a tin hat and a pair of boots. Peter Stephenson, who was the publicity officer on that organising committee and was also the secretary of the Toronto RSL sub-branch, wrote a poem about this and these are Peter’s words. The poem is called An Empty Chair.

quote.para: A single chair sits empty:
Our flag is draped about
And on its seat sits still:
A ‘‘tin-hat’’ and boots at its feet:
We may see this empty chair
And think of nothing else:
Yet as we celebrate our Vict’ry
Ghosts watch on and smile:
This is not an empty chair
For in it sits the spirit:
Of those who’ve gone before us
Those who’ve shown the way
This chair is here to remind us:
Of those who could not
Be with us in the flesh today:
They’re here yet all the same
So as we gaze upon this chair
Let us see the faces
Of young and vibrant warriors:
Sitting with us, in this place
Let’s take peace and joy
Their work was not in vain:
Let’s celebrate the past
Knowing they are freed of pain

speech.para: I know Peter is very proud of that poem, and so he should be.
The Prime Minister, while speaking to this motion in this House, paid tribute to Australia’s wartime Prime Minister, John Curtin. He said:

quote.para: ... to our own Prime Minister at the time, John Curtin, who died on 5 July 1945 and was thus denied the opportunity to see the victory to which his leadership had made a very significant contribution.
