I pay unconditional tribute to the contribution that he made in the time he was Prime Minister during World War II.

speech.para: In his recent biography of John Curtin, author David Day wrote:

quote.para: Curtin committed his life to achieving a better Australia for all its citizens ... He was of that optimistic generation that came to adulthood in the wake of Federation and which had its hopes tempered by the horrors of the First World War. Despite that experience and the years of the Great Depression, or perhaps because of them, Curtin continued to devote himself to improving the lives of ordinary Australians. It was his hope for a better Australia that drove him, at a terrible cost to his health, to galvanise Australians against the dangers of a military invasion that would have destroyed those hopes for all time.

speech.para: In conclusion, I once again honour all those veterans and widows of the Charlton electorate. I wish them all the best of good wishes and health. I pay tribute to all who made such an important and significant contribution to our history. We must never forget the tragedy of war, and future generations must commit to doing whatever is needed to ensure that the international community works towards world peace encompassing respect and justice for all global citizens.

talk.start.para: —As I am the oldest member of the ALP in the House, being born in June 1941, I want to talk about some memories. I was just over four when the war ended. I remember vividly my Uncle Bill, Bill Lostetter. He was an American Marine and he married my mum’s sister, my Aunt May, who was a teenage American war bride. I remember when Uncle Bill was on leave in Australia going around to my grandmother and Grandpa’s place in Hampton and seeing him there in his gear and being impressed.

speech.para: Uncle Bill served in Guadalcanal, one of the areas of huge loss for the American Marines, and Iwo Jima and all those sorts of areas. My Aunty May was shipped, with many other teenage American war brides, across the Pacific in very dangerous conditions with their young children. Aunt May arrived on the west coast of America and then was sent by train across to Cincinnati in Ohio to live with Uncle Bill’s family. She had never met them before. She did not know whether she would ever see him again, but this was her new family in a strange country and she subsequently settled there. When Uncle Bill returned from the war they moved to Downey in California.

I have other memories of that time. As I said, we lived in Hampton. We had an air-raid shelter in the backyard. I remember as a young four-year-old—the eldest in the family—clambering in and out of the air-raid shelter; it was a sort of cubbyhouse. I also remember the searchlights in the sky over Melbourne. A bit later, we moved up to Ballarat because my grandparents were ageing. I also remember the rationing and going to the grocer with mum with a ration book. I still have it at home, and it is one of my proud treasures. Those were the days of rationing and small amounts of butter, sugar and tea. That was before plastics were invented. There was no such thing as putting your recycling out. Everyone had chooks. We used to collect the horse manure, because the bread and milk were delivered by horse and cart, and we had a wonderful garden sprinkled liberally with horse manure.

I remember my father telling me after the war had ended and I was getting towards the stage of going to school about the contributions made by some of his mates who had served with him in the First World War; they were young enough to participate in the Second World War and had gone back for a double dose. Fortunately, my dad was wounded seriously enough in the First World War not to have to venture a second try. I remember when a neighbour, Clarrie Everett, a 19-year-old, left for the Middle East and served in the African desert. He was withdrawn from there and was expected to—and did—fight in the Pacific. He went from the trauma of the heat, the dry and the dust of the African campaign to the heat, the wet, the damp and the unknown of the jungles of the Pacific. He was so tormented that, not long after he returned, he ended up killing himself.

I remember the Anzac Day marches in the forties and, as a child, proudly going along and watching my father march. Remember that, in the late forties, most of the guys from the First World War were still in their 40s—and there were the young blokes who had come back from the Second World War marching proudly. The Anzac Day marches lasted forever and ever.

Since I have been a member of the federal parliament I have visited the Kokoda Trail, Lae, Wewak and Madang. I have visited parts of the Marshall Islands and have seen first hand some of the battlefields and war memorials. I was in Lae and Wewak when the rain absolutely pelted down. I thought, ‘How in the name of creation could you ever fight anybody in these conditions?’ It was 33 or 34 degrees, there were inches and inches of rain and it was real jungle. How could you fight and survive in something like that?

I remember children who had Winston as part of their name. The Prime Minister’s middle name is Winston and so is my brother’s—John Winston Howard and Robert Winston Quick. I remember the saying about the Yanks being ‘overpaid, oversexed and over here’. I remember hearing stories about the ‘battle of Spencer Street’ when a train load of Americans came in saying, ‘Don’t worry fellas, we’ll look after your women for you!’ A few people got rather excited and discharged weapons, and some died as a result of that confrontation.

I remember going out to where the American soldiers were based in the forests in Ballarat when I was a young cub and unexpectedly finding a pistol that had been left behind. I remember wondering whether I should stick it in my rucksack and go home, excited, but I must have been well trained, because I handed it over to my sixer and then it was handed over to the scoutmaster. As I got older, being a student of history, I tried to get in touch with many of the diggers of the Second World War who had served in the Pacific, to try to understand some of the experiences and traumas they experienced. One of my best mates’ fathers, Bob Brownlie, who served in the Air Force, who was almost like a surrogate father to me, told me of his experiences in the Pacific.

Most of us have organised a variety of events in our electorates to pay due respect and homage to these people—as people have said, not just to the men but to the women. As a student of history, I remember reading of the tragedy that beset the Australian nurses in the Pacific, who were captured by the Japanese and most of whom were executed. Vivian Bullwinkel is the famous nurse who survived to tell the story. Women stayed at home and worked in industry. Growing up in the Mallee, I knew of the role of women in the bush who stayed and worked to ensure that the farms continued, because in those days most of the men who could enrol did enrol.

It is a time that we should not forget. Most of these people are now well into their 80s, and many are in their 90s. I think we have learnt the lesson from the First World War where, tragically, we let them get to the stage that the Second World War guys are at at the moment and suddenly realised that they were dying in vast numbers. There are now only three of them left. Someone mentioned Australia Remembers and Con Sciacca. I think what we are doing here with Victory in the Pacific goes some way to recognising the wonderful role that they played in ensuring that we live in the best country in the world, with the democracy that many people dream of. When I have my thanksgiving celebrations and hand out the medallions on 28 October, I will do it with a tear in my eye because, as I said, there are strong links through my family and through many of my friends’ parents who are no longer with us. I would like to pay tribute publicly to all of these people who have contributed much to our history.

talk.start.para: —I too want to make some remarks in respect of Victory in the Pacific Day. I want to start by thanking the government for going to the effort of recognising this day and providing sufficient funds for all our electorates to honour this celebration. It is quite interesting that, for years and years, our celebrations of the Australian war effort have concentrated on World War I, so it was fascinating, appropriate and timely to actually do something in respect of World War II. I hope, as members of parliament, all of us will continue this tradition—be it funded or not, whether there are medals or not—and do something on this day in years to come, because I think it reinforces for the generations who have no recollection or linkage to the war whatsoever that people did make a great sacrifice. In those traditional words, lest we forget.

speech.para: This also gives us a time to recall that we do honour those who gave their lives, but we also continue to have Australian service men and women serving for our country overseas. The notion of a returned service man or woman is not gone, and we still have people returning from conflicts, returning injured, but, touch wood, not returning dead. We need to recall that people continue to engage in active service on behalf of our country.

I, like everyone else in this place, was privileged to be part of many ceremonies for VP Day. On the day itself we had two very moving services. One was at the Oakleigh RSL, where a phenomenal speech was given by Mal Carson, the past president of the Waverley RSL. Many people attended that fantastic service. I want to thank Neil Slaughter, at the Waverley RSL, for being the driving force behind that. I want to thank Chris and Peter, a phenomenal duo, at the Oakleigh RSL, for all their efforts, and I also want to thank Ray Scott at the Clayton RSL for the work he did on that day. So in the morning we had that service.

In the afternoon we coordinated through the Box Hill RSL, and a big thank you to Tony Bowden for that. We invited students from the local schools to attend a memorial service, and we asked grades 5 and 6 to be present. We provided them with a base to make their own wreaths, and they could do whatever theme they wanted. We also asked them to provide some poetry for the day. I would like to share with you some phenomenally inspirational words from children who have no direct experience of these conflicts. Kingswood College Junior School students wrote:

quote.para: To the men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in the Battle for the Pacific in WWII; We are grateful for giving us the freedom we enjoy today. We are now aware of the brutality and cruelty many of you suffered and the bravery and mateship you showed each other, which have become a symbol of the spirit of the Australian soldier. May history never forget you and may you continue to be honoured.

speech.para: St Benedict’s Primary School, my old alma mater:

quote.para: Some lived, Some died
In our hearts, they survive.
They fought for our freedom
And some went to prison.
We celebrate on August 15,
When a new day had arisen.

speech.para: Mont Albert Primary School:

quote.para: As Sadako Sasaka was dying of leukemia in Hiroshima, she folded paper cranes as a prayer for health. On her deathbed she held one up and said, “I will write Peace on your wings and you will fly all over the world”.
We share her dream of a world without war.
It is up to the children of the world if Peace will come in the end.
Give us the knowledge and wisdom to help prevent wars.
We wish there were no war, violence or terrorism anywhere.
We wish that everyone would co-operate, show tolerance and respect; and live in harmony.
We wish that the cranes could fly free.

speech.para: Presbyterian Ladies’ College Junior School:

quote.para: On and on and he ran through the fields
Each step he took would hopefully bring Australia one giant leap towards freedom.
Japanese soldiers lay in wait on the muddy ground
The sky was turning blood red as he ran towards the dreaded No Man’s Land.
Bullets whistled past his ear
Japanese gunmen laid low on the hills
Waiting for the perfect moment to strike
One moment felt like a lifetime
Suddenly everything was silent
A smooth, cold bullet punctured him
Slowly he fell to the ground
“For Australia” he whispered silently in a hoarse voice
When would the terror and bloodshed end?
Hiroshima devastated along with the hopes of innocent civilians.
A white flag rose and the war came to an end
To this day we remember the brave who died for the greed of man.

speech.para: Our Lady’s Primary School:

quote.para: VP Day
60 years ago, PM Chifley announced,
World War II was over. People started to dance.
Over 1,000,000 Aussies fought to defend
But for 40,000, their lives came to an end.
Today we gather here to remember
Those women and men whose lives changed forever.
We celebrate the end of World War 2
As world peace and freedom, we pursue.

speech.para: Mount Scopus Junior School:

quote.para: A day of mourning, a day of grief,
Today we are going to lay this wreath.
For the soldiers that have died,
In their Australian pride.
They dressed in green,
With their fatal machine.
Knowing their fate was near,
They stood their ground, without any fear.
In our minds the bravest men of Australia,
The ones who fought for their country and gave up their lives.

speech.para: Clayton Primary School:

quote.para: To end a war that should not have started
To bring joy to the broken-hearted.
The men and women that went to war
Swore to the enemies, that they would never fall.
Many years have passed us by
When many soldiers cried and died.
We remember them on this day as VP day
When World War 2 went away.
It’s been 60 long years
Of pain and tears
We’ve tried our best to comfort
The brave.
We remember them today
As heroes who set us all free,
To live today in peace and harmony.

speech.para: Wattle Park Primary School:

quote.para: The war was bloody,
The guns never stopped,
And there was a good chance that you would be shot.
Lots were killed,
40,000 in all,
And then there was no fighting,
The end of World War.
Soldiers died,
To keep us free,
To save Australia
For you and me.

speech.para: Kerrimuir Primary School quoted from Rudyard Kipling’s Ode, which he wrote for the commemoration of the Melbourne Shrine of Remembrance. I am going to read just a couple of stanzas:

quote.para: SO LONG as memory, valour, and faith endure,
Let these stones witness, through the years to come,
How once there was a people fenced secure
Behind great waters girdling a far home.
Their own and their land’s youth ran side by side
Heedless and headlong as their unyoked seas—
Lavish o’er all, and set in stubborn pride
Of judgment, nurtured by accepted peace.
Thus, suddenly, war took them—seas and skies
Joined with the earth for slaughter. In a breath
They, scoffing at all talk of sacrifice,
Gave themselves without idle words to death.
Then they returned to their desired land—
The kindly cities and plains where they were bred—
Having revealed their nation in earth’s sight
So long as sacrifice and honour stand,
And their own sun at the hushed hour shall light
The shrine of these their dead!

speech.para: I found the whole ceremony incredibly moving. Some World War II veterans were present in the audience and there was not a dry eye in the house. We were also very blessed to have a veteran address the group. The children and I were quite stunned to find that this man had spent six years on the front line. He survived, he came back and 60 years later he was still alive. I, too, asked various people what they remembered about the end of the war. My mother said, ‘I was pretty young and I think we got a day off school.’ My dad said that his most vivid memory was a couple of weeks later when he was sitting around at home as usual. A whole bunch of people were sitting around having a cup of tea—I come from pretty good Irish stock—and someone said to dad, ‘Barney’—that is how they referred to him—‘see that bloke in the corner; he’s your dad,’ and it was the first time he had met him. He had returned from World War II. Dad was probably about eight. He had no recollections of him prior to going to war, and there was this man in the corner who was his father. He lived for only a couple more years. My father said that the most vivid memory he has of his childhood was meeting the man who was his father. My grandfather served in World War I and World War II. Like many of us, we have connections to this horror.

I hope that these celebrations and commemorations demonstrate to those people who fought for us so long ago that we do not forget. We thank them for their service, we commemorate them and, hopefully, as I said, we will not let this pass as a one-off. As electorates, we will share the valour of our World War II heroes and remember them. It was not just the men who fought; many Australian women fought and many Australian women did their bit back home. All of Australia was at war at that time.

Sadly, I have two regrets about this occasion. I would like to put on the record my sadness for Norm Furness, from the 2nd 22nd Battalion, who was hoping to get back to Rabaul this year for a commemorative service. Veterans were sent there by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. Sadly, Norm’s group in Melbourne were not made aware of that commemoration and no-one from his regiment, who was on the front line, was given the chance to attend that ceremony. I am disappointed on their behalf.

I am also disappointed on behalf of a couple of veterans in my area—particularly Cyril Ashton, who was a citizen of the United Kingdom at the time. He was conscripted aged 19. He did his war service. He did his bit at the hospital where they sewed up what they referred to as ‘the guinea pigs’—those people who came down during those tragic air battles over England. Sadly, as his service was not recognised as being part of a conflict because he was not actually overseas—although in Cyril’s words ‘They were dropping bombs on me every day, so I figured I was probably in a war zone—he was not entitled to a 60th anniversary medallion and that caused him some grief.

I would like to thank all those people involved, particularly Ric from my office who did such great work to make our medal presentation the splendid day it was. To the Mount Scopus children who came and presented, on behalf of the Jewish community, their memories of war, my thanks. Thanks to the Pacific Island dancers who came and represented the Pacific Islands and all those who partook in the ceremony. Lest we forget.
Debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: Can he say when a Medicare Office will be opened in Gungahlin in the electoral division of Fraser, one of eight new offices to be opened, as indicated in the Health Insurance Commission’s announcement of 31 August 2004 which can be viewed on its website.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
talker.role: Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Hockey

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Medicare Australia has leased premises for a new Medicare office in Gungahlin, ACT. The site chosen is in a newly developed shopping centre called ‘The G’ which is owned and developed by Coles.
The Gungahlin Medicare Office opened on 19 September 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Are debt collection companies engaged to assist in the recovery of Family Debt overpayments; if so, what sum was paid to debt collection companies during 2004?
How many overpayments were referred to debt collection companies?
What is the name of each debt collection company engaged for this purpose?

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
talker.role: Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Hockey

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, debt collection companies are engaged by Centrelink to recover overpayments from non-current customers for a range of payment types, including Family Tax Benefit.
Debt collection arrangements vary from year to year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Does any agency for which the Minister is responsible pay for massages for its staff; if so, what sum did each agency spend on this purpose in 2004.
What was the cost per massage.
How many staff made use of this service.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST)

item.para: DEST does not generally provide massages for staff on an ongoing basis. On occasions, massages are arranged on-site, but paid for by participating staff. In one isolated case, DEST paid a total of $550 (excluding GST) for massages for staff in the Melbourne Office. This was a local area OH&S arrangement in response to staff continuing to work while the floor was being refurbished around them.
The massages cost $12.50 (excluding GST).
44 staff made use of the service.

quote.para: QUESTACON

item.para: Questacon operates as a separate business unit with its own Certified Agreement, under which Questacon paid a total of $1,850 (excluding GST) for massages for staff under a Health Awareness Program.
The massages cost $12.50 each (excluding GST), in addition to a fee of $100 (excluding GST) to hire the massage chair for 5 days.
140 staff made use of the service.

quote.para: None of the Agencies under the Portfolio have provided massages for their staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: Are there any plans to close the Medicare office located in 16 Walkers Arcade, Coburg.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
talker.role: Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Hockey

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Medicare Australia has no plans to close the Coburg Medicare Office located at 16 Walkers Arcade, Coburg, Victoria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: What year was the Medicare office at Mt Druitt closed?
How many transactions were completed in the last 12 months of operation at the Mt Druitt Medicare Office?
What was the value of dead rent paid for the Mt Druitt Office?

In respect of each Medicare office that has been opened since the Medicare Office at Mt Druitt was closed, (a) what is its address, (b) in which electoral division is it located, and (c) what is the annual number of transactions it processes?
For the most recent calendar year for which the information is available, which Medicare office processed the (a) highest and (b) lowest number of transactions and how many did it process?
For the most recent calendar year for which the information is available, what is the (a) average and (b) modal number of transactions processed by all Medicare offices combined?

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
talker.role: Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Hockey

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: 63,453 transactions were processed from April 1997 to end March 1998.
The following information relates to those Medicare offices opened since the Mt Druitt Medicare Office was closed:

entry.para: Shop 15, Rosebud Village Shopping Centre, 967 Point Nepean Road, Rosebud, VIC
Shop 115, Westfield Fountain Gate Shopping Centre, 352 Princes Hwy, Narre Warren, VIC
Shop T02, Palmerston Shopping Centre, 10 Temple Terrace, Palmerston, NT
Shop 31, Leichhardt Market Place, 138 Flood Street, Leichhardt, NSW
Tenancy G3, Sanori House, 126 Grand Boulevard, Joondalup, WA
Shop 26, The Pines Shopping Centre ,313 KP McGrath Drive, Elanora, QLD
Shop 61, Centro Cranbourne Shopping Centre, High Street, Cranbourne, VIC
Shop 1142, Westfield Tuggerah, Cnr Wyong and Gavenlock Roads, Tuggerah, NSW
Shop 11, Wynnum Shopping Centre, 89 Bay Terrace, QLD
Shop 323, Level 1 Sunshine Plaza, Horton Parade, Maroochydore, QLD

item.para: For the 2004 calendar year:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Woden Medicare Office, ACT processed the highest number of transactions, which was 415,574; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Bega Medicare Office, NSW processed the lowest number of transactions, which was 62,635.
For the 2004 calendar year:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The average number of transactions processed by all Medicare offices was 189,965.

item.label: (b)
item.para: There is no modal number (number with the highest frequency of repetitions) of transactions processed by all Medicare offices combined, as no Medicare office had the same number of total transactions processed for the 2004 calendar year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: What are the names and academic qualifications of the managers of the (a) Corporate Services Branch, and the (i) Human Resource/Industrial Relations Section, (ii) Finance and Business Support Section, (iii) Information and Communications Technology Section, (iv) Risk Management and Internal Audit Section, and (v) Security Section, (b) Regulatory Branch, and the (i) Nuclear Installations Section, (ii) Facilities and Sources Section, and (iii) Regulatory Strategy and Policy Section, (c) Medical Radiation Branch, and the (i) Medical Physics Section, (ii) Ionizing Radiation Section, (iii) Radiopharmaceuticals Section, and (iv) Personal Radiation Monitoring Service Section, (d) Non-Ionizing Radiation Branch, and the (i) Ultraviolet Radiation Section, (ii) Electromagnetic Radiation Section, (iii) Engineering Support Services and Quality Assurance Section, and (iv) Publications and Multimedia Section, and (e) Environmental and Radiation Health Branch, and the (i) Analysis and Monitoring Section, (ii) Environmental Radioactivity Section, (iii) Health Physics Section, and (iv) Standards Development and Committee Support Section of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency.

talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing
talker.name: Mr Abbott

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Corporate Services Branch: Carol Cheung, Director Corporate Services Branch (Bachelor of Arts (Mathematics & Computer Science) and Master of Business Administration); (i) John Nasser, Manager Human Resource/Industrial Relations Section (Diploma in Human Resource Management/Industrial Relations); (ii) Catherine Johns, Manager Finance and Business Support Section (Graduate Certificate in Professional Accounting and Advanced Diploma in Accounting); (iii) David Tomlinson, Manager Information and Communications Technology Section (Diploma in Aeronautical Radio and Certificate in Microprocessor Technology); (iv) Risk Management and Internal Audit Section (note: this section provides secretariat support to the Internal Audit Committee and is staffed by the Director of Corporate Services Branch); (v) Peter Ellis, Manager Security Section (Diploma in Security Risk Management, Diploma in Front Line Management).

item.label: (b)
item.para: Regulatory Branch: Don Macnab, Director Regulatory Branch (Bachelor of Science (Physics and Mathematics), Master of Engineering Science (Nuclear Engineering)); (i) Vince Diamond, Manager Nuclear Installations Section (Bachelor of Science (Engineering)); (ii) Facilities and Sources Section (note: Section amalgamated into Radiation Safety Section); (iii) Regulatory Strategy and Policy Section (note: Section amalgamated into Radiation Safety Section); (iv) Jim Scott, Manager Radiation Safety Section (Bachelor of Science, Master of Science (Applied Radiation Physics) and Bachelor of Arts (Mechanical Engineering)).

item.label: (c)
item.para: Medical Radiation Branch: John Baldas, Director Medical Radiation Branch, Bachelor of Science, Doctor of Philosophy (Chemistry); (i) Julian Thompson, Manager Medical Physics Section (Bachelor of Science (Physics), Doctor of Philosophy (Science)); (ii) David Webb, Manager Ionizing Radiation Section (Bachelor of Science and Doctor of Philosophy (Science)); (iii) Zlata Ivanov, Manager Radiopharmaceuticals Section (Diploma of Applied Chemistry, Master of Science (Chemistry), Doctor of Philosophy (Chemistry)); and (iv) Neil Morris, Manager Personal Radiation Monitoring Service Section (Bachelor of Science (Physics)).

item.label: (d)
item.para: Non-Ionizing Radiation Branch: Colin Roy, Director Non-Ionizing Radiation Branch (Bachelor of Science and Doctor of Philosophy (Radiation Chemistry); (i) Peter Gies, Manager Ultraviolet Radiation Section (Bachelor of Science, Doctor of Philosophy (Physics)); (ii) Lindsay Martin, Manager Electromagnetic Radiation Section (Bachelor of Science and Doctor of Philosophy (Physics); (iii) Stuart Baylis, Manager Engineering Support Services and Quality Assurance Section (Associate Diploma in Electronic Engineering); and (iv) John Briggs, Manager Publications and Multimedia Unit (Bachelor Agricultural Science, Diploma Education, Graduate Diploma Business Computing).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: In respect of the placement of twelve departmental officers with employer industry organisations to assist employers to access Skilled Migration programs, (a) what process was used to select the employer organisations, (b) which employer organisations are involved, and (c) where will the officers be located.

What are the arrangements with the employer organisations concerning the operational costs of locating the officers with employer organisations and to whom will the officers be accountable for their day to day work.

In respect of the placement of department officers through the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) network, is the department aware that New Apprenticeship Centre staff located in the ACCI have been required in the past to assist in recruiting members to ACCI, if so, what action has been taken to ensure that such misuse of government resources for private commercial purposes does not occur.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Advertisements seeking expressions of interest were placed in The Australian, The Sydney Morning Herald, The Canberra Times and the Age on 21 May 2005. Industry Groups were asked to submit a brief proposal outlining how the department officers would be utilised and addressing the following selection criteria:
extent of skills shortage,
extent of education required in the industry,
extent of organisation support available for the officer, and
the work plan proposal.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The following industry groups are involved:
Australian Chamber of Commerce & Industry
Master Builders Association
Housing Industry Association
Motor Trades Association of Australia
Australasian Railways Association
Commerce Queensland
Growcom
National Farmers Federation
Victorian Employer’s Chamber of Commerce & Industry
Manufacturing & Engineering Skills Advisory Board Victoria
Australian Industry Group
Australian Business Ltd
Association of Consulting Engineers Australia
Australian Mines & Metals Association
WA Resources Sector Consortium (CME & APPEA)
Chamber of Commerce & Industry WA
Business SA
Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce & Industry
Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce & Industry
Restaurants & Catering Australia
In addition, the department is also working closely with the Minerals Council of Australia but not on an outplaced basis.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The officers will be located in Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne, Darwin, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Brisbane. Some will have national and others state wide coverage.

The Department is responsible for salary, travel, equipment for presentations and related administrative costs. The host employer organisation will provide a work area, some equipment and administrative support needed for the day-to-day work of the officer. The officers remain accountable to the department.

DIMIA has taken steps to ensure clarity on the role and activities of the industry officers. A draft Deed of Agreement has been developed for signing with each host Industry group. The Deed identifies clearly the role of the industry officers and does not include membership recruitment activities.

In addition, the Industry officers are developing business plans, in conjunction with the host industry group and the department. These plans will clearly outline the roles and responsibilities of the outposted officers. These will include advising on immigration options to the employer members of the organisation, promoting electronic lodgement and liaising on policy/procedural issues that require attention.

The effectiveness of the program is being monitored through strategies such as monthly reports received from each industry officer on their activities and progress with the business plan. The program will be formally evaluated after nine months.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: Do security staff at Baxter detention centre dispense prescribed medication to detainees; if so, has the wrong medication ever been dispensed to a detainee by security staff.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Where medication is required by detainees at Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF) at night or on Sundays, Detention Services Officers deliver medications prescribed to detainees by authorised medical staff by way of “Webster Packs”. A “Webster Pack” is an A4 card, printed with the patient’s name, medication and daily/weekly dosage. Attached to the front of the card is a clear plastic blister pack which a pharmacist fills with the appropriate medication, thus enabling the delivery of medication by non-clinical staff. Pharmacists are the only people able to fill a Webster Pack and this is done in accordance with prescriptions authorised by a qualified medical practitioner. Delivery of medication via Webster Packs is undertaken in accordance with procedures that have been approved by independent medical experts. Where officers deliver medication via Webster Packs the Webster Packs are returned to the Health Centre as part of the control process where nurses review the medication delivered and note the detainee’s medical chart accordingly.
Webster Packs were introduced at Baxter IDF due to intimidating behaviour by detainees towards nursing staff who previously dispensed after hours medication from trolleys at the accommodation units.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs’ (DIMIA) records indicate that on 1 December 2004 a detainee advised that he had been provided with medication of a type that he no longer required on 29 November 2004. The Detention Services Provider (DSP) was asked to investigate the matter. DIMIA was advised that the detainee had left the IDF and that no medication was provided to the detainee on the date in question.
Neither DIMIA nor the DSP is aware of any other incidents involving incorrect medication other than that described above, which has not been substantiated.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: What were the grounds for the decision to waive the jurisdiction of the Queensland courts to try Lance Corporal Craig Meeks and Staff Sergeant Beryl Wilson Jr in relation to the alleged assault and attempted murder of Mr Heath Twomey of Townsville.

Can he explain the process that was followed in making this decision, including details on the date of the decision, the name and position of the decision-maker and the information collected before the decision was made.

At the time that this decision was made, what assurances or undertakings did the Government receive from the Government of the United States of America as to the steps that would be taken to ensure that Lance Corporal Meeks and Staff Sergeant Wilson would face charges for the alleged assault and attempted murder of Mr Twomey.
Did the Government request that the US military proceedings in this matter take place in Townsville or elsewhere in Australia; if so, on what grounds was this request denied.
What steps did the Government take to ensure that Mr Twomey or other Townsville-based witnesses could give evidence in the US military proceedings.
What steps did the Government take to monitor the conduct of this matter through the US military justice system.
What steps, if any, did the Government take to assist the US authorities that investigated and tried this matter, including assistance to prosecutors.
When did the Government first become aware that no charges had been laid against Lance Corporal Meeks and that Staff Sergeant Wilson had been acquitted.
What steps did the Government take to ensure that Mr Twomey and his family were informed of developments in the matter, including the acquittal and the decision not to lay charges.
Why has he failed to acknowledge or reply to correspondence (dated 5 March 2005 and 24 May 2005) on this matter from Mr Michael Reynolds, Member for Townsville in the Queensland Parliament.

Since 1996, how many times has the Government waived the jurisdiction of an Australian, State or Territory court to try foreign nationals accused of crimes committed in Australia so that the foreign nationals could be tried in another country.

In respect of each occasion since 1996 that the Government has waived the jurisdiction of an Australian, State or Territory court, (a) what were the details of the case including the alleged crime, (b) what were the grounds for the waiver, (c) which other country was involved, and (d) what was the outcome of trial in that country.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
talker.role: Attorney-General
talker.name: Mr Ruddock

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The decision-maker considered a broad range of factors such as the views and wishes of the complainant, the need to deter recurrence of the alleged conduct by visiting forces, the length of the trial processes in each jurisdiction, the comparative penalties in each jurisdiction and the comparative costs of trial in each jurisdiction.

The decision was made on 19 May 2004, by Robert Cornall, Secretary of the Attorney‑General’s Department. The following information was collected before the decision was made: the views of Mr Heath Twomey, the views of the Queensland Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the difference in penalties, the comparative costs in either case and who would bear them, and the difference in compensation arrangements.

The decision to waive Australia’s jurisdiction in this case was made on the basis that the marines would be appropriately tried under US military laws, which comprise disciplinary as well as criminal sanctions.
No.
Once transferred, the United States has jurisdiction and it is not appropriate for Australia to interfere in the United States’ proceedings.

Once jurisdiction was transferred, the United States had the responsibility to update Mr Twomey about the proceedings. Since finding out about the outcome in this case, the Government sought further information from the US about the handling of this matter. It is regrettable that the US did not inform the complainant about the outcome of this matter. However, the Government has since been advised that the US has spoken and written to the complainant about the approach to the trial and its outcome.
The matter was thoroughly investigated by the US military, with the cooperation of the Queensland Police.
The Department contacted the US Embassy on 21 April 2005, to enquire about the Meeks and Wilson case and was informed of the outcome.

Since finding out about the outcome in this case, the Government sought further information from the US about the handling of this matter. It is regrettable that the US did not inform the complainant about the outcome of this matter. However, the Government has since been advised that the US has spoken and written to the complainant about the approach to the trial and its outcome.
I replied to both of these letters on 7 July 2005.
Since 1996, the Government has waived jurisdiction under section 10 of the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963 over four individuals.
Request 1

item.label: (a)
item.para: Charged with rape and sexual intercourse without consent, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, and (d) 18 years confinement, reduced to lowest military grade and dishonourable discharge.
Request 2

item.label: (a)
item.para: Charged with being an accessory to rape, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, (d) 2 years confinement, reduced to lowest military grade, ‘total forfeiture’ (ie no pay), and dishonourable discharge.
Request 3

item.label: (a)
item.para: Charged with aggravated assault, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, (d) investigated by US and charges not progressed.
Request 4

item.label: (a)
item.para: Charged with attempted murder, (b) the alleged victim and the relevant state Director of Public Prosecutions supported the waiver, (c) the United States, and (d) acquitted.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 9 August 2005:

item.para: In respect of the provisions of the Commonwealth Protective Security Survey Manual regarding checks on Top Secret files, what audit procedures have been undertaken by his department to identify problems in the management, security and location or retention of classified material held by Commonwealth agencies from 1998 to the present
Have any of the audits identified discrepancies in the management, security and location or retention of classified material held by Commonwealth agencies.

In respect of the correspondence between Deputy Secretary, Mr Miles Jordana, and the Herald Sun reporter, Mr Mark Dunn, dated 29 June 2005 which confirmed that the Attorney-General’s Department holds material “coming into the ambit” of an FOI request lodged by Mr Dunn and that the material identifies a number of ‘discrepancies’ of the type mentioned in his request, how many discrepancies have been identified.
What is the nature of the discrepancies and do any of the discrepancies constitute security breaches.
Were any of the discrepancies identified in relation to classified documents; if so, how many classified documents were involved and at what security level were these documents classified.
What specific steps have been taken by the department since the first security discrepancies were identified to prevent further breaches or discrepancies from occurring.

Can he confirm that the view of his department as expressed in the decision not to release information relating to security discrepancies that “vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the storing and retention of such material are likely to exist within the Department” is correct.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
talker.role: Attorney-General
talker.name: Mr Ruddock

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Responsibility for the management of classified material rests with each agency’s Chief Executive Officer/Secretary. Each Department is responsible for auditing their own security procedures. Australian Government agencies complete an annual survey on their protective security compliance and the results are considered by Government. The Attorney-General’s Department Security Unit is responsible for security audits internally.

The Department does not conduct protective security audits of other Australian Government agencies. The internal audits conducted by the Department’s Security Unit noted minor discrepancies in the management, security and location of the Department’s information holdings.
The information recorded is largely qualitative in nature and cannot be readily converted to numbers or statistics.

The discrepancies noted in the internal audits related to procedural errors in the management of Departmental information holdings. These were minor. Identifying and monitoring these procedural errors assisted the Department to improve its security practices.

These discrepancies related to classified and unclassified documents and files at varying classifications. All breaches were minor and so no investigations were undertaken. The exact number of documents was not recorded in the audit reports, as the reports commonly focused on the procedural weaknesses in the affected areas.

The Department has conducted and continues to conduct security audits and make recommendations for improving security practice. The results of these audits are monitored and targeted security training is provided where necessary. The Department also has in place a security awareness training program for all staff.

The answer is no. The response provided to Mr Dunn was that: “The material sought by you identifies the type of vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the storing and retention of such material that are unavoidably likely to exist within the Department from time to time.” The discrepancies identified within the Department have been of a minor nature and therefore were not investigated. The Department undertakes security awareness training and continues to monitor security procedures to ensure compliance with the standards detailed in the Protective Security Manual.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 17 August 2005:

item.para: What enquiries did the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, as the Acting Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, make before issuing the statement on 26 April that “All people working as psychologists at immigration detention facilities are appropriately trained and registered with relevant agencies” in response to credible information that unregistered psychologists were practising at the Baxter Detention Centre in contravention of South Australian law and in clear breach of the Detention Services Contract between DIMIA and GSL.

Is the Minister aware that the South Australian Psychological Board pursued the matter and found that the psychologists were not registered and consequently advised them that any further breaches of the law would be referred to the Crown Solicitor’s office for prosecution.
Can the Minister account for, or explain, the Acting Minister’s apparent error in this matter.

What action has the Minister taken to improve the process by which statements are issued from (a) the Minister’s and (b) the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs’ office since becoming aware that the statement issued on 26 April 2005 was incorrect.

In respect of the breach of clause 7.1.9 of the Detention Services Contract between DIMIA and GSL which requires that “All detainees must be able to access timely and effective primary health care, including psychological and psychiatric services. At all times, care needs must be identified and delivered by qualified, registered and appropriately trained health care professionals” can the Minister provide the date on which GSL informed DIMIA of the Default that occurred, as it is required to do under clause 8.1.1 of the Detention Services Contract.
Can the Minister advise whether DIMIA has issued a Default Notice under clause 8.1.2(a) in relation to this matter.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: to (4) The intent of the statement of 26 April 2005 referred to the training and registration of psychologists employed on an ongoing basis, all of whom were registered with the appropriate professional board in a state of Australia. After investigation by my Department, this remains the case.

However, after further investigation, it is true that two psychologists who provided short-term relief services at Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF) had omitted to obtain mutual recognition of registration in South Australia in advance of this. They obtained the proper registration on 2 May and 4 May 2005 respectively and both apologised in writing to the South Australian Psychological Board for their oversight.

The Acting Minister’s statement was not intended to mislead. It was interpreted in a way that was not anticipated at the time. The relevant officer has apologised to me for not being clearer in preparing the statement.

After requests for more detailed information, on 7 July 2005 the Detention Services Provider (GSL Australia) advised my Department of a total of fifteen instances in which visiting psychologists providing services at the Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre and Baxter IDF had failed to comply with state mutual recognition registration requirements while providing short-term relief or visiting services.

In all cases, there is no indication that the psychologist involved did not have the appropriate skills and training to provide psychological services. All psychologists were trained and properly registered to work as psychologists in the state in which they usually worked.

to (6) My Department does not consider that clause 7.1.9 of schedule 2 of the Detention Services Contract was breached in these instances as the health care professionals were in fact registered as psychologists in other states and there is no suggestion that they were not appropriately qualified and trained to provide psychological services to detainees. However, my Department does consider that there were breaches of Immigration Detention Standard 7.1.3, which requires staff to be registered in the state or territory where they are working.
My Department has made it clear to GSL that these breaches are totally unacceptable. Significant sanctions were imposed on GSL as a result of the breaches.

item.label: (i)
item.para: and (b) The following table shows traditional trade apprenticeships and total New Apprenticeships commencements recorded against each New Apprenticeships Centre since 1 May 1998. The definition of apprentices uses a TYIMS identifier which classifies individual qualifications into an apprenticeship or traineeship according to how the qualification is assessed in a majority of States / Territories. This definition may differ from that used by other organisations. In responding to this question traditional trade apprenticeships have been identified as ‘Apprentices’ in the tables. As a result data for 2004/2005 and 2005/2006 will continue to increase over time as more training contracts are entered onto TYIMS with commencement dates in those financial years. quote.para: What sum under the Flagpole Funding Initiative was granted to each (a) government and (b) non-government school in the postcode area (i) 3337, (ii) 3338, (iii) 3435, (iv) 3437, (v) 3438, (vi) 3440, (vii) 3441, and (viii) 3442.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Government Schools

item.label: (i)
item.para: In postcode area 3337 one government school (Melton Primary School) received $1,198.64 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: In postcode area 3338 no funding was provided to government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: In postcode area 3435 one government school (Lancefield Primary School) received $1,345.00 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (iv) (v)
item.para: , (vi), (vii) In postcode areas 3437, 3438, 3440 and 3441 no funding was provided to government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (viii)
item.para: In postcode area 3442 one government school (Woodend Primary School) received $1,377 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Non-government Schools

item.label: (i)
item.para: In postcode area 3337 one non-government school (St Dominic’s Primary School) received $1,185.50 under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

item.label: (ii) (iii)
item.para: , (iv), (v), (vi), (vii) and (viii) In postcode areas 3338, 3435, 3437, 3438, 3440, 3441 and 3442 no funding was provided to non-government schools under the Flagpole Funding Initiative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister confirm that the Government is seeking ways to encourage migrants and refugees to settle in regional areas.

What is the Government doing so that in encouraging the regional settlement of migrants and refugees care is taken to ensure that resettlement is consolidated and that value is placed on the knowledge, networks and industry insight of the ‘local connection’.

Is the Minister aware that the tender to provide the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS) in the Newcastle and Hunter Region has been conferred on a consortium led by the Australian Centre for Languages (ACL) which is a Sydney-based, for profit, company with no local history or reputation in the Newcastle and Hunter region.

Is the Minister aware that with only a month before the new contracts for IHSS delivery commence, ACL has (a) shown no evidence of its client focus or seamless service delivery in the critical weeks of the roll-out, (b) paid one half-hour visit to the area, and (c) made one phone call to Centrelink in the region.

Is the Minister concerned that ACL has shown a lack of commitment to the regional settlement of migrants and refugees and has ignored local knowledge, insight and expertise; if not, can the Minister explain the basis on which the Government is satisfied with ACL’s commitment to the settlement of migrants and refugees in the Newcastle and Hunter Region.
Will the Minister ensure that local expertise will be included in the current and future tenders for IHSS service delivery; if not, why not.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, in line with the recommendations of the 2003 Report of the Review of Settlement Services for Migrants and Humanitarian Entrants and the Government’s broader strategy to increase regional migration, the Australian Government is actively encouraging new arrivals to settle in regional Australia.

The Australian Government is aware of the need to ensure that the appropriate settlement services are in place to cater for the particular needs of humanitarian entrants, family stream migrants and family members of skilled migrants with low English proficiency. In addition to available mainstream services, the Government delivers targeted assistance through the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS), the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) and the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS).

Yes, the contract to provide IHSS services in the Northern Metropolitan Region in NSW, encompassing the Newcastle and Hunter Region, has been awarded to a consortium led by the Australian Centre for Languages (ACL) and including Resolve FM, Mission Australia and STARTTS as partners.

There is significant evidence of the ACL consortium’s strong client focus and commitment to service delivery in the Newcastle and Hunter Region. Both Mission Australia and STARTTS have offices in Newcastle and ACL is acquiring an office in Newcastle. ACL is implementing a transition plan which was agreed by my Department and which includes a number of actions to facilitate a smooth transition to service delivery under the new arrangements.

Given that IHSS service delivery under new contracts does not begin until 1 October there is no evidence to suggest that the ACL consortium is not committed to the settlement of migrants and refugees in the Newcastle and Hunter Region. On the contrary, implementation activity already undertaken indicates that the consortium has a strong commitment to both regional settlement and to the utilisation of local knowledge.
Local knowledge and expertise was a requirement of the current IHSS tender and will be in any future IHSS tender.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 6 September 2005:

item.para: For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many Sudanese refugees have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division.
For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many other refugees from the African continent have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division.
For (a) 2002, (b) 2003, (c) 2004, and (d) 2005, how many migrants from the African continent have been settled (i) in total and (ii) in each federal electoral division.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr John Cobb

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The information requested is not available by federal electorate without a very considerable investment of resources. The following information shows the State or Territory of settlement of refugee and other migrant entrants at 31 August 2005, by country of birth.

For the purposes of this question, refugees have been defined as persons processed within visa sub-classes 200 - 217 (Refugee & Humanitarian overseas sub-classes) and visa sub-class 866 (onshore Permanent Protection). The data does not include Temporary Protection Visa holders.

item.para: Sudanese refugees by State/Territory of settlement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workforce Participation, in writing, on 6 September 2005:

item.para: Is he aware that Job Network providers are requesting that job seekers with a disability, such as epilepsy, should not advise a potential employer of their disability in job interviews?
What are the guidelines for Job Network providers on advising job seekers of their obligation to disclose disabilities to potential employers.

talker.name: Dutton, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Workforce Participation
talker.name: Mr Dutton

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: No. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations has not directed Job Network members to request job seekers with a disability not to advise potential employers.

Job Network members are bound by the Employment Services Contract 2003-2006 to comply with all relevant Australian laws, including anti-discrimination laws, in their dealings with job seekers. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations maintains a dedicated web site, JobAble, to provide a wide range of information and strategies to assist Job Network members in servicing people with disabilities as well as information for employers. JobAble provides links to the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, including that recruitment questions about an applicant’s disability should be linked to the requirements of the vacancy.
